   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Saudi Arabia</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in Southwestern Asia
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       "KSA" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/KSA_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="KSA (disambiguation)">KSA (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p> 
      <table class="infobox geography vcard" style="width:22em;font-size:88%;">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <th colspan="2" class="adr" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;padding:0.25em 0.33em 0.33em;line-height:1.2em;font-size:1.25em;">
          <div style="display:inline" class="fn org country-name">
           Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
          </div><br>
          <div style="padding-top:0.25em; font-weight:normal;">
           <span lang="ar" dir="rtl" style="font-style: normal;" title="Arabic-language text">ٱلْمَمْلَكَة ٱلْعَرَبِيَّة ٱلسَّعُوْدِيَّة</span>&nbsp;<span class="languageicon" style="font-size:100%;font-weight:normal;">(<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>)</span> 
           <br> <i><i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language romanization">Al-Mamlakah al-ʿArabīyah as-Saʿūdīyah</i></i> (The Saudi Arab Kingdom)
          </div></th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align:center;padding:0.5em 0;">
          <div style="display:table; width:100%;">

            <div style="padding-bottom:3px;">

            </div>

        <tr>
         <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
          <div style="line-height:1.2em;">
           <b>Motto:&nbsp;</b><span class="nowrap">لَا إِلٰهَ إِلَّا ٱلله، مُحَمَّدٌ رَسُوْلُ ٱلله</span> 
           <br> '<i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language romanization">Lā ʾilāha ʾillā Llāh, Muḥammadur rasūlu Llāh</i>' 
           <br> 'There is no god but Allah; Muhammad is the messenger of Allah.'<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[a]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/Shahada" title="Shahada">Shahada</a>)
          </div></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td colspan="2" class="anthem" style="text-align:center">
          <div style="line-height:1.2em;">
           <b>Anthem:&nbsp;</b><span lang="ar" dir="rtl" title="Arabic-language text">ٱلنَّشِيْد ٱلْوَطَنِي ٱلسَّعُوْدِي</span> 
           <br> "<a href="/wiki/National_Anthem_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="National Anthem of Saudi Arabia"><i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language romanization">an-Našīd al-Waṭanīy as-Saʿūdī</i></a>" 
           <br> "National Anthem of Saudi Arabia" 
           <br>

          </div></th>
         <td>24 October 1945</td>

          </div></th>

      </table> 
      <p><b>Saudi Arabia</b>,<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[c]</a></sup> officially the <b>Kingdom of Saudi Arabia</b>,<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[d]</a></sup> is a country in <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a> constituting the vast majority of the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a>. With a land area of approximately 2,150,000&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (830,000&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), Saudi Arabia is geographically the largest <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">sovereign state</a> in Western Asia, the second-largest in the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a> (after <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a>), the fifth-largest in <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">12th-largest in the world</a>. Saudi Arabia is bordered by <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a> to the north, <a href="/wiki/Kuwait" title="Kuwait">Kuwait</a> to the northeast, <a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">Bahrain</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a> to the east, <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a> to the southeast and <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a> to the south; it is separated from <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a> in the north-west by the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Aqaba" title="Gulf of Aqaba">Gulf of Aqaba</a>. Saudi Arabia is the only country with both a <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a> coast and a <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a> coast, and most of its terrain consists of arid desert, lowland, steppe and mountains. As of October 2018, the <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Economy of Saudi Arabia">Saudi economy</a> was the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">largest in the Middle East and the 18th largest in the world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_12-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-12">[10]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia also has one of the world's youngest populations, with approximately 50 percent of its population of 34.2 million being under 25 years old.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[13]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The territory that now constitutes Saudi Arabia was the site of several <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Prehistory of Arabia">ancient cultures</a> and civilizations. The prehistory of Saudi Arabia shows some of the earliest traces of human activity in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[14]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Major_religious_groups" title="Major religious groups">world's second-largest religion</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-landscape_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-landscape-19">[15]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, emerged in modern-day Saudi Arabia. In the early 7th century, the <a href="/wiki/Prophets_and_messengers_in_Islam" title="Prophets and messengers in Islam">Islamic prophet</a> <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> united the population of <a href="/wiki/Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabia">Arabia</a> and created a single Islamic religious polity.<sup id="cite_ref-James_E._Lindsay_2005_33_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-James_E._Lindsay_2005_33-20">[16]</a></sup> Following his death in 632, his followers rapidly expanded the territory under Muslim rule beyond Arabia, <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim conquests">conquering huge and unprecedented swathes of territory</a> (from the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> in the West to modern-day <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> in the East) in a matter of decades. Arab dynasties originating from modern-day Saudi Arabia founded the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun</a> (632–661), <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad</a> (661–750), <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasid</a> (750–1517) and <a href="/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate" title="Fatimid Caliphate">Fatimid</a> (909–1171) caliphates as well as numerous other dynasties in Asia, <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-21">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto1_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-22">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto2_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-23">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto3_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-24">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto4_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-25">[21]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The area of modern-day Saudi Arabia formerly consisted of mainly four distinct historical regions: <a href="/wiki/Hejaz" title="Hejaz">Hejaz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Najd" title="Najd">Najd</a> and parts of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Arabia" title="Eastern Arabia">Eastern Arabia</a> (<a href="/wiki/Eastern_Arabia" title="Eastern Arabia">Al-Ahsa</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Southern_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Southern Arabia">Southern Arabia</a> (<a href="/wiki/%27Asir_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="'Asir Region">'Asir</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[22]</a></sup> The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia was founded in 1932 by <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Saud" title="Ibn Saud">Ibn Saud</a>. He united the four regions into a single state through a series of conquests beginning in 1902 with the capture of <a href="/wiki/Riyadh" title="Riyadh">Riyadh</a>, the ancestral home of his family, the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Saud" title="House of Saud">House of Saud</a>. Saudi Arabia has since been a <a href="/wiki/Totalitarianism" title="Totalitarianism">totalitarian</a> <a href="/wiki/Absolute_monarchy" title="Absolute monarchy">absolute monarchy</a>, effectively a <a href="/wiki/Hereditary_dictatorship" class="mw-redirect" title="Hereditary dictatorship">hereditary dictatorship</a> governed along <a href="/wiki/Islamism" title="Islamism">Islamist</a> lines.<sup id="cite_ref-HT2003:_14_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HT2003:_14-27">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-28">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EIU_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EIU-30">[26]</a></sup> The ultraconservative <a href="/wiki/Wahhabism" title="Wahhabism">Wahhabi</a> religious movement within <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a> has been called "the predominant feature of <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Culture of Saudi Arabia">Saudi culture</a>", with its global spread largely financed by the oil and gas trade.<sup id="cite_ref-HT2003:_14_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HT2003:_14-27">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-28">[24]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia is sometimes called "the Land of the Two Holy Mosques" in reference to <a href="/wiki/Great_Mosque_of_Mecca" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Mosque of Mecca">Al-Masjid al-Haram</a> (in <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Al-Masjid_an-Nabawi" title="Al-Masjid an-Nabawi">Al-Masjid an-Nabawi</a> (in <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a>), the two holiest places in Islam. The state's official language is Arabic. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">Petroleum</a> was discovered on 3 March 1938 and followed up by several other finds in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Province,_Saudi_Arabia" title="Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia">Eastern Province</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[27]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia has since become the world's second <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_oil_production" title="List of countries by oil production">largest oil producer</a> (behind the US) and the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_oil_exports" title="List of countries by oil exports">largest oil exporter</a>, controlling the world's second largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves" title="List of countries by proven oil reserves">oil reserves</a> and the sixth largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_proven_reserves" title="List of countries by natural gas proven reserves">gas reserves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[28]</a></sup> The kingdom is categorized as a <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_high-income_economy" title="World Bank high-income economy">World Bank high-income economy</a> with a very high <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a><sup id="cite_ref-UNDR2014_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNDR2014-33">[29]</a></sup> and is the only Arab country to be part of the <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" class="mw-redirect" title="G-20 major economies">G-20 major economies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[30]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The state has attracted criticism for a variety of reasons including: its <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian-led_intervention_in_Yemen" title="Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen">role in the Yemeni Civil War</a>, <a href="/wiki/State-sponsored_terrorism#Saudi_Arabia" title="State-sponsored terrorism">sponsorship of Islamic terrorism</a>, its failure to adopt adequate measures against <a href="/wiki/Human_trafficking_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Human trafficking in Saudi Arabia">human trafficking</a>, and its <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Human rights in Saudi Arabia">poor human rights record</a>, which has been characterized by the <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_rights_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Women's rights in Saudi Arabia">lack of women's rights</a>, excessive and often extrajudicial <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Capital punishment in Saudi Arabia">use of capital punishment</a>, state-sponsored <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Freedom of religion in Saudi Arabia">discrimination against religious minorities</a> and <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Irreligion in Saudi Arabia">atheists</a>, state-sanctioned <a href="/wiki/Racism_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Racism in Saudi Arabia">racism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Antisemitism_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Antisemitism in Saudi Arabia">antisemitism</a>, and its <a href="/wiki/Legal_system_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Legal system of Saudi Arabia">strict interpretation of Shari'a law</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Bjørgo2004_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bjørgo2004-42">[38]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#Bundling_citations" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This claim has too many footnotes for reading to be smooth. (January 2021)">excessive citations</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>The kingdom spends 8% of its <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> on the military (highest in the world after <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[39]</a></sup> which places it as the world's third biggest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">military spender</a> behind the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-:2_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-44">[40]</a></sup> and the world's largest arms importer from 2015 to 2019, receiving half of all the US arms exports to the Middle East.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[42]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Bonn_International_Center_for_Conversion" title="Bonn International Center for Conversion">BICC</a>, Saudi Arabia is the 28th most militarized country in the world and enjoys the region's best military equipment qualititively, after <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[43]</a></sup> However, in recent years, there have been continuous calls for halting of arms sales to Saudi Arabia, mainly due to <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian-led_intervention_in_Yemen#Reports_of_war_crimes" title="Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen">alleged war crimes</a> in Yemen<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[44]</a></sup> and especially following the <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Jamal_Khashoggi" title="Assassination of Jamal Khashoggi">assassination of Jamal Khashoggi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[45]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[46]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Saudi Arabia is considered a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional</a> and <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-The_United_States_and_the_Great_Powers_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_United_States_and_the_Great_Powers-51">[47]</a></sup> In addition to being a member of the <a href="/wiki/Cooperation_Council_for_the_Arab_States_of_the_Gulf" class="mw-redirect" title="Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf">Gulf Cooperation Council</a>, it is an active and founding member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a>, <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a> and is also a <a href="/wiki/Major_non-NATO_ally" title="Major non-NATO ally">major non-NATO ally</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[48]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">
       <input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/House_of_Saud" title="House of Saud">House of Saud</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arab_(etymology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab (etymology)">Arab (etymology)</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Following the amalgamation of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hejaz" title="Kingdom of Hejaz">Kingdom of Hejaz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nejd" class="mw-redirect" title="Nejd">Nejd</a>, the new state was named <i>al-Mamlakah al-ʿArabīyah as-Saʿūdīyah</i> (a transliteration of <span lang="ar" dir="rtl" title="Arabic-language text">المملكة العربية السعودية</span> in <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>) by royal decree on 23 September 1932 by its founder, <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Saud" title="Ibn Saud">Abdulaziz bin Saud</a>. Although this is normally translated as "the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia" in English,<sup id="cite_ref-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia-53">[49]</a></sup> it literally means "the Saudi Arab kingdom",<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[50]</a></sup> or "the Arab Saudi Kingdom".<sup id="cite_ref-Safran1988_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Safran1988-55">[51]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The word "Saudi" is derived from the element <i>as-Saʿūdīyah</i> in the <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a> name of the country, which is a type of adjective known as a <a href="/wiki/Nisba_(onomastics)" title="Nisba (onomastics)">nisba</a>, formed from the dynastic name of the Saudi royal family, the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Saud" title="House of Saud">Al Saud</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">آل سعود</span>‎). Its inclusion expresses the view that the country is the personal possession of the royal family.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[52]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kamrava_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kamrava-57">[53]</a></sup> <i>Al Saud</i> is an <a href="/wiki/Arabic_name" title="Arabic name">Arabic name</a> formed by adding the word <i>Al</i>, meaning "family of" or "House of",<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[54]</a></sup> to the personal name of an ancestor. In the case of the <a href="/wiki/Al_Saud" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Saud">Al Saud</a>, this is <a href="/wiki/Saud_ibn_Muhammad_ibn_Muqrin" class="mw-redirect" title="Saud ibn Muhammad ibn Muqrin">Saud ibn Muhammad ibn Muqrin</a>, the father of the dynasty's 18th-century founder, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_bin_Saud" title="Muhammad bin Saud">Muhammad bin Saud</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[55]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="History of Saudi Arabia">History of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Pre-Islamic Arabia">Pre-Islamic Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg/190px-Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="284" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg/285px-Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg/380px-Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1712" data-file-height="2560"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pergamon-Museum_-_Anthropomorphe_Stele_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Anthropomorphic stela (4th millennium BC), sandstone, 57x27 cm, from El-Maakir-Qaryat al-Kaafa (National Museum, <a href="/wiki/Riyadh" title="Riyadh">Riyadh</a>)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>There is evidence that human habitation in the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> dates back to about 125,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[56]</a></sup> A 2011 study found that the first modern humans to spread east across Asia left Africa about 75,000 years ago across the <a href="/wiki/Bab-el-Mandeb" title="Bab-el-Mandeb">Bab-el-Mandeb</a> connecting the <a href="/wiki/Horn_of_Africa" title="Horn of Africa">Horn of Africa</a> and Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[57]</a></sup> The Arabian peninsula is regarded as a central figure in the understanding of hominin evolution and dispersals. Arabia underwent an extreme environmental fluctuation in the <a href="/wiki/Quaternary" title="Quaternary">Quaternary</a> that led to profound evolutionary and demographic changes. Arabia has a rich <a href="/wiki/Lower_Paleolithic" title="Lower Paleolithic">Lower Paleolithic</a> record, and the quantity of <a href="/wiki/Oldowan" title="Oldowan">Oldowan</a>-like sites in the region indicate a significant role that Arabia had played in the early hominin colonization of Eurasia.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[58]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> period, prominent cultures such as <a href="/wiki/Al-Magar" title="Al-Magar">Al-Magar</a>, whose center lay in modern-day southwestern Najd flourished. Al-Magar could be considered as a "Neolithic Revolution" in human knowledge and handicraft skills.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[59]</a></sup> The culture is characterized as being one of the world's first to involve the widespread domestication of animals, particularly the horse, during the Neolithic period.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[60]</a></sup> Aside from horses, animals such as sheep, goats, dogs, in particular of the <a href="/wiki/Saluki" title="Saluki">Saluki</a> breed, ostriches, falcons and fish were discovered in the form of stone statues and rock engravings. Al-Magar statues were made from local stone, and it seems that the statues were fixed in a central building that might have had a significant role on the social and religious life of the inhabitants.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>In November 2017, hunting scenes showing images of most likely domesticated dogs, resembling the <a href="/wiki/Canaan_dog" class="mw-redirect" title="Canaan dog">Canaan dog</a>, wearing leashes were discovered in Shuwaymis, a hilly region of northwestern Saudi Arabia. These rock engravings date back more than 8,000 years, making them the earliest depictions of dogs in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[61]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>At the end of the <a href="/wiki/4th_millennium_BC" title="4th millennium BC">4th millennium BC</a>, Arabia entered the <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> after witnessing drastic transformations; metals were widely used, and the period was characterized by its 2&nbsp;m high burials which was simultaneously followed by the existence of numerous temples, that included many free-standing sculptures originally painted with red colors.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[62]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Islamic">Pre-Islamic</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg/220px-Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg/330px-Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg/440px-Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3024" data-file-height="4032"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Statue_at_National_Museum_of_Korea.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The "Worshipping Servant" statue (2500 BC), above one metre in height, is much taller than any possible Mesopotamian or Harappan models. Photo courtesy of the <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Korea" title="National Museum of Korea">National Museum of Korea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180-67">[63]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The earliest sedentary culture in Saudi Arabia dates back to the <a href="/wiki/Ubaid_period" title="Ubaid period">Ubaid period</a>, upon discovering various pottery sherds at <a href="/wiki/Dosariyah" title="Dosariyah">Dosariyah</a>. Initial analysis of the discovery concluded that the eastern province of Saudi Arabia was the homeland of the earliest settlers of <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, and by extension, the likely origin of the <a href="/wiki/Sumer" title="Sumer">Sumerians</a>. However, experts such as <a href="/wiki/Joan_Oates" title="Joan Oates">Joan Oates</a> had the opportunity to see the Ubaid period sherds in eastern Arabia and consequently conclude that the sherds dates to the last two phases of Ubaid period (period three and four), while handful examples could be classified roughly as either Ubaid 3 or Ubaid 2. Thus the idea that colonists from Saudi Arabia had emigrated to southern Mesopotamia and founded the region's first sedentary culture was abandoned.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[64]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Climatic change and the onset of aridity may have brought about the end of this phase of settlement, as little archaeological evidence exists from the succeeding millennium.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[65]</a></sup> The settlement of the region picks up again in the period of <a href="/wiki/Dilmun" title="Dilmun">Dilmun</a> in the early 3rd millennium. Known records from <a href="/wiki/Uruk" title="Uruk">Uruk</a> refer to a place called <a href="/wiki/Dilmun" title="Dilmun">Dilmun</a>, associated in several occasions with copper and in later period it was a source of imported woods in southern Mesopotamia. A number of scholars have suggested that Dilmun originally designated the eastern province of Saudi Arabia, notably linked with the major Dilmunite settlements of Umm an-Nussi and Umm ar-Ramadh in the interior and Tarout on the coast. It is likely that <a href="/wiki/Tarout_Island" title="Tarout Island">Tarout Island</a> was the main port and the capital of Dilmun.<sup id="cite_ref-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180-67">[63]</a></sup> Mesopotamian inscribed clay tablets suggests that, in the early period of Dilmun, a form of hierarchical organized political structure existed. In 1966 an earthwork in <a href="/wiki/Tarout" class="mw-redirect" title="Tarout">Tarout</a> exposed an ancient burial field that yielded a large, impressive statue dating to the Dilmunite period (mid 3rd millennium BC). The statue was locally made under strong Mesopotamian influence on the artistic principle of Dilmun.<sup id="cite_ref-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180_67-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180-67">[63]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By 2200 BC, the centre of Dilmun shifted for unknown reasons from <a href="/wiki/Tarout_Island" title="Tarout Island">Tarout</a> and the Saudi Arabian mainland to the island of <a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">Bahrain</a>, and a highly developed settlement emerged there, where a labourious temple complex and thousands of burial mounds that dates to this period were discovered.<sup id="cite_ref-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180_67-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roads_of_Arabia_p._180-67">[63]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Qasr_al_Farid.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Qasr_al_Farid.JPG/300px-Qasr_al_Farid.JPG" decoding="async" width="300" height="172" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Qasr_al_Farid.JPG/450px-Qasr_al_Farid.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Qasr_al_Farid.JPG/600px-Qasr_al_Farid.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="1875"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Qasr_al_Farid.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i>Qaṣr Al-Farīd</i>, the largest of the 131 <a href="/wiki/Rock_cut_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Rock cut architecture">rock-cut</a> monumental tombs built from the 1st century BC to the 1st century AD, with their elaborately ornamented façades, at the extensive ancient <a href="/wiki/Nabatean" class="mw-redirect" title="Nabatean">Nabatean</a> archaeological site of <a href="/wiki/Hegra_(Mada%27in_Salih)" title="Hegra (Mada'in Salih)">Hegra</a> located in the area of <a href="/wiki/AlUla" title="AlUla">AlUla</a> within <a href="/wiki/Al_Madinah_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Madinah Region">Al Madinah Region</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Hejaz" title="Hejaz">Hejaz</a>. A UNESCO <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> since 2008.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>By the late <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a>, a historically recorded people and land (Midian and the Midianites) in the north-western portion of Saudi Arabia are well-documented in the <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a>. Centered in <a href="/wiki/Tabuk,_Saudi_Arabia" title="Tabuk, Saudi Arabia">Tabouk</a>, it stretched from <a href="/wiki/Wadi_Arabah" class="mw-redirect" title="Wadi Arabah">Wadi Arabah</a> in the north to the area of al-Wejh in the south.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[66]</a></sup> The capital of Midian was Qurayyah,<sup id="cite_ref-ArnoldStrawn2016_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArnoldStrawn2016-71">[67]</a></sup> it consists of a large fortified citadel encompassing 35 hectares and below it lies a walled settlement of 15 hectares. The city hosted as many as 10 to 12 thousand inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-Coogan2001_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Coogan2001-72">[68]</a></sup> The Midianites were depicted in two major events in the Bible that recount Israel's <a href="/wiki/Midian_war" class="mw-redirect" title="Midian war">two wars</a> with Median, somewhere in the early 11th century BC. Politically, the Midianite were described as having decentralized structure headed by five kings (Evi, Rekem, Tsur, Hur and Reba), the names appears to be toponyms of important Midianite settlements.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[69]</a></sup> It is common view that Midian designated a confederation of tribes, the sedentary element settled in the Hijaz while its nomadic affiliates pastured, and sometimes pillaged as far away land as Palestine.<sup id="cite_ref-Midian_p._163_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Midian_p._163-74">[70]</a></sup> The nomadic Midianites were one of the earliest exploiters of the domestication of camels that enabled them to navigate through the harsh terrains of the region.<sup id="cite_ref-Midian_p._163_74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Midian_p._163-74">[70]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg/220px-Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg/330px-Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg/440px-Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3024" data-file-height="4032"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Statue_of_a_man_at_National_Museum_of_Korea_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Colossal statue from <a href="/wiki/AlUla" title="AlUla">AlUla</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Hejaz" title="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> (6th–4th century BC), it followed the standardized artistic sculpting of the <a href="/wiki/Lihyan" title="Lihyan">Lihyanite</a> kingdom, the original statue was painted with white
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>At the end of the 7th century BC, an emerging kingdom appeared on the historical theater of north-western Arabia. It started as a Sheikdom of Dedan, which developed into the Kingdom of Lihyan tribe.<sup id="cite_ref-Lihyan_p._192_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lihyan_p._192-75">[71]</a></sup> The earliest attestation of state regality, King of Lihyan, was in the mid-sixth century BC.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[72]</a></sup> The second stage of the kingdom saw the transformation of Dedan from a mere city-state of which only influence they exerted was inside their city walls, to a kingdom that encompass much wider domain that marked the pinnacle of Lihyan civilization.<sup id="cite_ref-Lihyan_p._192_75-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lihyan_p._192-75">[71]</a></sup> The third state occurred during the early 3rd century BC with bursting economic activity between the south and north that made Lihyan acquire large influence suitable to its strategic position on the caravan road.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[73]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Lihyan was a powerful and highly organized ancient <a href="/wiki/Arabian" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabian">Arabian</a> kingdom that played a vital cultural and economic role in the north-western region of the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[74]</a></sup> The Lihyanites ruled over large domain from <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Yathrib</a> in the south and parts of the Levant in the north.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[75]</a></sup> In antiquity, <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Aqaba" title="Gulf of Aqaba">Gulf of Aqaba</a> used to be called Gulf of Lihyan. A testimony to the extensive influence that Lihyan acquired.<sup id="cite_ref-HiltonHilton1996_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HiltonHilton1996-80">[76]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Lihyanites fell into the hands of the <a href="/wiki/Nabataeans" title="Nabataeans">Nabataeans</a> around 65 BC upon their seizure of Hegra then marching to <a href="/wiki/Tayma" title="Tayma">Tayma</a>, and to their capital Dedan in 9 BC. The Nabataeans ruled large portions of north Arabia until their domain was annexed by the Roman Empire.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages_and_rise_of_Islam">Middle Ages and rise of Islam</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Caliphate" title="Caliphate">Caliphate</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Umayyad750ADloc.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Umayyad750ADloc.png/300px-Umayyad750ADloc.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="183" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Umayyad750ADloc.png/450px-Umayyad750ADloc.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Umayyad750ADloc.png/600px-Umayyad750ADloc.png 2x" data-file-width="1481" data-file-height="902"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Umayyad750ADloc.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>At its greatest extent, the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a> (661–750) covered 11,100,000&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (4,300,000&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi)<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[77]</a></sup> and 62 million people (29 percent of the world's population),<sup id="cite_ref-Blankinship_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Blankinship-82">[78]</a></sup> making it one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_empires" title="List of largest empires">largest empires in history</a> in both area and proportion of the world's population. It was also larger than any previous empire in history.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Shortly before the advent of Islam, apart from urban trading settlements (such as <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a>), much of what was to become Saudi Arabia was populated by nomadic pastoral tribal societies.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[79]</a></sup> The Islamic prophet Muhammad was born in Mecca in about 571 <a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">CE</a>. In the early 7th century, Muhammad united the <a href="/wiki/Tribes_of_Arabia" title="Tribes of Arabia">various tribes of the peninsula</a> and created a single Islamic religious polity.<sup id="cite_ref-James_E._Lindsay_2005_33_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-James_E._Lindsay_2005_33-20">[16]</a></sup> Following his death in 632, his followers rapidly expanded the territory under Muslim rule beyond Arabia, <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim conquests">conquering huge and unprecedented swathes of territory</a> (from the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> in west to modern day <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> in east) in a matter of decades. <a href="/wiki/Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabia">Arabia</a> soon became a more politically peripheral region of the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Muslim world</a> as the focus shifted to the vast and newly conquered lands.<sup id="cite_ref-James_E._Lindsay_2005_33_20-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-James_E._Lindsay_2005_33-20">[16]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Arab" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab">Arabs</a> originating from modern-day Saudi Arabia, the <a href="/wiki/Hejaz" title="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> in particular, founded the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun</a> (632–661), <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad</a> (661–750), <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasid</a> (750–1517) and the <a href="/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate" title="Fatimid Caliphate">Fatimid</a> (909–1171) caliphates.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-21">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto1_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-22">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto2_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-23">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto3_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-24">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto4_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-25">[21]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>From the 10th century to the early 20th century, Mecca and Medina were under the control of a local Arab ruler known as the <a href="/wiki/Sharif_of_Mecca" title="Sharif of Mecca">Sharif of Mecca</a>, but at most times the Sharif owed allegiance to the ruler of one of the major Islamic empires based in <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a> or <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>. Most of the remainder of what became Saudi Arabia reverted to traditional tribal rule.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[81]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg/180px-Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="270" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg/270px-Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg/360px-Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg 2x" data-file-width="506" data-file-height="760"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Siyer-i_Nebi_-_Imam_Ali_und_Hamza_bei_dem_vorgezogenen_Einzelkampf_in_Badr_gegen_die_G%C3%B6tzendiener.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Badr" title="Battle of Badr">Battle of Badr</a>, 13 March 624 CE
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>For much of the 10th century, the <a href="/wiki/Isma%27ilism" title="Isma'ilism">Isma'ili</a>-Shi'ite <a href="/wiki/Qarmatians" title="Qarmatians">Qarmatians</a> were the most powerful force in the Persian Gulf. In 930, the Qarmatians pillaged Mecca, outraging the Muslim world, particularly with their theft of the <a href="/wiki/Black_Stone" title="Black Stone">Black Stone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[82]</a></sup> In 1077–1078, an Arab Sheikh named <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_bin_Ali_Al_Uyuni" title="Abdullah bin Ali Al Uyuni">Abdullah bin Ali Al Uyuni</a> defeated the Qarmatians in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Arabia" title="Eastern Arabia">Bahrain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Al-Ahsa_Oasis" title="Al-Ahsa Oasis">al-Hasa</a> with the help of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Seljuq_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Seljuq Empire">Great Seljuq Empire</a> and founded the <a href="/wiki/Uyunid_dynasty" title="Uyunid dynasty">Uyunid dynasty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[84]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Uyunid_Emirate" title="Uyunid Emirate">Uyunid Emirate</a> later underwent expansion with its territory stretching from Najd to the <a href="/wiki/Syrian_desert" class="mw-redirect" title="Syrian desert">Syrian desert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Safa_Khulusi_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Safa_Khulusi-89">[85]</a></sup> They were overthrown by the <a href="/wiki/Usfurids" title="Usfurids">Usfurids</a> in 1253.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[86]</a></sup> Ufsurid rule was weakened after Persian rulers of <a href="/wiki/Ormus" title="Ormus">Hormuz</a> captured Bahrain and <a href="/wiki/Qatif" title="Qatif">Qatif</a> in 1320.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[87]</a></sup> The vassals of Ormuz, the Shia <a href="/wiki/Jarwanid_dynasty" title="Jarwanid dynasty">Jarwanid dynasty</a> came to rule eastern Arabia in the 14th century.<sup id="cite_ref-JuanCole_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JuanCole-92">[88]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[89]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Jabrids" title="Jabrids">Jabrids</a> took control of the region after overthrowing the Jarwanids in the 15th century and clashed with Hormuz for more than two decades over the region for its economic revenues, until finally agreeing to pay <a href="/wiki/Tribute" title="Tribute">tribute</a> in 1507.<sup id="cite_ref-JuanCole_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JuanCole-92">[88]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Al-Muntafiq" title="Al-Muntafiq">Al-Muntafiq</a> tribe later took over the region and came under <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> suzerainty. The <a href="/wiki/Bani_Khalid" title="Bani Khalid">Bani Khalid</a> tribe later revolted against them in the 17th century and took control.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[90]</a></sup> Their rule extended from <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a> to <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a> at its height and they too came under Ottoman suzerainty.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[91]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[92]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ottoman_Hejaz">Ottoman Hejaz</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_era_in_the_history_of_Saudi_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman era in the history of Saudi Arabia">Ottoman era in the history of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In the 16th century, the <a href="/wiki/Ottomans" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottomans">Ottomans</a> added the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a> coast (the Hejaz, <a href="/wiki/%27Asir_Province" title="'Asir Province">Asir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Arabia" title="Eastern Arabia">Al-Ahsa</a>) to the Empire and claimed <a href="/wiki/Suzerainty" title="Suzerainty">suzerainty</a> over the interior. One reason was to <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_naval_expeditions_in_the_Indian_Ocean" title="Ottoman naval expeditions in the Indian Ocean">thwart Portuguese attempts</a> to attack the Red Sea (hence the Hejaz) and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bernstein_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bernstein-97">[93]</a></sup> Ottoman degree of control over these lands varied over the next four centuries with the fluctuating strength or weakness of the Empire's central authority.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[95]</a></sup> These changes contributed to later uncertainties, such as the <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Ma%27an" title="Occupation of Ma'an">dispute with Transjordan over the inclusion of the sanjak of Ma'an</a>, including the cities of <a href="/wiki/Ma%27an" title="Ma'an">Ma'an</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aqaba" title="Aqaba">Aqaba</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foundation_of_the_Saud_dynasty">Foundation of the Saud dynasty</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Unification_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Unification of Saudi Arabia">Unification of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Arabia,_Egypt,_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Arabia%2C_Egypt%2C_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg/220px-Arabia%2C_Egypt%2C_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="187" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Arabia%2C_Egypt%2C_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg/330px-Arabia%2C_Egypt%2C_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Arabia%2C_Egypt%2C_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg/440px-Arabia%2C_Egypt%2C_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5784" data-file-height="4926"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Arabia,_Egypt,_Nubia_and_Abyssinia_1883_map.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Atlas map of Arabia and the wider region in 1883
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The emergence of what was to become the Saudi royal family, known as the Al Saud, began in <a href="/wiki/Nejd" class="mw-redirect" title="Nejd">Nejd</a> in central Arabia in 1744, when <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_bin_Saud" title="Muhammad bin Saud">Muhammad bin Saud</a>, founder of the dynasty, joined forces with the religious leader <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_ibn_Abd_al-Wahhab" title="Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab">Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[96]</a></sup> founder of the Wahhabi movement, a strict puritanical form of Sunni Islam.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[97]</a></sup> This alliance formed in the 18th century provided the ideological impetus to Saudi expansion and remains the basis of Saudi Arabian dynastic rule today.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[98]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Diriyah" title="Emirate of Diriyah">first "Saudi state"</a> established in 1744 in the area around <a href="/wiki/Riyadh" title="Riyadh">Riyadh</a>, rapidly expanded and briefly controlled most of the present-day territory of Saudi Arabia,<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[99]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wahhabi_sack_of_Karbala" title="Wahhabi sack of Karbala">sacking Karbala</a> in 1802 and <a href="/wiki/Destruction_of_early_Islamic_heritage_sites_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Destruction of early Islamic heritage sites in Saudi Arabia">capturing Mecca</a> in 1803, but was destroyed by 1818 by the Ottoman viceroy of <a href="/wiki/Egypt_Eyalet" title="Egypt Eyalet">Egypt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_of_Egypt" title="Muhammad Ali of Egypt">Mohammed Ali Pasha</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[100]</a></sup> A much smaller <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Nejd" title="Emirate of Nejd">second "Saudi state"</a>, located mainly in Nejd, was established in 1824. Throughout the rest of the 19th century, the Al Saud contested control of the interior of what was to become Saudi Arabia with another Arabian ruling family, the <a href="/wiki/Rashidi_dynasty" title="Rashidi dynasty">Al Rashid</a>, who ruled the <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Jabal_Shammar" title="Emirate of Jabal Shammar">Emirate of Jabal Shammar</a>. By 1891, the Al Rashid were victorious and the Al Saud were driven into exile in <a href="/wiki/Sheikhdom_of_Kuwait" title="Sheikhdom of Kuwait">Kuwait</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ibn_Saud_(kuwait_1910).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Ibn_Saud_%28kuwait_1910%29.jpg/220px-Ibn_Saud_%28kuwait_1910%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="271" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Ibn_Saud_%28kuwait_1910%29.jpg/330px-Ibn_Saud_%28kuwait_1910%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Ibn_Saud_%28kuwait_1910%29.jpg/440px-Ibn_Saud_%28kuwait_1910%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1299" data-file-height="1600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ibn_Saud_(kuwait_1910).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ibn_Saud" title="Ibn Saud">Abdulaziz Ibn Saud</a>, the founding father and first king of Saudi Arabia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>At the beginning of the 20th century, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> continued to control or have a suzerainty over most of the peninsula. Subject to this suzerainty, Arabia was ruled by a patchwork of tribal rulers,<sup id="cite_ref-Murphy_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Murphy-105">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[102]</a></sup> with the <a href="/wiki/Sharif_of_Mecca" title="Sharif of Mecca">Sharif of Mecca</a> having pre-eminence and ruling the <a href="/wiki/Hejaz_Vilayet" title="Hejaz Vilayet">Hejaz</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[103]</a></sup> In 1902, <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Rahman_bin_Faisal" class="mw-redirect" title="Abdul Rahman bin Faisal">Abdul Rahman</a>'s son, Abdul Aziz—later to be known as <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Saud" title="Ibn Saud">Ibn Saud</a>—recaptured control of Riyadh bringing the Al Saud back to Nejd, creating the <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Nejd_and_Hasa" title="Emirate of Nejd and Hasa">third "Saudi state"</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> Ibn Saud gained the support of the <a href="/wiki/Ikhwan" title="Ikhwan">Ikhwan</a>, a tribal army inspired by Wahhabism and led by <a href="/wiki/Faisal_Al-Dawish" class="mw-redirect" title="Faisal Al-Dawish">Faisal Al-Dawish</a>, and which had grown quickly after its foundation in 1912.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[104]</a></sup> With the aid of the Ikhwan, Ibn Saud captured <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Arabia" title="Eastern Arabia">Al-Ahsa</a> from the Ottomans in 1913. </p>
      <p>In 1916, with the encouragement and support of Britain (which was fighting the Ottomans in <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>), the Sharif of Mecca, <a href="/wiki/Hussein_bin_Ali,_Sharif_of_Mecca" title="Hussein bin Ali, Sharif of Mecca">Hussein bin Ali</a>, led a <a href="/wiki/Arab_Revolt" title="Arab Revolt">pan-Arab revolt</a> against the Ottoman Empire to create a united Arab state.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[105]</a></sup> Although the Arab Revolt of 1916 to 1918 failed in its objective, <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">the Allied</a> victory in World War I resulted in the end of Ottoman suzerainty and control in Arabia and Hussein bin Ali became <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hejaz" title="Kingdom of Hejaz">King of Hejaz</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[106]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ibn Saud avoided involvement in the Arab Revolt, and instead continued his struggle with the Al Rashid. Following the latter's final defeat, he took the title <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Nejd" title="Sultanate of Nejd">Sultan of Nejd</a> in 1921. With the help of the Ikhwan, the Kingdom of Hejaz was conquered in 1924–25 and on 10 January 1926, Ibn Saud declared himself King of Hejaz.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[107]</a></sup> A year later, he added the title of King of Nejd. For the next five years, he administered the two parts of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hejaz_and_Nejd" title="Kingdom of Hejaz and Nejd">his dual kingdom</a> as separate units.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the conquest of the Hejaz, the Ikhwan leadership's objective switched to expansion of the Wahhabist realm into the British protectorates of <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Transjordan" title="Emirate of Transjordan">Transjordan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mandatory_Iraq" title="Mandatory Iraq">Iraq</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sheikhdom_of_Kuwait" title="Sheikhdom of Kuwait">Kuwait</a>, and began raiding those territories. This met with Ibn Saud's opposition, as he recognized the danger of a direct conflict with the British. At the same time, the Ikhwan became disenchanted with Ibn Saud's domestic policies which appeared to favor modernization and the increase in the number of non-Muslim foreigners in the country. As a result, they turned against Ibn Saud and, after a two-year struggle, were defeated in 1929 at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Sabilla" title="Battle of Sabilla">Battle of Sabilla</a>, where their leaders were massacred.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[108]</a></sup> On 23 September 1932, the two <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hejaz_and_Nejd" title="Kingdom of Hejaz and Nejd">kingdoms of the Hejaz and Nejd</a> were united as the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia,<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> and that date is now a national holiday called <a href="/wiki/Saudi_National_Day" title="Saudi National Day">Saudi National Day</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[109]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-unification">Post-unification</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Modern_history_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Modern history of Saudi Arabia">Modern history of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg/220px-Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="257" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg/330px-Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg/440px-Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1010" data-file-height="1179"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Arabia_Saudi_political.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Political map of Saudi Arabia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The new kingdom was reliant on limited agriculture and pilgrimage revenues.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[110]</a></sup> In 1938, vast reserves of <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">oil</a> were discovered in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Arabia" title="Eastern Arabia">Al-Ahsa</a> region along the coast of the Persian Gulf, and full-scale development of the oil fields began in 1941 under the US-controlled <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Aramco" title="Saudi Aramco">Aramco (Arabian American Oil Company)</a>. Oil provided Saudi Arabia with economic prosperity and substantial political leverage internationally.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Cultural life rapidly developed, primarily in the Hejaz, which was the center for newspapers and radio. However, the large influx of <a href="/wiki/Foreign_workers_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Foreign workers in Saudi Arabia">foreign workers in Saudi Arabia</a> in the oil industry increased the pre-existing propensity for <a href="/wiki/Xenophobia" title="Xenophobia">xenophobia</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="Your explanation here (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> At the same time, the government became increasingly wasteful and extravagant. By the 1950s this had led to large governmental deficits and excessive foreign borrowing.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1953, <a href="/wiki/Saud_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Saud of Saudi Arabia">Saud of Saudi Arabia</a> succeeded as the king of Saudi Arabia, on his father's death, until 1964 when he was deposed in favor of his half brother <a href="/wiki/Faisal_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Faisal of Saudi Arabia">Faisal of Saudi Arabia</a>, after an intense rivalry, fueled by doubts in the royal family over Saud's competence. In 1972, Saudi Arabia gained a 20 percent control in Aramco, thereby decreasing US control over Saudi oil.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>In 1973, Saudi Arabia led an oil boycott against the Western countries that supported Israel in the <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War" title="Yom Kippur War">Yom Kippur War</a> against Egypt and Syria. Oil prices quadrupled.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> In 1975, Faisal was assassinated by his nephew, Prince <a href="/wiki/Faisal_bin_Musaid" class="mw-redirect" title="Faisal bin Musaid">Faisal bin Musaid</a> and was succeeded by his half-brother <a href="/wiki/Khalid_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Khalid of Saudi Arabia">King Khalid</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Al-Rasheed_136-137_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Al-Rasheed_136-137-115">[111]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg/220px-Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="241" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg/330px-Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg/440px-Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1827" data-file-height="2000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_2003_CIA_map.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of Saudi Arabian administrative regions and roadways
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>By 1976, Saudi Arabia had become the largest oil producer in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[112]</a></sup> Khalid's reign saw economic and social development progress at an extremely rapid rate, transforming the infrastructure and educational system of the country;<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> in foreign policy, close ties with the US were developed.<sup id="cite_ref-Al-Rasheed_136-137_115-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Al-Rasheed_136-137-115">[111]</a></sup> In 1979, two events occurred which greatly concerned the government,<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[113]</a></sup> and had a long-term influence on Saudi foreign and domestic policy. The first was the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Revolution" title="Iranian Revolution">Iranian Islamic Revolution</a>. It was feared that the country's <a href="/wiki/Shi%27a_Islam_in_Saudi_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Shi'a Islam in Saudi Arabia">Shi'ite minority</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Province,_Saudi_Arabia" title="Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia">Eastern Province</a> (which is also the location of the oil fields) might rebel under the influence of their Iranian co-religionists. There were several anti-government uprisings in the region such as the <a href="/wiki/1979_Qatif_Uprising" title="1979 Qatif Uprising">1979 Qatif Uprising</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Toby_Craig_Jones_2010_218–219_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toby_Craig_Jones_2010_218–219-118">[114]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The second event was the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Mosque_Seizure" class="mw-redirect" title="Grand Mosque Seizure">Grand Mosque Seizure</a> in Mecca by Islamist extremists. The militants involved were in part angered by what they considered to be the corruption and un-Islamic nature of the Saudi government.<sup id="cite_ref-Toby_Craig_Jones_2010_218–219_118-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toby_Craig_Jones_2010_218–219-118">[114]</a></sup> The government regained control of the mosque after 10 days and those captured were executed. Part of the response of the royal family was to enforce a much stricter observance of traditional religious and social norms in the country (for example, the closure of cinemas) and to give the <a href="/wiki/Ulema" class="mw-redirect" title="Ulema">Ulema</a> a greater role in government.<sup id="cite_ref-Hegghammer24_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hegghammer24-119">[115]</a></sup> Neither entirely succeeded as <a href="/wiki/Islamism" title="Islamism">Islamism</a> continued to grow in strength.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[116]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1980, Saudi Arabia bought out the American interests in Aramco.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[117]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>King Khalid died of a heart attack in June 1982. He was succeeded by his brother, <a href="/wiki/Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Fahd of Saudi Arabia">King Fahd</a>, who added the title "Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques" to his name in 1986 in response to considerable fundamentalist pressure to avoid use of "majesty" in association with anything except God. Fahd continued to develop close relations with the United States and increased the purchase of American and British military equipment.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The vast wealth generated by oil revenues was beginning to have an even greater impact on Saudi society. It led to rapid technological (but not cultural) modernization, urbanization, mass public education and the creation of new media. This and the presence of increasingly large numbers of foreign workers greatly affected traditional Saudi norms and values. Although there was dramatic change in the social and economic life of the country, political power continued to be monopolized by the royal family<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> leading to discontent among many Saudis who began to look for wider participation in government.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[118]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the 1980s, Saudi Arabia spent $25 billion in support of <a href="/wiki/Saddam_Hussein" title="Saddam Hussein">Saddam Hussein</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Iraq_War" title="Iran–Iraq War">Iran–Iraq War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[119]</a></sup> However, Saudi Arabia condemned the <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Kuwait" title="Invasion of Kuwait">Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in 1990</a> and asked the US to intervene.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> King Fahd allowed American and coalition troops to be stationed in Saudi Arabia. He invited the Kuwaiti government and many of its citizens to stay in Saudi Arabia, but expelled citizens of Yemen and <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a> because of their governments' support of Iraq. In 1991, Saudi Arabian forces were involved both in bombing raids on Iraq and in the land invasion that helped to liberate Kuwait.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Saudi Arabia's relations with the West began to cause growing concern among some of the ulema and students of sharia law and was one of the issues that led to <a href="/wiki/List_of_militant_incidents_in_Saudi_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="List of militant incidents in Saudi Arabia">an increase in Islamist terrorism</a> in Saudi Arabia, as well as <a href="/wiki/Islamic_terrorism" title="Islamic terrorism">Islamist terrorist attacks</a> in Western countries by Saudi nationals. <a href="/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden" title="Osama bin Laden">Osama bin Laden</a> was a Saudi citizen (until stripped of his citizenship in 1994) and was responsible for the <a href="/wiki/1998_U.S._embassy_bombings" class="mw-redirect" title="1998 U.S. embassy bombings">1998 U.S. embassy bombings</a> in East Africa and the 2000 <a href="/wiki/USS_Cole_bombing" title="USS Cole bombing">USS Cole bombing</a> near the port of <a href="/wiki/Aden" title="Aden">Aden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a>. 15 of the 19 terrorists involved in <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a> in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, and near <a href="/wiki/Shanksville,_Pennsylvania" title="Shanksville, Pennsylvania">Shanksville, Pennsylvania</a> were Saudi nationals.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[120]</a></sup> Many Saudis who did not support the <a href="/wiki/Islamist" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamist">Islamist</a> terrorists were nevertheless deeply unhappy with the government's policies.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[121]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_(large).gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_%28large%29.gif/220px-Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_%28large%29.gif" decoding="async" width="220" height="194" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_%28large%29.gif/330px-Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_%28large%29.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_%28large%29.gif/440px-Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_%28large%29.gif 2x" data-file-width="959" data-file-height="844"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Oil_and_Gas_Infrastructure_Persian_Gulf_(large).gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">oil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">gas</a> pipelines in the Middle-East
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Islamism was not the only source of hostility to the government. Although now extremely wealthy, Saudi Arabia's economy was near stagnant. High taxes and a growth in unemployment have contributed to discontent, and has been reflected in a rise in civil unrest, and discontent with the royal family. In response, a number of limited "reforms" were initiated by King Fahd. In March 1992, he introduced the "<a href="/wiki/Basic_Law_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Basic Law of Saudi Arabia">Basic Law</a>", which emphasized the duties and responsibilities of a ruler. In December 1993, the Consultative Council was inaugurated. It is composed of a chairman and 60 members—all chosen by the King. The King's intent was to respond to dissent while making as few actual changes in the status quo as possible.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Fahd made it clear that he did not have democracy in mind: "A system based on elections is not consistent with our Islamic creed, which [approves of] government by consultation [shūrā]."<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1995, Fahd suffered a debilitating stroke, and the Crown Prince, <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Abdullah of Saudi Arabia">Abdullah</a>, assumed the role of <i>de facto</i> <a href="/wiki/Regent" title="Regent">regent</a>, taking on the day-to-day running of the country. However, his authority was hindered by conflict with Fahd's full brothers (known, with Fahd, as the "<a href="/wiki/Sudairi_Seven" title="Sudairi Seven">Sudairi Seven</a>").<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[122]</a></sup> From the 1990s, signs of discontent continued and included, in 2003 and 2004, a series of bombings and armed violence in Riyadh, Jeddah, Yanbu and Khobar.<sup id="cite_ref-Cordesman_2009_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cordesman_2009-127">[123]</a></sup> In February–April 2005, the first-ever nationwide municipal elections were held in Saudi Arabia. Women were not allowed to take part in the poll.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2005, King Fahd died and was succeeded by Abdullah, who continued the policy of minimum reform and clamping down on protests. The king introduced a number of economic reforms aimed at reducing the country's reliance on oil revenue: limited deregulation, encouragement of foreign investment, and privatization. In February 2009, <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Abdullah of Saudi Arabia">Abdullah</a> announced a series of governmental changes to the judiciary, armed forces, and various ministries to modernize these institutions including the replacement of senior appointees in the judiciary and the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_religious_police" title="Islamic religious police">Mutaween</a> (religious police) with more moderate individuals and the appointment of the country's first female deputy minister.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_history_84-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_history-84">[80]</a></sup> </p>
