      <p>On 29 January 2011, hundreds of protesters gathered in the city of <a href="/wiki/Jeddah" title="Jeddah">Jeddah</a> in a rare display of criticism against the city's poor infrastructure after deadly floods swept through the city, killing 11 people.<sup id="cite_ref-Montreal_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Montreal-128">[124]</a></sup> Police stopped the demonstration after about 15 minutes and arrested 30 to 50 people.<sup id="cite_ref-Reuters_Dozens_detained_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters_Dozens_detained-129">[125]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since 2011, Saudi Arabia has been affected by its own <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9313_Saudi_Arabian_protests" class="mw-redirect" title="2011–13 Saudi Arabian protests">Arab Spring protests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Fisk_troops_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fisk_troops-130">[126]</a></sup> In response, King Abdullah announced on 22 February 2011 a series of benefits for citizens amounting to $36 billion, of which $10.7 billion was earmarked for <a href="/wiki/Housing" title="Housing">housing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[127]</a></sup> No political reforms were announced as part of the package, though some prisoners indicted for financial crimes were pardoned.<sup id="cite_ref-AlJazeeraEnglishBenefits_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AlJazeeraEnglishBenefits-132">[128]</a></sup> On 18 March the same year, King Abdullah announced a package of $93 billion, which included 500,000 new homes to a cost of $67 billion, in addition to creating 60,000 new security jobs.<sup id="cite_ref-theguardian1_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-theguardian1-133">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[130]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Although male-only <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_municipal_elections,_2011" class="mw-redirect" title="Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2011">municipal elections were held on 29 September 2011</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-alawsat_details_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alawsat_details-135">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bloom_women_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bloom_women-136">[132]</a></sup> Abdullah allowed women to vote and be elected in the <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_municipal_elections,_2015" class="mw-redirect" title="Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2015">2015 municipal elections</a>, and also to be nominated to the <a href="/wiki/Consultative_Assembly_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia">Shura Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-oman_observer_electionday_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oman_observer_electionday-137">[133]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since 2001, Saudi Arabia has engaged in <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_Saudi_Arabia#The_Internet" title="Censorship in Saudi Arabia">widespread internet censorship</a>. Most online censorship generally falls into two categories: one based on censoring "immoral" (mostly <a href="/wiki/Pornography" title="Pornography">pornographic</a> and <a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a>-supportive websites along with websites promoting any religious ideology other than Sunni Islam) and one based on a blacklist run by <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Media_(Saudi_Arabia)" title="Ministry of Media (Saudi Arabia)">Saudi Arabia's Ministry of Media</a>, which primarily censors websites critical of the Saudi regime or associated with parties that are opposed to or opposed by Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[136]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Politics of Saudi Arabia">Politics of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; float:left; margin-right:9px; margin-left:2px;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/File:Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9,_2013.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Salman bin Abdull aziz December 9, 2013.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9%2C_2013.jpg/157px-Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9%2C_2013.jpg" decoding="async" width="157" height="160" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9%2C_2013.jpg/236px-Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9%2C_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9%2C_2013.jpg/314px-Salman_bin_Abdull_aziz_December_9%2C_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1360" data-file-height="1386"></a> </td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mohammed_Bin_Salman_al-Saud2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Mohammed Bin Salman al-Saud2.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Mohammed_Bin_Salman_al-Saud2.jpg/128px-Mohammed_Bin_Salman_al-Saud2.jpg" decoding="async" width="128" height="160" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Mohammed_Bin_Salman_al-Saud2.jpg/192px-Mohammed_Bin_Salman_al-Saud2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Mohammed_Bin_Salman_al-Saud2.jpg/256px-Mohammed_Bin_Salman_al-Saud2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="2500"></a> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Salman of Saudi Arabia">Salman Al Saud</a><br><a href="/wiki/King_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="King of Saudi Arabia">King</a> and<br><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Prime Minister of Saudi Arabia">Prime Minister</a> </td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Mohammad_bin_Salman" class="mw-redirect" title="Mohammad bin Salman">Mohammad bin Salman</a><br><a href="/wiki/Crown_Prince_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia">Crown Prince</a> </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>Saudi Arabia is an <a href="/wiki/Absolute_monarchy" title="Absolute monarchy">absolute monarchy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Cavendish78_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cavendish78-141">[137]</a></sup> However, according to the <a href="/wiki/Basic_Law_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Basic Law of Saudi Arabia">Basic Law of Saudi Arabia</a> adopted by royal decree in 1992, the king must comply with <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a> (Islamic law) and the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>, while the Quran and the <a href="/wiki/Sunnah" title="Sunnah">Sunnah</a> (the traditions of Muhammad) are declared to be the country's constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-Gerhard_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gerhard-142">[138]</a></sup> No political parties or national elections are permitted.<sup id="cite_ref-Cavendish78_141-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cavendish78-141">[137]</a></sup> Critics regard it as a <a href="/wiki/Totalitarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Totalitarian">totalitarian</a> <a href="/wiki/Dictatorship" title="Dictatorship">dictatorship</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SaudiDic_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SaudiDic-143">[139]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i> rated the Saudi government as the fifth most authoritarian government out of 167 rated in its 2012 <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-EIU_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EIU-30">[26]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> gave it its lowest "Not Free" rating, 7.0 ("1=best, 7=worst") for 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-FH2019_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FH2019-144">[140]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the absence of national elections and political parties,<sup id="cite_ref-Cavendish78_141-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cavendish78-141">[137]</a></sup> politics in Saudi Arabia takes place in two distinct arenas: within the royal family, the Al Saud, and between the royal family and the rest of Saudi society.<sup id="cite_ref-Noreng97_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Noreng97-145">[141]</a></sup> Outside of the Al-Saud, participation in the political process is limited to a relatively small segment of the population and takes the form of the royal family consulting with the ulema, tribal sheikhs and members of important commercial families on major decisions.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-146">[142]</a></sup> This process is not reported by the Saudi media.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[143]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By custom, all males of full age have a right to petition the king directly through the traditional tribal meeting known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Majlis" title="Majlis">majlis</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Cavendish92_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cavendish92-148">[144]</a></sup> In many ways the approach to government differs little from the traditional system of tribal rule. Tribal identity remains strong and, outside of the royal family, political influence is frequently determined by tribal affiliation, with tribal sheikhs maintaining a considerable degree of influence over local and national events.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_146-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-146">[142]</a></sup> As mentioned earlier, in recent years there have been limited steps to widen political participation such as the establishment of the Consultative Council in the early 1990s and the National Dialogue Forum in 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-Al-Rasheed242_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Al-Rasheed242-149">[145]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The rule of the Al Saud faces political opposition from four sources: <a href="/wiki/Sunni" class="mw-redirect" title="Sunni">Sunni</a> <a href="/wiki/Islamist" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamist">Islamist</a> activism; liberal critics; the <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Shia Islam in Saudi Arabia">Shi'ite minority</a>—particularly in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Province,_Saudi_Arabia" title="Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia">Eastern Province</a>; and long-standing tribal and <a href="/wiki/Regionalism_(politics)" title="Regionalism (politics)">regionalist</a> particularistic opponents (for example in the Hejaz).<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[146]</a></sup> Of these, the minority activists have been the most prominent threat to the government and have in recent years perpetrated a number of <a href="/wiki/List_of_militant_incidents_in_Saudi_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="List of militant incidents in Saudi Arabia">violent incidents in the country</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Cordesman_2009_127-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cordesman_2009-127">[123]</a></sup> However, open protest against the government, even if peaceful, is not tolerated.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Monarchy_and_royal_family">Monarchy and royal family</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/House_of_Saud" title="House of Saud">House of Saud</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg/220px-Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg/330px-Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg/440px-Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="2885"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ivana_Trump_shakes_hands_with_Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>King <a href="/wiki/Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Fahd of Saudi Arabia">Fahd</a> with US President <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> and future US President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> in 1985. The US and Saudi Arabia <a href="/wiki/Operation_Cyclone" title="Operation Cyclone">supplied money and arms</a> to the anti-Soviet <i><a href="/wiki/Mujahideen" title="Mujahideen">mujahideen</a></i> fighters in Afghanistan.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The king combines legislative, executive, and judicial functions<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_146-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-146">[142]</a></sup> and royal decrees form the basis of the country's legislation.<sup id="cite_ref-Campbell_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Campbell-151">[147]</a></sup> The king is also the prime minister, and presides over the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Council of Ministers of Saudi Arabia">Council of Ministers of Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Consultative_Assembly_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia">Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia</a>. </p>
      <p>The royal family dominates the political system. The family's vast numbers allow it to control most of the kingdom's important posts and to have an involvement and presence at all levels of government.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[148]</a></sup> The number of princes is estimated to be at least 7,000, with most power and influence being wielded by the 200 or so male descendants of Ibn Saud.<sup id="cite_ref-FT_Saud_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FT_Saud-153">[149]</a></sup> The key ministries are generally reserved for the royal family,<sup id="cite_ref-Cavendish78_141-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cavendish78-141">[137]</a></sup> as are the 13 regional governorships.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[150]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Long term political and government appointments have resulted in the creation of "power fiefdoms" for senior princes,<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[151]</a></sup> such as those of King Abdullah, who had been Commander of the <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_National_Guard" title="Saudi Arabian National Guard">National Guard</a> since 1963 (until 2010, when he appointed his son to replace him),<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[152]</a></sup> former Crown <a href="/wiki/Sultan_bin_Abdulaziz" class="mw-redirect" title="Sultan bin Abdulaziz">Prince Sultan</a>, Minister of Defence and Aviation from 1962 to his death in 2011, former crown prince <a href="/wiki/Nayef_bin_Abdul_Aziz" class="mw-redirect" title="Nayef bin Abdul Aziz">Prince Nayef</a> who was the Minister of Interior from 1975 to his death in 2012, <a href="/wiki/Saud_bin_Faisal_bin_Abdulaziz_Al_Saud" title="Saud bin Faisal bin Abdulaziz Al Saud">Prince Saud</a> who had been Minister of Foreign Affairs since 1975<sup id="cite_ref-bio_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bio-157">[153]</a></sup> and current <a href="/wiki/Salman_bin_Abdulaziz_Al_Saud" class="mw-redirect" title="Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud">King Salman</a>, who was Minister of Defense and Aviation before he was crown prince and Governor of the <a href="/wiki/Riyadh_Province" title="Riyadh Province">Riyadh Province</a> from 1962 to 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[154]</a></sup> The current Minister of Defense is <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_bin_Salman_Al_Saud" class="mw-redirect" title="Mohammad bin Salman Al Saud">Prince Mohammad bin Salman</a>, the son of King Salman and Crown Prince.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[155]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The royal family is politically divided by factions based on clan loyalties, personal ambitions and ideological differences.<sup id="cite_ref-Noreng97_145-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Noreng97-145">[141]</a></sup> The most powerful clan faction is known as the '<a href="/wiki/Sudairi" class="mw-redirect" title="Sudairi">Sudairi</a> Seven', comprising the late King Fahd and his full brothers and their descendants.<sup id="cite_ref-Economist_Succession_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist_Succession-160">[156]</a></sup> Ideological divisions include issues over the speed and direction of reform,<sup id="cite_ref-Kostiner236_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kostiner236-161">[157]</a></sup> and whether the role of the ulema should be increased or reduced. There were divisions within the family over who should succeed to the throne after the accession or earlier death of Prince Sultan.<sup id="cite_ref-Economist_Succession_160-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist_Succession-160">[156]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-David33_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-David33-162">[158]</a></sup> When prince Sultan died before ascending to the throne on 21 October 2011, King Abdullah appointed Prince Nayef as crown prince.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[159]</a></sup> The following year Prince Nayef also died before ascending to the throne.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[160]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Secretary_of_Defense_Chuck_Hagel_walks_with_Saudi_Deputy_Minister_of_Defense_Prince_Fahd_bin_Abdullah_before_departing_Riyadh,_Saudi_Arabia,_on_April_24,_2013_130424-D-BW835-179.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Secretary_of_Defense_Chuck_Hagel_walks_with_Saudi_Deputy_Minister_of_Defense_Prince_Fahd_bin_Abdullah_before_departing_Riyadh%2C_Saudi_Arabia%2C_on_April_24%2C_2013_130424-D-BW835-179.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Secretary_of_Defense_Chuck_Hagel_walks_with_Saudi_Deputy_Minister_of_Defense_Prince_Fahd_bin_Abdullah_before_departing_Riyadh%2C_Saudi_Arabia%2C_on_April_24%2C_2013_130424-D-BW835-179.jpg/330px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Secretary_of_Defense_Chuck_Hagel_walks_with_Saudi_Deputy_Minister_of_Defense_Prince_Fahd_bin_Abdullah_before_departing_Riyadh%2C_Saudi_Arabia%2C_on_April_24%2C_2013_130424-D-BW835-179.jpg/440px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3891" data-file-height="2590"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Secretary_of_Defense_Chuck_Hagel_walks_with_Saudi_Deputy_Minister_of_Defense_Prince_Fahd_bin_Abdullah_before_departing_Riyadh,_Saudi_Arabia,_on_April_24,_2013_130424-D-BW835-179.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>As many as 500 princes, government ministers, and business people, including Prince <a href="/wiki/Fahd_bin_Abdullah_bin_Mohammed_Al_Saud" title="Fahd bin Abdullah bin Mohammed Al Saud">Fahd bin Abdullah</a>, were arrested by Saudi Arabian authorities as part of the <a href="/wiki/2017_Saudi_Arabian_purge" class="mw-redirect" title="2017 Saudi Arabian purge">2017 Saudi Arabian purge</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Saudi government and the royal family have often, over many years, been accused of corruption.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[161]</a></sup> In a country that is said to "belong" to the royal family and is <a href="/wiki/Etymology_of_Saudi_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Etymology of Saudi Arabia">named for them</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Kamrava_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kamrava-57">[53]</a></sup> the lines between state assets and the personal wealth of senior princes are blurred.<sup id="cite_ref-FT_Saud_153-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FT_Saud-153">[149]</a></sup> The extent of corruption has been described as systemic<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[162]</a></sup> and endemic,<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[163]</a></sup> and its existence was acknowledged<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[164]</a></sup> and defended<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[165]</a></sup> by <a href="/wiki/Bandar_bin_Sultan" class="mw-redirect" title="Bandar bin Sultan">Prince Bandar bin Sultan</a> (a senior member of the royal family<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[166]</a></sup>) in an interview in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-PBS_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PBS-171">[167]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Although corruption allegations have often been limited to broad undocumented accusations,<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[168]</a></sup> specific allegations were made in 2007, when it was claimed that the British defence contractor <a href="/wiki/BAE_Systems" title="BAE Systems">BAE Systems</a> had paid Prince Bandar US$2 billion in bribes relating to the <a href="/wiki/Al-Yamamah_arms_deal" title="Al-Yamamah arms deal">Al-Yamamah arms deal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[169]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[170]</a></sup> Prince Bandar denied the allegations.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[171]</a></sup> Investigations by both US and UK authorities resulted, in 2010, in <a href="/wiki/Plea_bargain" title="Plea bargain">plea bargain</a> agreements with the company, by which it paid $447 million in fines but did not admit to bribery.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[172]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">Transparency International</a> in its annual <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a> for 2010 gave Saudi Arabia a score of 4.7 (on a scale from 0 to 10 where 0 is "highly corrupt" and 10 is "highly clean").<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[173]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia has undergone a process of political and social reform, such as to increase public transparency and good governance. However, nepotism and patronage are widespread when doing business in the country. The enforcement of the anti-corruption laws is selective and public officials engage in corruption with impunity. A number of prominent Saudi Arabian princes, government ministers, and businesspeople, including Prince <a href="/wiki/Al-Waleed_bin_Talal" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-Waleed bin Talal">Al-Waleed bin Talal</a>, were <a href="/wiki/2017_Saudi_Arabian_anti-corruption_arrests" class="mw-redirect" title="2017 Saudi Arabian anti-corruption arrests">arrested in Saudi Arabia</a> in November 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[174]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There has been mounting pressure to reform and modernize the royal family's rule, an agenda championed by King Abdullah both before and after his accession in 2005. The creation of the Consultative Council in the early 1990s did not satisfy demands for political participation, and, in 2003, an annual <i>National Dialogue Forum</i> was announced that would allow selected professionals and intellectuals to publicly debate current national issues, within certain prescribed parameters. In 2005, the first municipal elections were held. In 2007, the <a href="/wiki/Allegiance_Council" title="Allegiance Council">Allegiance Council</a> was created to regulate the succession.<sup id="cite_ref-Al-Rasheed242_149-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Al-Rasheed242-149">[145]</a></sup> In 2009, the king made significant personnel changes to the government by appointing reformers to key positions and the first woman to a ministerial post.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[175]</a></sup> However, these changes have been criticized as being too slow or merely cosmetic.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[176]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Al_ash-Sheikh_and_role_of_the_ulema">Al ash-Sheikh and role of the ulema</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG/220px-Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG/330px-Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG/440px-Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG 2x" data-file-width="5124" data-file-height="3212"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh_Senate_of_Poland_02.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Abdullah_ibn_Muhammad_Al_ash-Sheikh" title="Abdullah ibn Muhammad Al ash-Sheikh">Abdullah ibn Muhammad Al ash-Sheikh</a> with <a href="/wiki/Bogdan_Borusewicz" title="Bogdan Borusewicz">Bogdan Borusewicz</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Polish_Senate" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish Senate">Polish Senate</a>, 26 May 2014
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Saudi Arabia is almost unique in giving the <a href="/wiki/Ulama" title="Ulama">ulema</a> (the body of Islamic religious leaders and jurists) a direct role in government.<sup id="cite_ref-Goldstein118_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Goldstein118-181">[177]</a></sup> The preferred ulema are of the <a href="/wiki/Salafi_movement" title="Salafi movement">Salafi</a> persuasion. The ulema have also been a key influence in major government decisions, for example the imposition of the <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">oil embargo in 1973</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">invitation to foreign troops to Saudi Arabia in 1990</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-meforum.org_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-meforum.org-182">[178]</a></sup> In addition, they have had a major role in the judicial and education systems<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[179]</a></sup> and a monopoly of authority in the sphere of religious and social morals.<sup id="cite_ref-Hassner_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hassner-184">[180]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By the 1970s, as a result of oil wealth and the modernization of the country initiated by King Faisal, important changes to Saudi society were under way and the power of the ulema was in decline.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[181]</a></sup> However, this changed following the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Mosque_Seizure" class="mw-redirect" title="Grand Mosque Seizure">seizure of the Grand Mosque</a> in Mecca in 1979 by <a href="/wiki/Islamist" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamist">Islamist</a> radicals.<sup id="cite_ref-Abir21_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abir21-186">[182]</a></sup> The government's response to the crisis included strengthening the ulema's powers and increasing their financial support:<sup id="cite_ref-Hegghammer24_119-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hegghammer24-119">[115]</a></sup> in particular, they were given greater control over the education system<sup id="cite_ref-Abir21_186-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abir21-186">[182]</a></sup> and allowed to enforce stricter observance of Wahhabi rules of moral and social behaviour.<sup id="cite_ref-Hegghammer24_119-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hegghammer24-119">[115]</a></sup> After his accession to the throne in 2005, King Abdullah took steps to reduce the powers of the ulema, for instance transferring control over girls' education to the Ministry of Education.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_Abdullah_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_Abdullah-187">[183]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The ulema have historically been led by the <a href="/wiki/Al_ash-Sheikh" title="Al ash-Sheikh">Al ash-Sheikh</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[184]</a></sup> the country's leading religious family.<sup id="cite_ref-Hassner_184-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hassner-184">[180]</a></sup> The Al ash-Sheikh are the descendants of <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_ibn_Abd_al-Wahhab" title="Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab">Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab</a>, the 18th-century founder of the Wahhabi form of <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a> which is today dominant in Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[185]</a></sup> The family is second in prestige only to the Al Saud (the royal family)<sup id="cite_ref-Long11_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long11-190">[186]</a></sup> with whom they formed a "mutual support pact"<sup id="cite_ref-IBP_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IBP-191">[187]</a></sup> and power-sharing arrangement nearly 300 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-meforum.org_182-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-meforum.org-182">[178]</a></sup> The pact, which persists to this day,<sup id="cite_ref-IBP_191-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IBP-191">[187]</a></sup> is based on the Al Saud maintaining the Al ash-Sheikh's authority in religious matters and upholding and propagating Wahhabi doctrine. In return, the Al ash-Sheikh support the Al Saud's political authority<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[188]</a></sup> thereby using its religious-<a href="/wiki/Moral_authority" title="Moral authority">moral authority</a> to legitimize the royal family's rule.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[189]</a></sup> Although the Al ash-Sheikh's domination of the ulema has diminished in recent decades,<sup id="cite_ref-Mattar_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mattar-194">[190]</a></sup> they still hold the most important religious posts and are closely linked to the Al Saud by a high degree of intermarriage.<sup id="cite_ref-Hassner_184-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hassner-184">[180]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_system">Legal system</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Legal_system_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Legal system of Saudi Arabia">Legal system of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Capital punishment in Saudi Arabia">Capital punishment in Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Public_executions_in_Saudi_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Public executions in Saudi Arabia">Public executions in Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Iqra.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Iqra.jpg/220px-Iqra.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Iqra.jpg/330px-Iqra.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Iqra.jpg/440px-Iqra.jpg 2x" data-file-width="550" data-file-height="416"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Iqra.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Verses from the Quran. The Quran is the official constitution of the country and a primary source of law. Saudi Arabia is unique in enshrining a religious text as a political document.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[191]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The primary source of law is the Islamic <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a> derived from the teachings of the <a href="/wiki/Qur%27an" class="mw-redirect" title="Qur'an">Qur'an</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sunnah" title="Sunnah">Sunnah</a> (the traditions of the Prophet).<sup id="cite_ref-Campbell_151-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Campbell-151">[147]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia is unique among modern Muslim states in that Sharia is not <a href="/wiki/Codification_(law)" title="Codification (law)">codified</a> and there is no system of <a href="/wiki/Judicial_precedent" class="mw-redirect" title="Judicial precedent">judicial precedent</a>, giving judges the power to use independent legal reasoning to make a decision. Saudi judges tend to follow the principles of the <a href="/wiki/Hanbali" title="Hanbali">Hanbali</a> school of jurisprudence (or <i><a href="/wiki/Fiqh" title="Fiqh">fiqh</a></i>) found in pre-modern texts<sup id="cite_ref-Haffner58_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haffner58-196">[192]</a></sup> and noted for its literalist interpretation of the Qur'an and <a href="/wiki/Hadith" title="Hadith">hadith</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[193]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Because the judge is empowered to disregard previous judgments (either his own or of other judges) and may apply his personal interpretation of Sharia to any particular case, divergent judgements arise even in apparently identical cases,<sup id="cite_ref-Sharia_Inc_Courts_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sharia_Inc_Courts-198">[194]</a></sup> making predictability of legal interpretation difficult.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[195]</a></sup> The Sharia court system constitutes the basic judiciary of Saudi Arabia and its judges (<a href="/wiki/Qadi" title="Qadi">qadi</a>) and lawyers form part of the <a href="/wiki/Ulema" class="mw-redirect" title="Ulema">ulema</a>, the country's Islamic scholars.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Royal decrees are the other main source of law; but are referred to as <i>regulations</i> rather than <i>laws</i> because they are subordinate to the Sharia.<sup id="cite_ref-Campbell_151-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Campbell-151">[147]</a></sup> Royal decrees supplement Sharia in areas such as labour, commercial and corporate law. Additionally, traditional tribal law and <a href="/wiki/Custom_(law)" class="mw-redirect" title="Custom (law)">custom</a> remain significant.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[196]</a></sup> Extra-Sharia government tribunals usually handle disputes relating to specific royal decrees.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[197]</a></sup> Final appeal from both Sharia courts and government tribunals is to the King and all courts and tribunals follow Sharia rules of evidence and procedure.<sup id="cite_ref-Campbell268_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Campbell268-202">[198]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Saudi system of justice has been criticized for its "ultra-puritanical judges", who are often harsh in their sentencing (with beheading for the crime of witchcraft), but also sometimes overly lenient (for cases of rape or wife-beating) and slow, for example leaving thousands of abandoned women unable to secure a divorce.<sup id="cite_ref-econ-2007_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-econ-2007-203">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Economist_Cruel_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist_Cruel-204">[200]</a></sup> The system has also been criticized for being arcane,<sup id="cite_ref-Economist_Tentative_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist_Tentative-205">[201]</a></sup> lacking in some of the safeguards of justice, and unable to deal with the modern world.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[202]</a></sup> In 2007, King Abdullah issued royal decrees reforming the judiciary and creating a new court system,<sup id="cite_ref-Sharia_Inc_Courts_198-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sharia_Inc_Courts-198">[194]</a></sup> and, in 2009, the King made a number of significant changes to the judiciary's personnel at the most senior level by bringing in a younger generation.<sup id="cite_ref-Economist_Tentative_205-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist_Tentative-205">[201]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dira_Square.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Dira_Square.JPG/220px-Dira_Square.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Dira_Square.JPG/330px-Dira_Square.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Dira_Square.JPG/440px-Dira_Square.JPG 2x" data-file-width="691" data-file-height="461"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dira_Square.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Deera_Square" title="Deera Square">Deera Square</a>, central Riyadh. Known locally as "Chop-chop square", it is the location of public beheadings.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[203]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment" title="Capital punishment">Capital</a> and <a href="/wiki/Corporal_punishment" title="Corporal punishment">physical</a> punishments imposed by Saudi courts, such as <a href="/wiki/Decapitation" title="Decapitation">beheading</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stoning" title="Stoning">stoning</a> (to death), <a href="/wiki/Amputation" title="Amputation">amputation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion" title="Crucifixion">crucifixion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Flagellation" title="Flagellation">lashing</a>, as well as the sheer number of executions have been strongly criticized.<sup id="cite_ref-Sharia_Inc175_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sharia_Inc175-208">[204]</a></sup> The death penalty can be imposed for a wide range of offences including murder, rape, <a href="/wiki/Armed_robbery" class="mw-redirect" title="Armed robbery">armed robbery</a>, repeated drug use, <a href="/wiki/Apostasy" title="Apostasy">apostasy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adultery" title="Adultery">adultery</a>, <a href="/wiki/Witchcraft" title="Witchcraft">witchcraft</a> and <a href="/wiki/Magic_(paranormal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Magic (paranormal)">sorcery</a> and can be carried out by beheading with a sword, stoning or firing squad, followed by crucifixion.<sup id="cite_ref-FRD306_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FRD306-209">[205]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[206]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lu_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lu-211">[207]</a></sup> The 345 reported executions between 2007 and 2010 were all carried out by public beheading. The last reported execution for sorcery took place in September 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[208]</a></sup> Studies have shown that Saudi Arabia has one of the lowest crime rates in the world although there are differing views as to whether this is attributable to the legal system or other factors such as social structures.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[209]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Although repeated theft can be punishable by amputation of the right hand, only one instance of judicial amputation was reported between 2007 and 2010. Homosexual acts are punishable by flogging or death.<sup id="cite_ref-FRD306_209-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FRD306-209">[205]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lu_211-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lu-211">[207]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[210]</a></sup> In April 2020, Saudi Supreme Court issued a directive to eliminate the punishment of flogging from the Saudi court system, and it is to be replaced by imprisonment or fines.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[211]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[212]</a></sup> Atheism or "calling into question the fundamentals of the Islamic religion on which this country is based" is considered a terrorist crime.<sup id="cite_ref-i1_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-i1-217">[213]</a></sup> Lashings are a common form of punishment<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[214]</a></sup> and are often imposed for offences against religion and public morality such as drinking alcohol and neglect of prayer and fasting obligations.<sup id="cite_ref-FRD306_209-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FRD306-209">[205]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Retaliatory punishments, or <a href="/wiki/Qisas" title="Qisas">Qisas</a>, are practised: for instance, an eye can be surgically removed at the insistence of a victim who lost his own eye.<sup id="cite_ref-Economist_Cruel_204-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist_Cruel-204">[200]</a></sup> Families of someone unlawfully killed can choose between demanding the death penalty or granting clemency in return for a payment of <a href="/wiki/Diyya" class="mw-redirect" title="Diyya">diyya</a> (blood money), by the perpetrator.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[215]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Foreign relations of Saudi Arabia">Foreign relations of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi,_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia,_Melania_Trump,_and_Donald_Trump,_May_2017.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi%2C_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia%2C_Melania_Trump%2C_and_Donald_Trump%2C_May_2017.jpg/220px-Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi%2C_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia%2C_Melania_Trump%2C_and_Donald_Trump%2C_May_2017.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi%2C_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia%2C_Melania_Trump%2C_and_Donald_Trump%2C_May_2017.jpg/330px-Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi%2C_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia%2C_Melania_Trump%2C_and_Donald_Trump%2C_May_2017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi%2C_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia%2C_Melania_Trump%2C_and_Donald_Trump%2C_May_2017.jpg/440px-Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi%2C_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia%2C_Melania_Trump%2C_and_Donald_Trump%2C_May_2017.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi,_King_Salman_of_Saudi_Arabia,_Melania_Trump,_and_Donald_Trump,_May_2017.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> and First Lady <a href="/wiki/Melania_Trump" title="Melania Trump">Melania Trump</a> with King <a href="/wiki/Salman_bin_Abdulaziz_Al_Saud" class="mw-redirect" title="Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud">Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud</a> and the President of Egypt, <a href="/wiki/Abdel_Fattah_Al_Sisi" class="mw-redirect" title="Abdel Fattah Al Sisi">Abdel Fattah Al Sisi</a>, 21 May 2017
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Saudi Arabia joined the UN in 1945<sup id="cite_ref-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia_53-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia-53">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[216]</a></sup> and is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cooperation_Council_for_the_Arab_States_of_the_Gulf" class="mw-redirect" title="Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf">Gulf Cooperation Council</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muslim_World_League" title="Muslim World League">Muslim World League</a>, and the Organization of the Islamic Conference (now the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Saudi_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Saudi_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs-221">[217]</a></sup> It plays a prominent role in the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_World_Bank" class="mw-redirect" title="The World Bank">the World Bank</a>, and in 2005 joined the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia_53-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia-53">[49]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia supports the intended formation of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Customs_Union" title="Arab Customs Union">Arab Customs Union</a> in 2015 and an Arab <a href="/wiki/Single_market" title="Single market">common market</a><sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[218]</a></sup> by 2020, as announced at the 2009 Arab League summit.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[219]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since 1960, as a founding member of <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a>, its oil pricing policy has been generally to stabilize the world oil market and try to moderate sharp price movements so as to not jeopardise the Western economies.<sup id="cite_ref-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia_53-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-US_State_Dept_Saudi_Arabia-53">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[220]</a></sup> In 1973, Saudi Arabia and other <a href="/wiki/OAPEC" class="mw-redirect" title="OAPEC">Arab nations</a> imposed an <a href="/wiki/Oil_embargo" title="Oil embargo">oil embargo</a> against the United States, United Kingdom, Japan and other Western nations which supported <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War" title="Yom Kippur War">Yom Kippur War</a> of October 1973.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[221]</a></sup> The embargo caused an <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">oil crisis</a> with many short- and long-term effects on global politics and the global economy.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[222]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Between the mid-1970s and 2002 Saudi Arabia expended over $70 billion in "overseas development aid". However, there is evidence that the vast majority was, in fact, spent on propagating and extending the influence of <a href="/wiki/Wahhabism" title="Wahhabism">Wahhabism</a> at the expense of other forms of Islam.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[223]</a></sup> There has been an intense debate over whether Saudi aid and Wahhabism has fomented extremism in recipient countries.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[224]</a></sup> The two main allegations are that, by its nature, Wahhabism encourages intolerance and promotes terrorism.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[225]</a></sup> Counting only the non-Muslim-majority countries, Saudi Arabia has paid for the construction of 1359 mosques, 210 Islamic centres, 202 colleges and 2000 schools.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[226]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg/220px-Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="185" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg/330px-Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg/440px-Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="839"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Obama_meets_King_Abdullah_July_2014.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> meets King <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Abdullah of Saudi Arabia">Abdullah of Saudi Arabia</a>, July 2014
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Saudi Arabia–United States relations">Saudi Arabia and the United States</a> are strategic allies,<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_News_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_News-231">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[228]</a></sup> and since President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> took office in 2009, the US has sold $110 billion in arms to Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[229]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Salon_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salon-234">[230]</a></sup> However, the relationship between Saudi Arabia and the United States became strained and have witnessed major decline during the last years of the <a href="/wiki/Obama_administration" class="mw-redirect" title="Obama administration">Obama administration</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[231]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-act_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-act-236">[232]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-isis_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-isis-237">[233]</a></sup> although Obama had authorized US forces to provide logistical and intelligence support to the Saudis in their <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian-led_intervention_in_Yemen" title="Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen">military intervention in Yemen</a>, establishing a <a href="/wiki/Blockade_of_Yemen#United_States's_role" title="Blockade of Yemen">joint coordination planning cell</a> with the Saudi military that is helping manage the war,<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[234]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[235]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/CIA" class="mw-redirect" title="CIA">CIA</a> used Saudi bases for <a href="/wiki/Disposition_Matrix" title="Disposition Matrix">drone assassinations</a> in Yemen.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[236]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[237]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[238]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[239]</a></sup> In the first decade of the 21st century the Saudi Arabia paid approximately $100 million to <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Agents_Registration_Act" title="Foreign Agents Registration Act">American firms</a> to <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_lobby_in_the_United_States" title="Saudi Arabia lobby in the United States">lobby</a> the U.S. government.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[240]</a></sup> On 20 May 2017, President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> and King Salman signed a series of letters of intent for Saudi Arabia to <a href="/wiki/2017_United_States%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_arms_deal" title="2017 United States–Saudi Arabia arms deal">purchase arms from the United States</a> totaling US$110 billion immediately,<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[241]</a></sup> and $350 billion over 10 years.<sup id="cite_ref-cnbc-20170520_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnbc-20170520-246">[242]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG/220px-A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="171" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG/330px-A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG/440px-A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG 2x" data-file-width="959" data-file-height="746"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:A_view_of_Shah_Faisal_Mosque_from_adjoing_yard..JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Faisal_Mosque" title="Faisal Mosque">Faisal Mosque</a> in <a href="/wiki/Islamabad" title="Islamabad">Islamabad</a> is named after a Saudi king. The kingdom is a strong ally of <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>. <a href="/wiki/WikiLeaks" title="WikiLeaks">WikiLeaks</a> claimed that Saudis are "long accustomed to having a significant role in Pakistan's affairs".<sup id="cite_ref-time.com_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time.com-247">[243]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the Arab and Muslim worlds, Saudi Arabia is considered to be pro-Western and pro-American,<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[244]</a></sup> and it is certainly a long-term ally of the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[245]</a></sup> However, this<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[246]</a></sup> and Saudi Arabia's role in the 1991 <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Persian Gulf War">Persian Gulf War</a>, particularly the stationing of US troops on Saudi soil from 1991, prompted the development of a hostile <a href="/wiki/Islamist" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamist">Islamist</a> response internally.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[247]</a></sup> As a result, Saudi Arabia has, to some extent, distanced itself from the US and, for example, refused to support or to participate in the US-led <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">invasion of Iraq</a> in 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_146-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-146">[142]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_relations" title="China–Saudi Arabia relations">China and Saudi Arabia</a> are major allies, with relationship between the two countries growing significantly in recent decades. Majority of Saudi Arabians also expressed a favorable view of <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[248]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[249]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[250]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[251]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[252]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[253]</a></sup> In February 2019, Crown Prince Mohammad defended China's <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang_re-education_camps" title="Xinjiang re-education camps">Xinjiang re-education camps</a> for <a href="/wiki/Uyghurs" title="Uyghurs">Uyghur</a> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_China" title="Islam in China">Muslims</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[254]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[255]</a></sup> saying "China has the right to carry out anti-terrorism and de-extremisation work for its national security."<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[256]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[257]</a></sup> In July 2019, UN ambassadors of 37 countries, including Saudi Arabia, have signed a joint letter to the <a href="/wiki/UNHRC" class="mw-redirect" title="UNHRC">UNHRC</a> defending China's treatment of Uyghurs and other Muslim minority groups in the <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang" title="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a> region.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[258]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The consequences of the 2003 invasion and the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a> led to increasing alarm within the Saudi monarchy over the rise of <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>'s influence in the region.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[259]</a></sup> These fears were reflected in comments of King Abdullah,<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_Abdullah_187-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_Abdullah-187">[183]</a></sup> who privately urged the United States to attack Iran and "cut off the head of the snake".<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[260]</a></sup> The tentative rapprochement between the US and Iran that began in secret in 2011<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[261]</a></sup> was said to be feared by the Saudis,<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[262]</a></sup> and, during the run up to the widely welcomed deal on Iran's nuclear programme that capped the first stage of US–Iranian détente, Robert Jordan, who was US ambassador to Riyadh from 2001 to 2003, said "[t]he Saudis' worst nightmare would be the [Obama] administration striking a grand bargain with Iran."<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[263]</a></sup> A trip to Saudi by US President Barack Obama in 2014 included discussions of US–Iran relations, though these failed to resolve Riyadh's concerns.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[264]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In order to protect the house of Khalifa, the monarchs of Bahrain, <a href="/wiki/Saudi-led_intervention_in_Bahrain" title="Saudi-led intervention in Bahrain">Saudi Arabia invaded Bahrain</a> by sending military troops to quell the uprising of Bahraini people on 14 March 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-269">[265]</a></sup> The Saudi government considered the two-month uprising as a "security threat" posed by the <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia</a> who represent the majority of Bahrain population.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_269-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-269">[265]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:International_Syria_meeting_(29734397483).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/International_Syria_meeting_%2829734397483%29.jpg/220px-International_Syria_meeting_%2829734397483%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/International_Syria_meeting_%2829734397483%29.jpg/330px-International_Syria_meeting_%2829734397483%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/International_Syria_meeting_%2829734397483%29.jpg/440px-International_Syria_meeting_%2829734397483%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2023"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:International_Syria_meeting_(29734397483).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Foreign Minister <a href="/wiki/Adel_al-Jubeir" title="Adel al-Jubeir">Adel al-Jubeir</a> with then British Foreign Secretary <a href="/wiki/Boris_Johnson" title="Boris Johnson">Boris Johnson</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">Prime Minister</a>) in London, 16 October 2016
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>On 25 March 2015, Saudi Arabia, spearheading a coalition of <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Muslim</a> states,<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[266]</a></sup> started a <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian-led_intervention_in_Yemen" title="Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen">military intervention in Yemen</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia</a> <a href="/wiki/Houthis" class="mw-redirect" title="Houthis">Houthis</a> and forces loyal to former President <a href="/wiki/Ali_Abdullah_Saleh" title="Ali Abdullah Saleh">Ali Abdullah Saleh</a>, who was deposed in the 2011 <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a> uprisings.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[267]</a></sup> At least 56,000 people have been killed in armed violence in Yemen between January 2016 and October 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[268]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Saudi Arabia, together with <a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>, openly supported the <a href="/wiki/Army_of_Conquest" title="Army of Conquest">Army of Conquest</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[269]</a></sup> an umbrella group of anti-government forces fighting in the <a href="/wiki/Syrian_Civil_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Syrian Civil War">Syrian Civil War</a> that reportedly included an <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">al-Qaeda</a> linked <a href="/wiki/Al-Nusra_Front" title="Al-Nusra Front">al-Nusra Front</a> and another <a href="/wiki/Salafi_jihadism" title="Salafi jihadism">Salafi</a> coalition known as <a href="/wiki/Ahrar_al-Sham" title="Ahrar al-Sham">Ahrar al-Sham</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[270]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia was also involved in the CIA-led <a href="/wiki/Timber_Sycamore" title="Timber Sycamore">Timber Sycamore</a> covert operation to train and arm <a href="/wiki/List_of_armed_groups_in_the_Syrian_Civil_War" class="mw-redirect" title="List of armed groups in the Syrian Civil War">Syrian rebels</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[271]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Following a number of <a href="/wiki/Incidents_during_the_Hajj" title="Incidents during the Hajj">incidents during the Hajj</a> season, the deadliest<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[272]</a></sup> of which killed at least 2,070 pilgrim<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[273]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/2015_Mina_stampede" title="2015 Mina stampede">2015 Mina stampede</a>, Saudi Arabia has been accused of mismanagement and focusing on increasing money revenues while neglecting pilgrims' welfare.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[274]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In March 2015, <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a> scrapped an arms deal with Saudi Arabia, marking an end to a decade-old defense agreement with the kingdom. The decision came after Swedish Foreign Minister <a href="/wiki/Margot_Wallstr%C3%B6m" title="Margot Wallström">Margot Wallstrom</a> was blocked by the Saudis while speaking about democracy and women's rights at the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a>. This also led to Saudi Arabia recalling its ambassador to Sweden.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[275]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Saudi Arabia has been seen as a moderating influence in the <a href="/wiki/Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_conflict" title="Arab–Israeli conflict">Arab–Israeli conflict</a>, periodically putting forward a peace plan between Israel and the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Palestinian people">Palestinians</a> and condemning <a href="/wiki/Hezbollah" title="Hezbollah">Hezbollah</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[276]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a> Saudi Arabia offered asylum to deposed President <a href="/wiki/Zine_El_Abidine_Ben_Ali" title="Zine El Abidine Ben Ali">Zine El Abidine Ben Ali</a> of Tunisia and King Abdullah telephoned President <a href="/wiki/Hosni_Mubarak" title="Hosni Mubarak">Hosni Mubarak</a> of Egypt (prior to his deposition) to offer his support.<sup id="cite_ref-guardian.co.uk_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardian.co.uk-281">[277]</a></sup> In early 2014 relations with <a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a> became strained over its support for the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_Brotherhood" title="Muslim Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a>, and Saudi Arabia's belief that Qatar was interfering in its affairs. In August 2014 both countries appeared to be exploring ways of ending the rift.<sup id="cite_ref-QatarSaudi_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-QatarSaudi-282">[278]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia and its allies have criticized Qatar-based TV channel <a href="/wiki/Al_Jazeera" title="Al Jazeera">Al Jazeera</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Qatar_relations" title="Iran–Qatar relations">Qatar's relations with Iran</a>. In 2017, Saudi Arabia imposed a land, naval and air <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_Qatar_diplomatic_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="2017–18 Qatar diplomatic crisis">blockade on Qatar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[279]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png/220px-Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png/330px-Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png/440px-Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="872"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Major <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict" title="Iran–Saudi Arabia proxy conflict">Iran–Saudi Arabia proxy conflict</a> locations
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Saudi Arabia halted new trade and investment dealings with <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_relations" title="Canada–Saudi Arabia relations">suspended diplomatic ties</a> in a dramatic escalation of a dispute over the kingdom's arrest of women's rights activist <a href="/wiki/Samar_Badawi" title="Samar Badawi">Samar Badawi</a> on 6 August 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[280]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[281]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Tensions have escalated between Saudi Arabia and its allies after the disappearance of <a href="/wiki/Jamal_Khashoggi" title="Jamal Khashoggi">Jamal Khashoggi</a> from the Saudi consulate in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>. Turkish officials are highly skeptical of Khashoggi being murdered inside the consulate; this has strained the already suffering <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia%E2%80%93Turkey_relations" title="Saudi Arabia–Turkey relations">Saudi Arabia–Turkey relations</a>. As stated by Ozgur Unluhisarcikli, director of the German Marshall Fund's Ankara office "Turkey is maintaining a very delicate balance in its relations with Saudi Arabia. The relations have the potential of evolving into a crisis at any moment."<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[282]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The pressure on Saudi to reveal the insights about <a href="/wiki/Killing_of_Jamal_Khashoggi" class="mw-redirect" title="Killing of Jamal Khashoggi">Khashoggi's disappearance</a> from the US and other European countries has increased. <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Saudi Arabia–United States relations">Saudi-US relations</a> took an ugly turn on 14 October 2018, when Trump promised "severe punishment" if the royal court was responsible for Khashoggis’ death. The Saudi Foreign Ministry retaliated with an equal statement saying, "it will respond with greater action," indicating the kingdom's "influential and vital role in the global economy." A joint statement was issued by Britain, France and Germany also demanding a "credible investigation to establish the truth about what happened, and — if relevant — to identify those bearing responsibility for the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi, and ensure that they are held to account."<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[283]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The US expects its Gulf allies involved in the coalition in <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a> to put in more efforts and address the rising concerns about the millions that have been pushed to the <a href="/wiki/Famine_in_Yemen_(2016%E2%80%93present)" title="Famine in Yemen (2016–present)">brink of famine</a>. According to the United Nations, the Arabian peninsula nation is home to the world's worst humanitarian crisis.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[284]</a></sup> More than 50,000 children in Yemen died from <a href="/wiki/Starvation" title="Starvation">starvation</a> in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[285]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Famine" title="Famine">famine</a> in Yemen is the direct result of the Saudi-led intervention and <a href="/wiki/Blockade" title="Blockade">blockade</a> of the rebel-held area.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[286]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[287]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the wake of Jamal Khashoggi's murder in October 2018, the US secretary of state <a href="/wiki/Mike_Pompeo" title="Mike Pompeo">Mike Pompeo</a> and the US defence secretary <a href="/wiki/Jim_Mattis" title="Jim Mattis">Jim Mattis</a> called for a ceasefire in Yemen within 30 days followed by UN-initiated peace talks. Pompeo has asked Saudi Arabia and the UAE to stop their airstrikes on populated areas in Yemen. <a href="/wiki/Theresa_May" title="Theresa May">Theresa May</a> backed the US call to end the coalition. President of the <a href="/wiki/International_Rescue_Committee" title="International Rescue Committee">International Rescue Committee</a> <a href="/wiki/David_Miliband" title="David Miliband">David Miliband</a> called the US announcement as "the most significant breakthrough in the war in Yemen for four years".<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[288]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In September 2020, <a href="/wiki/Showtime_(TV_network)" title="Showtime (TV network)">Showtime</a> announced that it will premiere its original documentary, <i>Kingdom of Silence</i>, on 2 October that year. The film was based on the 2018 murder of <a href="/wiki/Jamal_Khashoggi" title="Jamal Khashoggi">Jamal Khashoggi</a> by Saudi authorities. Directed by filmmaker Rick Rowley, the documentary examines the relationship between the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">US</a> and Saudi Arabia, as a backdrop to the murder of Khashoggi, along with the interactions between the Trump administration and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[289]</a></sup> Another documentary by <a href="/wiki/Bryan_Fogel" title="Bryan Fogel">Bryan Fogel</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Dissident" title="The Dissident">The Dissident</a></i>, which excavated a web of deceit behind the murder, was to be released on the same day that marked second death anniversary of Khashoggi.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[290]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Hunt" title="Jeremy Hunt">Jeremy Hunt</a>, the UK Foreign Secretary, on his visit to Saudi Arabia and the UAE on 12 November 2018, is expected to raise the need for a ceasefire from all sides in the four-year long Yemen civil war. The US called for a ceasefire within 30 days.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[291]</a></sup> Andrew Smith, of <a href="/wiki/Campaign_Against_Arms_Trade" title="Campaign Against Arms Trade">Campaign Against Arms Trade</a> (CAAT), said that Hunt and <a href="/wiki/Boris_Johnson" title="Boris Johnson">Boris Johnson</a> "played an utterly central and complicit role in arming and supporting the Saudi-led destruction of Yemen."<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[292]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[293]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2017, as part of its <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear power</a> program, Saudi Arabia planned to extract <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a> domestically, taking a step towards self-sufficiency in producing <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fuel" title="Nuclear fuel">nuclear fuel</a>. On 24 August 2017, the Kingdom signed a memorandum of understanding with <a href="/wiki/China_National_Nuclear_Corporation" title="China National Nuclear Corporation">China National Nuclear Corporation</a> (CNNC) to explore and assess uranium<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[294]</a></sup> On 4 August 2020, a report claimed that Saudi Arabia has constructed a facility in the desert near AlUla for extracting uranium yellowcake from <a href="/wiki/Uranium_ore" title="Uranium ore">uranium ore</a> with the help of <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>. The facility raised concerns among the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">US</a> and allied officials about Saudi nuclear energy plans and the country's option of developing <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">nuclear weapon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[295]</a></sup> On 19 August 2020, Congressional Democrats asked the US secretary of state, <a href="/wiki/Mike_Pompeo" title="Mike Pompeo">Mike Pompeo</a>, to provide information about China's alleged role in building a uranium processing facility in Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[296]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 17 September 2020, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> released an exclusive report revealing that Saudi Arabia was paving the way for domestic production of nuclear fuel. The confidential report obtained by the media house stated that the Kingdom was assisted by Chinese geologists to produce over 90,000 tonnes of <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a> from three major deposits in the centre and northwest of Saudi, near the <a href="/wiki/NEOM" class="mw-redirect" title="NEOM">NEOM</a> megacity development. The disclosure raised concerns regarding Riyadh's aggressive interest in developing atomic weapons program.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[297]</a></sup> Apart from China, the <a href="/wiki/UN" class="mw-redirect" title="UN">UN</a> nuclear watchdog, <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a> (IAEA) was also assisting Saudi's nuclear ambition.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[298]</a></sup> </p> 
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Allegations of sponsoring global terrorism
       </dt>
      </dl> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_and_state-sponsored_terrorism" class="mw-redirect" title="Saudi Arabia and state-sponsored terrorism">Saudi Arabia and state-sponsored terrorism</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Jihad.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Flag_of_Jihad.svg/220px-Flag_of_Jihad.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="110" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Flag_of_Jihad.svg/330px-Flag_of_Jihad.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Flag_of_Jihad.svg/440px-Flag_of_Jihad.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="500"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Jihad.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
