         </div>Flag of <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">Al-Qaeda</a>, a transnational terrorist group formed by <a href="/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden" title="Osama bin Laden">Osama bin Laden</a>, a Saudi Arabian national of Yemeni and Syrian extraction who was stripped of his Saudi passport in 1994.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the Iraqi prime minister <a href="/wiki/Nouri_al-Maliki" title="Nouri al-Maliki">Nouri al-Maliki</a> in March 2014, Saudi Arabia along with Qatar provided political, financial and media support to terrorists against the Iraqi government.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[299]</a></sup> Similarly, President of Syria <a href="/wiki/Bashar_al-Assad" title="Bashar al-Assad">Bashar al-Assad</a> noted that the sources of the extreme ideology of the terrorist organization <a href="/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant" title="Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant">ISIS</a> and other such <a href="/wiki/Salafi_jihadism" title="Salafi jihadism">salafist extremist</a> groups are the <a href="/wiki/Wahabbism" class="mw-redirect" title="Wahabbism">Wahabbism</a> that has been supported by the royal family of Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[300]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The relations with the U.S. became strained following <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">9/11 terror attacks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[301]</a></sup> American politicians and media accused the Saudi government of supporting terrorism and tolerating a <i><a href="/wiki/Jihadist" class="mw-redirect" title="Jihadist">jihadist</a></i> culture.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[302]</a></sup> Indeed, <a href="/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden" title="Osama bin Laden">Osama bin Laden</a> and 15 out of the 19 9/11 hijackers were from Saudi Arabia;<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[303]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant" title="Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant">ISIL</a>-occupied <a href="/wiki/Raqqa" title="Raqqa">Raqqa</a>, in mid-2014, all 12 judges were Saudi.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[304]</a></sup> The leaked US Department of State memo, dated 17 August 2014, says that "governments of Qatar and Saudi Arabia...are providing clandestine financial and logistic support to ISIS and other radical groups in the region."<sup id="cite_ref-isis_237-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-isis-237">[233]</a></sup> According to former US Secretary of State <a href="/wiki/Hillary_Clinton" title="Hillary Clinton">Hillary Clinton</a>, "Saudi Arabia remains a critical financial support base for al-Qaida, the <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a>, <a href="/wiki/LeT" class="mw-redirect" title="LeT">LeT</a> and other terrorist groups... Donors in Saudi Arabia constitute the most significant source of funding to Sunni terrorist groups worldwide."<sup id="cite_ref-Guardian_05122010_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian_05122010-309">[305]</a></sup> Former CIA director <a href="/wiki/James_Woolsey" class="mw-redirect" title="James Woolsey">James Woolsey</a> described it as "the soil in which <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">Al-Qaeda</a> and its sister terrorist organizations are flourishing."<sup id="cite_ref-iags.org_310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iags.org-310">[306]</a></sup> The Saudi government denies these claims or that it exports religious or cultural extremism.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[307]</a></sup> In April 2016, Saudi Arabia has threatened to sell off $750 billion in <a href="/wiki/United_States_Treasury_security" title="United States Treasury security">Treasury securities</a> and other US assets if <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">Congress</a> passes a bill that would allow the Saudi government to be sued over 9/11.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_News_231-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_News-231">[227]</a></sup> In September 2016, the Congress passed the <a href="/wiki/Justice_Against_Sponsors_of_Terrorism_Act" title="Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act">Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act</a> that would allow relatives of victims of the 11 September attacks to sue Saudi Arabia for its government's alleged role in the attacks.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[308]</a></sup> Congress overwhelmingly rejected President <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_presidential_vetoes" title="List of United States presidential vetoes">Barack Obama's veto</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-act_236-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-act-236">[232]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-isis_237-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-isis-237">[233]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to <a href="/wiki/William_Patey" title="William Patey">Sir William Patey</a>, former British ambassador to Saudi Arabia, the kingdom funds mosques throughout Europe that have become hotbeds of extremism. "They are not funding terrorism. They are funding something else, which may down the road lead to individuals being radicalised and becoming fodder for terrorism," Patey said. He said that Saudi has been funding an ideology that leads to extremism and the leaders of the kingdom are not aware of the consequences.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[309]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Armed Forces of Saudi Arabia">Armed Forces of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_(1935).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_%281935%29.jpg/220px-%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_%281935%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_%281935%29.jpg/330px-%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_%281935%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_%281935%29.jpg/440px-%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_%281935%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="493" data-file-height="278"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%22Our_Eagles%22_The_first_Saudi_pilots_training_in_Italy_(1935).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>"The Saudi pilots training in Italy 1935"—a scene from 'Our Eagles', one of four <a href="/wiki/Video_wall" title="Video wall">video wall</a> shows made for the Royal Saudi Air Force Museum
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Saudi Arabia has one of the highest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditure_share_of_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by military expenditure share of GDP">percentages of military expenditure</a> in the world, spending around 8% of its GDP in its military, according to the 2020 <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">SIPRI</a> estimate.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[310]</a></sup> The Saudi military consists of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Saudi_Land_Forces" class="mw-redirect" title="Royal Saudi Land Forces">Royal Saudi Land Forces</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Saudi_Air_Force" title="Royal Saudi Air Force">Royal Saudi Air Force</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Saudi_Navy" title="Royal Saudi Navy">Royal Saudi Navy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Saudi_Air_Defense" title="Royal Saudi Air Defense">Royal Saudi Air Defense</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_National_Guard" title="Saudi Arabian National Guard">Saudi Arabian National Guard</a> (SANG, an independent military force), and paramilitary forces, totaling nearly 200,000 active-duty personnel. In 2005 the armed forces had the following personnel: the army, 75,000; the air force, 18,000; air defense, 16,000; the navy, 15,500 (including 3,000 marines); and the SANG had 75,000 active soldiers and 25,000 tribal levies.<sup id="cite_ref-Library_of_Congress_2006_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Library_of_Congress_2006-315">[311]</a></sup> In addition, there is an <a href="/wiki/Al_Mukhabarat_Al_A%27amah" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Mukhabarat Al A'amah">Al Mukhabarat Al A'amah</a> military intelligence service. </p>
      <p>The kingdom has a long-standing military relationship with <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, it has long been speculated that Saudi Arabia secretly funded Pakistan's <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Pakistan and weapons of mass destruction">atomic bomb programme</a> and seeks to purchase <a href="/wiki/Atomic_weapons" class="mw-redirect" title="Atomic weapons">atomic weapons</a> from Pakistan, in near future.<sup id="cite_ref-QV_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-QV-316">[312]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SPO_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SPO-317">[313]</a></sup> The SANG is not a reserve but a fully operational front-line force, and originated out of Ibn Saud's tribal military-religious force, the <a href="/wiki/Ikhwan" title="Ikhwan">Ikhwan</a>. Its modern existence, however, is attributable to it being effectively <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Abdullah of Saudi Arabia">Abdullah's</a> private army since the 1960s and, unlike the rest of the armed forces, is independent of the Ministry of Defense and Aviation. The SANG has been a counterbalance to the <a href="/wiki/Sudairi" class="mw-redirect" title="Sudairi">Sudairi</a> faction in the royal family: The late prince Sultan, former Minister of Defense and Aviation, was one of the so-called 'Sudairi Seven' and controlled the remainder of the armed forces until his death in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[314]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:11th_MEU_141213-M-CB493-105_(15657874453).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/11th_MEU_141213-M-CB493-105_%2815657874453%29.jpg/220px-11th_MEU_141213-M-CB493-105_%2815657874453%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/11th_MEU_141213-M-CB493-105_%2815657874453%29.jpg/330px-11th_MEU_141213-M-CB493-105_%2815657874453%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/11th_MEU_141213-M-CB493-105_%2815657874453%29.jpg/440px-11th_MEU_141213-M-CB493-105_%2815657874453%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1333"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:11th_MEU_141213-M-CB493-105_(15657874453).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/United_States_Military_Training_Mission" title="United States Military Training Mission">Saudi and US troops train</a> in December 2014
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Spending on defense and security has increased significantly since the mid-1990s and was about US$78.4 billion, as of 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_44-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-44">[40]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia ranks among the top 10 in the world in government spending for its military, representing about 8 percent of gross domestic product in 2019. Its modern high-technology arsenal makes Saudi Arabia among the world's most densely armed nations, with its military equipment being supplied primarily by the US, France and Britain.<sup id="cite_ref-Library_of_Congress_2006_315-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Library_of_Congress_2006-315">[311]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The United States sold more than $80 billion in military hardware between 1951 and 2006 to the Saudi military.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[315]</a></sup> On 20 October 2010, the US <a href="/wiki/State_Department" class="mw-redirect" title="State Department">State Department</a> notified Congress of its intention to make the biggest arms sale in American history—an estimated $60.5 billion purchase by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. The package represents a considerable improvement in the offensive capability of the Saudi armed forces.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[316]</a></sup> 2013 saw Saudi military spending climb to $67bn, overtaking that of the UK, France and Japan to place fourth globally.<sup id="cite_ref-AJE_2013_spending_321-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AJE_2013_spending-321">[317]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The United Kingdom has also been a major supplier of military equipment to Saudi Arabia since 1965.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[318]</a></sup> Since 1985, the UK has supplied military aircraft—notably the <a href="/wiki/Panavia_Tornado" title="Panavia Tornado">Tornado</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eurofighter_Typhoon" title="Eurofighter Typhoon">Eurofighter Typhoon</a> combat aircraft—and other equipment as part of the long-term <a href="/wiki/Al-Yamamah_arms_deal" title="Al-Yamamah arms deal">Al-Yamamah arms deal</a> estimated to have been worth £43 billion by 2006 and thought to be worth a further £40 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[319]</a></sup> In May 2012, British defence giant BAE signed a £1.9bn ($3bn) deal to supply Hawk trainer jets to Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[320]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">Stockholm International Peace Research Institute</a>, SIPRI, in 2010–14 Saudi Arabia became the world's second largest arms importer, receiving four times more major arms than in 2005–2009. Major imports in 2010–14 included 45 combat aircraft from the UK, 38 combat helicopters from the US, four tanker aircraft from <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> and over 600 armoured vehicles from <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a>. Saudi Arabia has a long list of outstanding orders for arms, including 27 more combat aircraft from the UK, 154 combat aircraft from the US and a large number of armoured vehicles from Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-books.sipri.org_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.sipri.org-325">[321]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia received 41 percent of UK arms exports in 2010–14.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[322]</a></sup> France authorized $18 billion in weapons sales to Saudi Arabia in 2015 alone.<sup id="cite_ref-Salon_234-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salon-234">[230]</a></sup> The $15 billion arms deal with Saudi Arabia is believed to be the largest arms sale in Canadian history.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[323]</a></sup> In 2016, the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> decided to temporarily impose an <a href="/wiki/Arms_embargo" title="Arms embargo">arms embargo</a> against Saudi Arabia, as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a> civilian population's suffering from the <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian-led_intervention_in_Yemen" title="Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen">conflict with Saudi Arabia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[324]</a></sup> In 2017, Saudi Arabia signed a <a href="/wiki/2017_United_States-Saudi_Arabia_Arms_Deal" class="mw-redirect" title="2017 United States-Saudi Arabia Arms Deal">110 billion dollar arms deal with the United States</a>. </p>
      <p>Saudi Arabia is Britain's largest arms customer, with more than £4.6 billion worth of arms bought since the start of Saudi-led coalition in Yemen. A recent poll conducted by <a href="/wiki/YouGov" title="YouGov">YouGov</a> for Save the Children and <a href="/wiki/Avaaz" title="Avaaz">Avaaz</a> stated that 63 percent of British people oppose the sale of weapons to Saudi.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[325]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Killing_of_Jamal_Khashoggi" class="mw-redirect" title="Killing of Jamal Khashoggi">killing of Jamal Khashoggi</a>, a nonbinding resolution was passed in the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> on 25 October 2018, urging EU countries to impose an EU-wide arms embargo on Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[326]</a></sup> Germany became the first Western government to suspend future arms deal with the kingdom after <a href="/wiki/Angela_Merkel" title="Angela Merkel">Angela Merkel</a> stated that "arms exports can't take place in the current circumstances."<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[327]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the new report from the <a href="/wiki/Global_Affairs_Canada" title="Global Affairs Canada">Department of Global Affairs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a> sold record-breaking amount of military hardware to Saudi Arabia in 2019, despite its poor <a href="/wiki/Human_rights" title="Human rights">human rights</a> record.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[328]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Human rights in Saudi Arabia">Human rights in Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Raif_Badawi_cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Raif_Badawi_cropped.jpg/170px-Raif_Badawi_cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="182" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Raif_Badawi_cropped.jpg/255px-Raif_Badawi_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Raif_Badawi_cropped.jpg/340px-Raif_Badawi_cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1506" data-file-height="1614"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Raif_Badawi_cropped.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>In 2014, Saudi Arabian writer <a href="/wiki/Raif_Badawi" title="Raif Badawi">Raif Badawi</a> was sentenced to 10 years in prison and 1,000 lashes for "undermining the regime and officials", "inciting public opinion", and "insulting the judiciary"
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Human Rights organizations such as <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a>, <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> condemn both the Saudi criminal justice system and its severe punishments. There are no jury trials in Saudi Arabia and courts observe few formalities.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[329]</a></sup> Human Rights Watch, in a 2008 report, noted that a criminal procedure code had been introduced for the first time in 2002, but it lacked some basic protections and, in any case, had been routinely ignored by judges. Those arrested are often not informed of the crime of which they are accused or given access to a lawyer and are subject to abusive treatment and torture if they do not confess. At trial, there is a presumption of guilt and the accused is often unable to examine witnesses and evidence or present a legal defense. Most trials are held in secret.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[330]</a></sup> An example of sentencing is that of UK pensioner and cancer victim Karl Andree, aged 74, who faced 360 lashes for home brewing alcohol.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[331]</a></sup> He was later released due to intervention by the <a href="/wiki/British_government" class="mw-redirect" title="British government">British government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[332]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Saudi Arabia is widely accused of having one of the worst human rights records in the world. Human rights issues that have attracted strong criticism include the extremely disadvantaged position of women (see <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia#Women" title="Saudi Arabia">Women</a> below), capital punishment for <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="LGBT rights in Saudi Arabia">homosexuality</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[333]</a></sup> religious discrimination, the lack of religious freedom and the activities of the <a href="/wiki/Committee_for_the_Promotion_of_Virtue_and_the_Prevention_of_Vice_(Saudi_Arabia)" title="Committee for the Promotion of Virtue and the Prevention of Vice (Saudi Arabia)">religious police</a> (see <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia#Religion" title="Saudi Arabia">Religion</a> below).<sup id="cite_ref-Sharia_Inc175_208-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sharia_Inc175-208">[204]</a></sup> Between 1996 and 2000, Saudi Arabia acceded to four UN human rights conventions and, in 2004, the government approved the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/National_Society_for_Human_Rights" title="National Society for Human Rights">National Society for Human Rights</a> (NSHR), staffed by government employees, to monitor their implementation. To date, the activities of the NSHR have been limited and doubts remain over its neutrality and independence.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[334]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Saudi Arabia remains one of the very few countries in the world not to accept the UN's <a href="/wiki/Universal_Declaration_of_Human_Rights" title="Universal Declaration of Human Rights">Universal Declaration of Human Rights</a>. In response to the continuing criticism of its human rights record, the Saudi government points to the special Islamic character of the country, and asserts that this justifies a different social and political order.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[335]</a></sup> The United States Commission on International Religious Freedom had unsuccessfully<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[336]</a></sup> urged President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> to raise human rights concerns with King Abdullah on his March 2014 visit to the Kingdom especially the imprisonments of Sultan Hamid Marzooq al-Enezi, Saud Falih Awad al-Enezi, and <a href="/wiki/Raif_Badawi" title="Raif Badawi">Raif Badawi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[337]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Saudi Arabia has a "Counter-Radicalization Program" the purpose of which is to "combat the spread and appeal of <a href="/wiki/Extremist" class="mw-redirect" title="Extremist">extremist</a> ideologies among the general populous (sic)" and to "instill the true values of the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_faith" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamic faith">Islamic faith</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Toleration" title="Toleration">tolerance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Moderation" title="Moderation">moderation</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[338]</a></sup> This "tolerance and moderation" has been called into question by the <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_Sun" class="mw-redirect" title="Baltimore Sun">Baltimore Sun</a>, based on the reports from <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> regarding <a href="/wiki/Raif_Badawi" title="Raif Badawi">Raif Badawi</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[339]</a></sup> and in the case of a man from Hafr al-Batin sentenced to death for rejecting Islam.<sup id="cite_ref-batin_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-batin-344">[340]</a></sup> In September 2015, Faisal bin Hassan Trad, Saudi Arabia's ambassador to the UN in Geneva, has been elected Chair of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Human_Rights_Council" title="United Nations Human Rights Council">United Nations Human Rights Council</a> panel that appoints independent experts.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[341]</a></sup> In January 2016, Saudi Arabia executed the prominent Shia cleric <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Nimr" class="mw-redirect" title="Sheikh Nimr">Sheikh Nimr</a> who had called for pro-democracy demonstrations and for free elections in Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-nimr_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nimr-346">[342]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In August 2017, ten <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a> laureates, including <a href="/wiki/Desmond_Tutu" title="Desmond Tutu">Desmond Tutu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lech_Wa%C5%82%C4%99sa" title="Lech Wałęsa">Lech Wałęsa</a>, urged Saudi Arabia to stop the executions of 14 young people for participating in the <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_Saudi_Arabian_protests" class="mw-redirect" title="2011–12 Saudi Arabian protests">2011–12 Saudi Arabian protests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[343]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 2 October 2018, Saudi journalist and <i><a href="/wiki/Washington_Post" class="mw-redirect" title="Washington Post">Washington Post</a></i> columnist <a href="/wiki/Jamal_Khashoggi" title="Jamal Khashoggi">Jamal Khashoggi</a> went <a href="/wiki/Missing_person" title="Missing person">missing</a> after entering the Saudi consulate in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>. According to Turkish government sources there is audio and video evidence for him having been murdered and <a href="/wiki/Dismember" class="mw-redirect" title="Dismember">dismembered</a> inside the consulate.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[344]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[345]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[346]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In December 2019, Saudi Arabia organized a big-budget electronic dance music festival, MDL Beast to the kingdom, "the region's biggest music event". However, it attracted controversy when many of its high profile attendees, including <a href="/wiki/Armie_Hammer" title="Armie Hammer">Armie Hammer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joan_Smalls" title="Joan Smalls">Joan Smalls</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wilmer_Valderrama" title="Wilmer Valderrama">Wilmer Valderrama</a>, were criticized for engaging in "image rehab" for the kingdom, overlooking the continued <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_abuses" class="mw-redirect" title="Human rights abuses">human rights abuses</a> in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[347]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In April 2020, the Saudi Supreme Court stated under a royal decree by King Salman that minors who commit crimes will no longer face the death sentence, but will be sentenced to a maximum of ten years of imprisonment in a juvenile detention facility.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[348]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> has criticized the UN's decision to remove Saudi Arabia from the “list of shame”. The rights group said that Saudi Arabia is responsible for grave violations and that “the secretary-general has brought shame on the UN by removing the Saudi-led coalition from his ‘list of shame’ even as it continues to kill and injure children in Yemen.”<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[349]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 13 October 2020, Saudi Arabia failed in its attempt to win a place on <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Human_Rights_Council" title="United Nations Human Rights Council">UN human rights council</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a> were elected for the next three years. The result appeared to be a severe blow to the Kingdom's efforts to improve its image in wake of the ordered killing of the Saudi dissident, <a href="/wiki/Jamal_Khashoggi" title="Jamal Khashoggi">Jamal Khashoggi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[350]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Geography of Saudi Arabia">Geography of Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Wildlife of Saudi Arabia">Wildlife of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png/220px-Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="194" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png/330px-Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png/440px-Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png 2x" data-file-width="1432" data-file-height="1266"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_Topography.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Saudi Arabia topography
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg/220px-Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg/330px-Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg/440px-Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3032" data-file-height="2005"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Harrat_Khaybar_Space.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Harrat_Khaybar" title="Harrat Khaybar">Harrat Khaybar</a> seen from the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a>. Saudi Arabia is home to more than 2000 dormant volcanoes.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[351]</a></sup> Lava fields in Hejaz, known locally by their Arabic name of harrat (the singular is harrah), form one of Earth's largest <a href="/wiki/Alkali_basalt" title="Alkali basalt">alkali basalt</a> regions, covering some 180,000 square kilometers (nearly 70,000 sq mi), an area greater than the state of <a href="/wiki/Missouri" title="Missouri">Missouri</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[352]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Saudi Arabia occupies about 80 percent of the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> (the world's largest peninsula),<sup id="cite_ref-Stokes605_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stokes605-357">[353]</a></sup> lying between latitudes <a href="/wiki/16th_parallel_north" title="16th parallel north">16°</a> and <a href="/wiki/33rd_parallel_north" title="33rd parallel north">33° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/34th_meridian_east" title="34th meridian east">34°</a> and <a href="/wiki/56th_meridian_east" title="56th meridian east">56° E</a>. Because the country's southern borders with the <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a> are not precisely marked, the exact size of the country is undefined.<sup id="cite_ref-Stokes605_357-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stokes605-357">[353]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" class="mw-redirect" title="CIA World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a> estimates 2,149,690&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (830,000&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) and lists Saudi Arabia as the world's 13th-largest state.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[354]</a></sup> It is geographically the largest country in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Plate" title="Arabian Plate">Arabian Plate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[355]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_SAU_present.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Koppen-Geiger_Map_SAU_present.svg/220px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_SAU_present.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Koppen-Geiger_Map_SAU_present.svg/330px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_SAU_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Koppen-Geiger_Map_SAU_present.svg/440px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_SAU_present.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1289" data-file-height="850"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_SAU_present.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Saudi Arabia's <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> map<sup id="cite_ref-Peel_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Peel-360">[356]</a></sup> is based on native vegetation, temperature, precipitation and their seasonality. 
         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style>
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#FE0000; color:black;font-size:60%;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Hot_desert_climate" class="mw-redirect" title="Hot desert climate">BWh Hot desert</a>
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#FE9695; color:black;font-size:60%;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Cold_desert_climate" class="mw-redirect" title="Cold desert climate">BWk Cold desert</a>
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#F5A301; color:black;font-size:60%;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Hot_semi-arid_climate" class="mw-redirect" title="Hot semi-arid climate">BSh Hot semi-arid</a>
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#FFDB63; color:black;font-size:60%;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Cold_semi-arid_climate" class="mw-redirect" title="Cold semi-arid climate">BSk Cold semi-arid</a>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Saudi Arabia's diverse geography is dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Desert" title="Arabian Desert">Arabian Desert</a>, associated semi-desert, shrubland, steppes, several mountain ranges, volcanic lava fields and highlands. The 647,500&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (250,001&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) <a href="/wiki/Rub%27_al_Khali" title="Rub' al Khali">Rub' al Khali</a> ("Empty Quarter") in the southeastern part of the country is the world's largest contiguous sand desert.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_146-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-146">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[357]</a></sup> Though there are lakes in the country, Saudi Arabia is the largest country in the world by area with no permanent rivers. <a href="/wiki/Wadis" class="mw-redirect" title="Wadis">Wadis</a>, non-permanent rivers, however, are very numerous. The fertile areas are to be found in the alluvial deposits in wadis, basins, and oases.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_146-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-146">[142]</a></sup> The main topographical feature is the central plateau which rises abruptly from the Red Sea and gradually descends into the <a href="/wiki/Nejd" class="mw-redirect" title="Nejd">Nejd</a> and toward the Persian Gulf. On the Red Sea coast, there is a narrow coastal plain, known as the <a href="/wiki/Tihamah" title="Tihamah">Tihamah</a> parallel to which runs an imposing escarpment. The southwest province of <a href="/wiki/%27Asir_Province" title="'Asir Province">Asir</a> is mountainous, and contains the 3,133&nbsp;m (10,279&nbsp;ft) <a href="/wiki/Jabal_Sawda" title="Jabal Sawda">Mount Sawda</a>, which is the highest point in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_146-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-146">[142]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Except for the southwestern regions such as <a href="/wiki/%27Asir_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="'Asir Region">Asir</a>, Saudi Arabia has a <a href="/wiki/Desert_climate" title="Desert climate">desert climate</a> with very high day-time temperatures during the summer and a sharp temperature drop at night. Average summer temperatures are around 45&nbsp;°C (113&nbsp;°F), but can be as high as 54&nbsp;°C (129&nbsp;°F) at its most extreme. In the winter the temperature rarely drops below 0&nbsp;°C (32&nbsp;°F) with the exception of mostly the northern regions of the country where annual snowfall, in particular in the mountainous regions of <a href="/wiki/Tabuk_province" class="mw-redirect" title="Tabuk province">Tabuk province</a>, is not uncommon.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[358]</a></sup> The lowest recorded temperature to date, −12.0&nbsp;°C (10.4&nbsp;°F), was measured in <a href="/wiki/Turaif" class="mw-redirect" title="Turaif">Turaif</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SaudiCC_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SaudiCC-363">[359]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the spring and autumn the heat is temperate, temperatures average around 29&nbsp;°C (84&nbsp;°F). Annual rainfall is very low. The Southern regions differ in that they are influenced by the Indian Ocean <a href="/wiki/Monsoons" class="mw-redirect" title="Monsoons">monsoons</a>, usually occurring between October and March. An average of 300&nbsp;mm (12&nbsp;in) of rainfall occurs during this period, which is about 60 percent of the annual precipitation.<sup id="cite_ref-weather_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-weather-364">[360]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia is home to approximately 1300 islands.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[361]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="List of birds of Saudi Arabia">List of birds of Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_mammals_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="List of mammals of Saudi Arabia">List of mammals of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg/200px-Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="160" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg/300px-Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg/400px-Halterstandingshotarabianone.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="800"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Arabian_horse" title="Arabian horse">Arabian horse</a> is native to Arabia, and an important element of traditional Arabian folklore
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_(8454247265).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_%288454247265%29.jpg/200px-Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_%288454247265%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_%288454247265%29.jpg/300px-Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_%288454247265%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_%288454247265%29.jpg/400px-Arabian_Leopard_Nimr_%288454247265%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The highly endangered <a href="/wiki/Arabian_leopard" title="Arabian leopard">Arabian leopard</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Saudi Arabia is home to five terrestrial ecoregions: <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula_coastal_fog_desert" title="Arabian Peninsula coastal fog desert">Arabian Peninsula coastal fog desert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southwestern_Arabian_foothills_savanna" title="Southwestern Arabian foothills savanna">Southwestern Arabian foothills savanna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southwestern_Arabian_montane_woodlands" title="Southwestern Arabian montane woodlands">Southwestern Arabian montane woodlands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Desert" title="Arabian Desert">Arabian Desert</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea_Nubo-Sindian_tropical_desert_and_semi-desert" title="Red Sea Nubo-Sindian tropical desert and semi-desert">Red Sea Nubo-Sindian tropical desert and semi-desert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-366">[362]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Wildlife includes the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_leopard" title="Arabian leopard">Arabian leopard</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Judas_et_al.,_2006_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Judas_et_al.,_2006-367">[363]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Spalton_et_al.,_2006_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spalton_et_al.,_2006-368">[364]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arabian_wolf" title="Arabian wolf">wolf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Striped_hyena" title="Striped hyena">striped hyena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongoose" title="Mongoose">mongoose</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baboon" title="Baboon">baboon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cape_hare" title="Cape hare">hare</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sand_cat" title="Sand cat">sand cat</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jerboa" title="Jerboa">jerboa</a>. Animals such as gazelles, <a href="/wiki/Oryx" title="Oryx">oryx</a>, leopards and <a href="/wiki/Asiatic_cheetah" title="Asiatic cheetah">cheetahs</a><sup id="cite_ref-Nowell1996_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nowell1996-369">[365]</a></sup> were relatively numerous until the 19th century, when extensive hunting reduced these animals almost to extinction. Birds include falcons (which are caught and trained for hunting), eagles, hawks, vultures, <a href="/wiki/Sandgrouse" title="Sandgrouse">sandgrouse</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bulbul" title="Bulbul">bulbuls</a>. There are several species of snakes, many of which are venomous. Saudi Arabia is home to a rich marine life. The Red Sea in particular is a rich and diverse <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystem</a>. More than <a href="/wiki/Fish_of_the_Red_Sea" class="mw-redirect" title="Fish of the Red Sea">1200 species of fish</a><sup id="cite_ref-fishbase_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fishbase-370">[366]</a></sup> have been recorded in the Red Sea, and around 10 percent of these are found nowhere else.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[367]</a></sup> This also includes 42 species of <a href="/wiki/List_of_deep_water_fish_of_the_Red_Sea" title="List of deep water fish of the Red Sea">deepwater fish</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-fishbase_370-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fishbase-370">[366]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The rich diversity is in part due to the 2,000&nbsp;km (1,240&nbsp;mi) of <a href="/wiki/Coral_reef" title="Coral reef">coral reef</a> extending along its <a href="/wiki/Coastline" class="mw-redirect" title="Coastline">coastline</a>; these <a href="/wiki/Fringing_reef" title="Fringing reef">fringing reefs</a> are 5000–7000 years old and are largely formed of stony <a href="/wiki/Acropora" title="Acropora">acropora</a> and <a href="/wiki/Porites" title="Porites">porites</a> corals. The reefs form platforms and sometimes <a href="/wiki/Lagoon" title="Lagoon">lagoons</a> along the coast and occasional other features such as cylinders (such as the <a href="/wiki/Blue_Hole_(Red_Sea)" title="Blue Hole (Red Sea)">Blue Hole (Red Sea)</a> at <a href="/wiki/Dahab" title="Dahab">Dahab</a>). These coastal reefs are also visited by <a href="/wiki/Pelagic" class="mw-redirect" title="Pelagic">pelagic</a> species of Red Sea fish, including some of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_sharks_in_the_Red_Sea" title="List of sharks in the Red Sea">44 species of shark</a>. The Red Sea also contains many offshore reefs including several true atolls. Many of the unusual offshore reef formations defy classic (i.e., Darwinian) coral reef classification schemes, and are generally attributed to the high levels of tectonic activity that characterize the area. Domesticated animals include the legendary <a href="/wiki/Arabian_horse" title="Arabian horse">Arabian horse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabian_camel" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabian camel">Arabian camel</a>, sheep, goats, cows, donkeys, chickens etc. Reflecting the country's dominant desert conditions, Saudi Arabia's plant life mostly consists of herbs, plants and shrubs that require little water. The <a href="/wiki/Date_(fruit)" class="mw-redirect" title="Date (fruit)">date</a> palm (<i>Phoenix dactylifera</i>) is widespread.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_146-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-146">[142]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Saudi_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Regions of Saudi Arabia">Regions of Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Governorates_of_Saudi_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Governorates of Saudi Arabia">Governorates of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Saudi Arabia is divided into 13 <a href="/wiki/Regions" class="mw-redirect" title="Regions">regions</a><sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[368]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">مناطق إدارية</span>‎; <i>manatiq idāriyya</i>, sing. منطقة إدارية; <i><a href="/wiki/Mintaqah" title="Mintaqah">mintaqah</a> idariyya</i>). The regions are further divided into 118 <a href="/wiki/Governorates_of_Saudi_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Governorates of Saudi Arabia">governorates</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">محافظات</span>‎; <i>muhafazat</i>, sing. محافظة; <i><a href="/wiki/Muhafazah" title="Muhafazah">muhafazah</a></i>). This number includes the 13 regional capitals, which have a different status as municipalities (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">أمانة</span>‎; <i>amanah</i>) headed by mayors (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">أمين</span>‎; <i>amin</i>). The governorates are further subdivided into sub-governorates (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">مراكز</span>‎; <i><a href="/wiki/Markaz_(country_subdivision)" class="mw-redirect" title="Markaz (country subdivision)">marakiz</a></i>, sing. مركز; <i>markaz</i>). </p> 
      <div role="img" class="noresize" style="width: 400px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;">
       <a href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg/400px-Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg.png" decoding="async" width="400" height="333" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg/600px-Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg/800px-Saudi_Arabia_location_map.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1802" data-file-height="1501"></a> 
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:30px; top:84px">

       </div>

        <a href="/wiki/Northern_Borders_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern Borders Region">Northern<br>Borders</a>

      <p> The 13 regions of Saudi Arabia. </p>
