        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">9</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Khobar" title="Khobar">Khobar</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Eastern_Province,_Saudi_Arabia" title="Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia">Ash-Sharqiyyah</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-Eastern_Region_374-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eastern_Region-374">[370]</a></sup>626,200</td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">19</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Yanbu" title="Yanbu">Yanbu</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Al_Madinah_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Madinah Region">Al Madinah</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-Al-Madinah_Al-Monawarah_378-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Al-Madinah_Al-Monawarah-378">[374]</a></sup>320,800 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">10</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Tabuk,_Saudi_Arabia" title="Tabuk, Saudi Arabia">Tabuk</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Tabuk_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Tabuk Region">Tabuk</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-Tabouk_382-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tabouk-382">[378]</a></sup>609,000</td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">20</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Al_Qunfudhah" title="Al Qunfudhah">Al Qunfudhah</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Makkah_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Makkah Region">Makkah</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-Makkah_Al-Mokarramah_375-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Makkah_Al-Mokarramah-375">[371]</a></sup>304,400 </td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Economy of Saudi Arabia">Economy of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg/220px-KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg/330px-KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg/440px-KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="2666"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:KAFD_seen_from_North_east_side_of_Riyadh_City.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>King Abdullah Financial Center is one of the largest investment centers in the Middle East, located in Riyadh
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As of October 2018, Saudi Arabia is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">largest</a> economy in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a> and the 18th largest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_12-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-12">[10]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves" title="List of countries by proven oil reserves">second-largest proven petroleum reserves</a> and the country is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_oil_exports" title="List of countries by oil exports">largest exporter of petroleum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1995_383-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1995-383">[379]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[380]</a></sup> It also has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_proven_reserves" title="List of countries by natural gas proven reserves">fifth-largest proven natural gas reserves</a>. Saudi Arabia is considered an "<a href="/wiki/Energy_superpower" title="Energy superpower">energy superpower</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-undp_385-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-undp-385">[381]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[382]</a></sup> It has the third highest total estimated value of <a href="/wiki/Natural_resources" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural resources">natural resources</a>, valued at US$34.4 trillion in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[383]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia's <a href="/wiki/Command_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="Command economy">command economy</a> is petroleum-based; roughly 63%<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[384]</a></sup> of budget revenues and 67%<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[385]</a></sup> of export earnings come from the oil industry. It is strongly dependent on foreign workers with about 80% of those employed in the private sector being non-Saudi.<sup id="cite_ref-coy-employ_390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-coy-employ-390">[386]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-McDowall_391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McDowall-391">[387]</a></sup> Challenges to the Saudi economy include halting or reversing the decline in per-capita income, improving education to prepare youth for the workforce and providing them with employment, diversifying the economy, stimulating the private sector and housing construction, and diminishing corruption and inequality.<sup id="cite_ref-HT2009:_150_392-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HT2009:_150-392">[388]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The oil industry constitutes about 45% of Saudi Arabia's nominal gross domestic product, compared with 40% from the private sector (see below). Saudi Arabia officially has about 260 billion barrels (4.1<span style="margin:0 .15em 0 .25em">×</span>10<sup>10</sup>&nbsp;m<sup>3</sup>) of <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Oil reserves in Saudi Arabia">oil reserves</a>, comprising about one-fifth of the world's proven total petroleum reserves.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[389]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th style="text-align:center; background:#cfb;" colspan="2">Share of world GDP (PPP)<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_12-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-12">[10]</a></sup> </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th style="background:#cfb;">Year </th> 
         <th style="background:#cfb;">Share </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">1980</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">2.73% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">1990</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">1.64% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>2000 </td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">1.42% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>2010 </td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">1.36% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">2017</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">1.40% </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>In the 1990s, Saudi Arabia experienced a significant contraction of oil revenues combined with a high rate of population growth. Per capita income fell from a high of $11,700 at the height of the oil boom in 1981 to $6,300 in 1998.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[390]</a></sup> Taking into account the impact of the real oil price changes on the Kingdom's real gross domestic income, the real command-basis GDP was computed to be 330.381 billion 1999 USD in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[391]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/World_oil_market_chronology_from_2003" title="World oil market chronology from 2003">Increases in oil prices in the early 2000s</a> helped boost per capita GDP to $17,000 in 2007 dollars (about $7,400 adjusted for inflation),<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[392]</a></sup> but have declined since oil price drop in mid-2014.<sup id="cite_ref-wti_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wti-397">[393]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:AramcoCoreArea.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/AramcoCoreArea.jpg/220px-AramcoCoreArea.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/AramcoCoreArea.jpg/330px-AramcoCoreArea.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/AramcoCoreArea.jpg/440px-AramcoCoreArea.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="427"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:AramcoCoreArea.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Office of <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Aramco" title="Saudi Aramco">Saudi Aramco</a>, the world's most valuable company and the main source of revenue for the state
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a> (the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries) limits its members' oil production based on their "proven reserves." Saudi Arabia's published reserves have shown little change since 1980, with the main exception being an increase of about 100 billion barrels (1.6<span style="margin:0 .15em 0 .25em">×</span>10<sup>10</sup>&nbsp;m<sup>3</sup>) between 1987 and 1988.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[394]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Matthew_Simmons" title="Matthew Simmons">Matthew Simmons</a> has suggested that Saudi Arabia is greatly exaggerating its reserves and may soon show production declines (see <a href="/wiki/Peak_oil" title="Peak oil">peak oil</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[395]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>From 2003 to 2013, "several key services" were privatized—municipal water supply, electricity, telecommunications—and parts of education and health care, traffic control and car accident reporting were also privatized. According to Arab News columnist Abdel Aziz Aluwaisheg, "in almost every one of these areas, consumers have raised serious concerns about the performance of these privatized entities."<sup id="cite_ref-Aluwaisheg_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Aluwaisheg-400">[396]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tadawul" title="Tadawul">Tadawul</a> All Share Index (TASI) of the Saudi stock exchange peaked at 16,712.64 in 2005, and closed at 8,535.60, at the end of 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-MV2013_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MV2013-401">[397]</a></sup> In November 2005, Saudi Arabia was approved as a member of the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>. Negotiations to join had focused on the degree to which Saudi Arabia is willing to increase market access to foreign goods and in 2000, the government established the <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_General_Investment_Authority" title="Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority">Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority</a> to encourage foreign direct investment in the kingdom. Saudi Arabia maintains a list of sectors in which foreign investment is prohibited, but the government plans to open some closed sectors such as telecommunications, insurance, and power transmission/distribution over time. </p>
      <p>The government has also made an attempt at "<a href="/wiki/Saudization" title="Saudization">Saudizing</a>" the economy, replacing foreign workers with Saudi nationals with limited success.<sup id="cite_ref-house-161_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-house-161-402">[398]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:What_did_Saudi_Arabia_export_in_2017.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/What_did_Saudi_Arabia_export_in_2017.png/220px-What_did_Saudi_Arabia_export_in_2017.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="100" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/What_did_Saudi_Arabia_export_in_2017.png/330px-What_did_Saudi_Arabia_export_in_2017.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/What_did_Saudi_Arabia_export_in_2017.png/440px-What_did_Saudi_Arabia_export_in_2017.png 2x" data-file-width="4860" data-file-height="2220"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:What_did_Saudi_Arabia_export_in_2017.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Graphical depiction of Saudi Arabia's product exports in 2017
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Saudi Arabia has had five-year "Development Plans" since 1970. Among its plans were to launch "economic cities" (e.g. <a href="/wiki/King_Abdullah_Economic_City" title="King Abdullah Economic City">King Abdullah Economic City</a>) to be completed by 2020, in an effort to diversify the economy and provide jobs. As of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> four cities were planned.<sup id="cite_ref-MCC_403-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MCC-403">[399]</a></sup> The King has announced that the per capita income is forecast to rise from $15,000 in 2006 to $33,500 in 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[400]</a></sup> The cities will be spread around Saudi Arabia to promote diversification for each region and their economy, and the cities are projected to contribute $150 billion to the GDP. </p>
      <p>In addition to petroleum and gas, Saudi also has a significant gold mining sector in the ancient <a href="/wiki/Mahd_adh_Dhahab" title="Mahd adh Dhahab">Mahd adh Dhahab</a> region and significant other mineral industries, an agricultural sector (especially in the southwest but not only) based on vegetables, fruits, dates etc. and livestock, and large number of temporary jobs created by the roughly two million annual <i><a href="/wiki/Hajj" title="Hajj">hajj</a></i> pilgrims.<sup id="cite_ref-HT2009:_150_392-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HT2009:_150-392">[388]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Statistics on poverty in the kingdom are not available through the UN resources because the Saudi government does not issue any.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[401]</a></sup> The Saudi state discourages calling attention to or complaining about poverty. In December 2011, the Saudi interior ministry arrested three reporters and held them for almost two weeks for questioning after they uploaded a video on the topic to YouTube.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[402]</a></sup> Authors of the video claim that 22 percent of Saudis may be considered poor (2009).<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[403]</a></sup> Observers researching the issue prefer to stay anonymous<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[404]</a></sup> because of the risk of being arrested. </p>
      <p>In September 2018, the Public Investment Fund completed a deal with a group of global lenders for a loan of $11 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[405]</a></sup> The deal raised more than initially planned and was the first time the PIF had incorporated loans and debt instruments into its funding.<sup id="cite_ref-blooms_410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-blooms-410">[406]</a></sup> According to data from Fitch Ratings, over two years starting from May 2016 Saudi Arabia went from having zero debt to raising $68 billion in dollar-denominated bonds and syndicated loans—one of the fastest rates among emerging economies.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[407]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Each year, about a quarter-million young Saudis enter the job market. With the first phase of <a href="/wiki/Saudization" title="Saudization">Saudization</a> into effect, 70% of sales job are expected to be filled by Saudis. However, the private sector still remains hugely dominated by foreigners. The rate of local unemployment is 12.9%, its highest in more than a decade.<sup id="cite_ref-blooms_410-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-blooms-410">[406]</a></sup> According to a report published by Bloomberg Economics in 2018, the government needs to produce 700,000 jobs by 2020 to meet its 9% unemployment target.<sup id="cite_ref-blooms_410-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-blooms-410">[406]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Agriculture in Saudi Arabia">Agriculture in Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa,_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9,_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8,_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa%2C_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9%2C_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8%2C_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG/220px-Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa%2C_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9%2C_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8%2C_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa%2C_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9%2C_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8%2C_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG/330px-Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa%2C_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9%2C_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8%2C_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa%2C_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9%2C_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8%2C_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG/440px-Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa%2C_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9%2C_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8%2C_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Jabal_Al_Qara_Cave_-_Al_Hassa,_Saudi_Arabia_%E0%B4%9C%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%96%E0%B4%BE%E0%B4%B1_%E0%B4%97%E0%B5%81%E0%B4%B9,_%E0%B4%85%E0%B5%BD_%E0%B4%B9%E0%B4%B8,_%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%97%E0%B4%A6%E0%B4%BF_%E0%B4%85%E0%B4%B1%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%AC%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF_13.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Al-Ahsa_Oasis" title="Al-Ahsa Oasis">Al-Hasa</a> is known for its palm trees and dates. Al-Hasa has over 30 million palm trees which produce over 100 thousand tons of dates every year.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Serious large-scale agricultural development began in the 1970s. The government launched an extensive program to promote modern farming technology; to establish rural roads, irrigation networks and storage and export facilities; and to encourage agricultural research and training institutions. As a result, there has been a phenomenal growth in the production of all basic foods. Saudi Arabia is now completely self-sufficient in a number of foodstuffs, including meat, milk and eggs. The country exports wheat, dates, dairy products, eggs, fish, poultry, fruits, vegetables and flowers to markets around the world. Dates, once a staple of the Saudi diet, are now mainly grown for global humanitarian aid. In addition, Saudi farmers grow substantial amounts of other grains such as barley, sorghum and millet. As of 2016, in the interest of preserving precious water resources, domestic production of wheat has ended.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[408]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Kingdom likewise has some of the most modern and largest dairy farms in the Middle East. Milk production boasts a remarkably productive annual rate of 1,800 gallons per cow, one of the highest in the world. The local dairy manufacturing company <a href="/wiki/Almarai" title="Almarai">Almarai</a> is the largest vertically integrated dairy company in the Middle East.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[409]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Kingdom's most dramatic agricultural accomplishment, noted worldwide, was its rapid transformation from importer to exporter of wheat. In 1978, the country built its first grain silos. By 1984, it had become self-sufficient in wheat. Shortly thereafter, Saudi Arabia began exporting wheat to some 30 countries, including China and the former Soviet Union, and in the major producing areas of Tabuk, Hail and Qasim, average yields reached 8.1 tonnes per hectare (3.6&nbsp;short ton/acre). The Kingdom has, however, stepped up fruit and vegetable production, by improving both agricultural techniques and the roads that link farmers with urban consumers. Saudi Arabia is a major exporter of fruits and vegetables to its neighbors. Among its most productive crops are watermelon, grapes, citrus fruits, onions, squash and tomatoes. At Jizan in the country's well-watered southwest, the Al-Hikmah Research Station is producing tropical fruits including pineapples, paw-paws, bananas, mangoes and guavas.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[410]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Olive" title="Olive">olive</a> tree is indigenous to Saudi Arabia. In 2018 the Al Jouf Agricultural Development Company received a certificate of merit from <a href="/wiki/The_Guinness_World_Records" class="mw-redirect" title="The Guinness World Records">The Guinness World Records</a> for the largest modern olive plantation in the world. The farm covers 7730 hectares and has 5 million olive trees. The Guinness World Records also took into consideration their production capacity of 15000 tonnes of high quality of olive oil, while the kingdom consumes double that. The Al Jouf farms are located in <a href="/wiki/Sakaka" class="mw-redirect" title="Sakaka">Sakaka</a>, a city in the north-western part of Saudi Arabia, which is a deeply-rooted in history. Sakaka dates back more than 4,000 years.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[411]</a></sup> The Al Jouf region has millions of olive trees and the expected number is expected to go up to 20 million trees soon.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[412]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Consuming non-renewable groundwater resulted in the loss of an estimated four fifths of the total groundwater reserves by 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[413]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Water supply and sanitation in Saudi Arabia">Water supply and sanitation in Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Irrigation_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Irrigation in Saudi Arabia">Irrigation in Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Water supply and sanitation in Saudi Arabia is characterized by significant investments in <a href="/wiki/Water_desalination" class="mw-redirect" title="Water desalination">seawater desalination</a>, water distribution, sewerage and wastewater treatment leading to a substantial increase in access to drinking water and sanitation over the past decades. About 50% of drinking water comes from desalination, 40% from the mining of non-renewable groundwater and 10% from surface water, especially in the mountainous southwest of the country. The capital <a href="/wiki/Riyadh" title="Riyadh">Riyadh</a>, located in the heart of the country, is supplied with desalinated water pumped from the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a> over a distance of 467&nbsp;km. Given the substantial <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Economy of Saudi Arabia">oil wealth</a>, water is provided almost for free. Despite improvements service quality remains poor. For example, in Riyadh water was available only once every 2.5 days in 2011, while in Jeddah it is available only every 9 days.<sup id="cite_ref-GWI_April_2011_418-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GWI_April_2011-418">[414]</a></sup> Institutional capacity and <a href="/wiki/Governance" title="Governance">governance</a> in the sector are weak, reflecting general characteristics of the public sector in Saudi Arabia. Since 2000, the government has increasingly relied on the private sector to operate water and sanitation infrastructure, beginning with desalination and wastewater treatment plants. Since 2008, the operation of urban water distribution systems is being gradually delegated to private companies as well.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Tourism in Saudi Arabia">Tourism in Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Although most tourism in Saudi Arabia still largely involves religious pilgrimages, there is growth in the leisure tourism sector. According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, approximately 14.3 million people visited Saudi Arabia in 2012, making it the world's 19th-most-visited country.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[415]</a></sup> Tourism is an important component of the <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Vision_2030" title="Saudi Vision 2030">Saudi Vision 2030</a> and according to a report conducted by BMI Research in 2018, both religious and non-religious tourism have significant potential for expansion.<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[416]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Starting December 2018, the kingdom will offer an electronic visa for foreign visitors to attend sport events and concerts. The "sharek" visa process will start with 15 December, Saudia Ad Diriyah E Prix race.<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[417]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In September 2019, the Kingdom announced its plans to open visa applications for visitors, where people from about 50 countries would be able to get tourist visas to Saudi.<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[418]</a></sup> </p> 
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Saudi Arabian people">Saudi Arabian people</a> and <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Demographics of Saudi Arabia">Demographics of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png/220px-Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="204" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png/330px-Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png/440px-Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png 2x" data-file-width="1001" data-file-height="930"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Saudi_Arabia_population_density_2010.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Saudi Arabia population density (people per km<sup>2</sup>)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#cfb;">Population<sup id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_423-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-423">[419]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_2019_424-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP_2019-424">[420]</a></sup> </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th style="background:#cfb;">Year </th> 
         <th style="background:#cfb;">Million </th>
        </tr>

         <td style="text-align:left;">1970</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">5.8 </td>
        </tr>

         <td style="text-align:right;">20.8 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">2018</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">33.7 </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Saudi_Arabien_2016.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Saudi_Arabien_2016.png/220px-Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Saudi_Arabien_2016.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Saudi_Arabien_2016.png/330px-Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Saudi_Arabien_2016.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Saudi_Arabien_2016.png/440px-Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Saudi_Arabien_2016.png 2x" data-file-width="610" data-file-height="425"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Saudi_Arabien_2016.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Population pyramid 2016
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The population of Saudi Arabia as of July 2013 is estimated to be 26.9 million, including between 5.5 million<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook-4">[3]</a></sup> and 10 million non-nationalized <a href="/wiki/Immigrants" class="mw-redirect" title="Immigrants">immigrants</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-McDowall_391-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McDowall-391">[387]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[421]</a></sup> though the Saudi population has long proved difficult to accurately estimate due to Saudi leaders' historical tendency to inflate census results.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[422]</a></sup> Saudi population has grown rapidly since 1950 when it was estimated to be 3 million,<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[423]</a></sup> and for many years had one of the highest birthrates in the world at around 3 percent a year.<sup id="cite_ref-long-27_428-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-long-27-428">[424]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The ethnic composition of Saudi citizens is 90% <a href="/wiki/Arab" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab">Arab</a> and 10% <a href="/wiki/Afro-Asian" class="mw-redirect" title="Afro-Asian">Afro-Asian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[425]</a></sup> Most Saudis live in the Hejaz (35%), Najd (28%), and the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Province,_Saudi_Arabia" title="Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia">Eastern Province</a> (15%).<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[426]</a></sup> Hejaz is the most populated region in Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[427]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As late as 1970, most Saudis lived a subsistence life in the rural provinces, but in the last half of the 20th century the kingdom has urbanized rapidly. As of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> about 80% of Saudis live in urban metropolitan areas—specifically <a href="/wiki/Riyadh" title="Riyadh">Riyadh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jeddah" title="Jeddah">Jeddah</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Dammam" title="Dammam">Dammam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">[428]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[429]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Its population is also quite young with over half the population under 25 years old.<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[430]</a></sup> A large fraction are foreign nationals. (The CIA Factbook estimated that as of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> foreign nationals living in Saudi Arabia made up about 21% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_4-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook-4">[3]</a></sup> Other estimates are 30%<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[431]</a></sup> or 33%<sup id="cite_ref-alriyadh.com_436-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alriyadh.com-436">[432]</a></sup>) </p>
      <p>As recently as the early 1960s, Saudi Arabia's slave population was estimated at 300,000.<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[433]</a></sup> Slavery was officially abolished in 1962.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_438-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-438">[434]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_439-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-439">[435]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3> 
      <p>The official language of Saudi Arabia is <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>. The three main regional variants spoken by Saudis are <a href="/wiki/Najdi_Arabic" title="Najdi Arabic">Najdi Arabic</a> (about 14.6 million speakers<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[436]</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Hejazi_Arabic" title="Hejazi Arabic">Hejazi Arabic</a> (about 10.3 million speakers<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">[437]</a></sup>), and <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Arabic" title="Gulf Arabic">Gulf Arabic</a> (about 0.96 million speakers<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[438]</a></sup>). <a href="/wiki/Faifi_language" title="Faifi language">Faifi</a> is spoken by about 50,000. <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Sign_Language" title="Saudi Sign Language">Saudi Sign Language</a> is the principal language of the deaf community, amounting to around 100,000 speakers. The large expatriate communities also speak their own languages, the most numerous of which, according to 2018 data, are <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_language" title="Tagalog language">Tagalog</a> (~900,000), <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Punjabi_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Punjabi language">Eastern Punjabi</a> (~800,000), <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a> (~740,000), <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Arabic" title="Egyptian Arabic">Egyptian Arabic</a> (~600,000), <a href="/wiki/Rohingya_language" title="Rohingya language">Rohingya</a>, and <a href="/wiki/North_Levantine_Arabic" title="North Levantine Arabic">North Levantine Arabic</a> (both ~500,000).<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[439]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religions">Religions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Religion in Saudi Arabia">Religion in Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Masjid_al-Quba.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Masjid_al-Quba.jpg/220px-Masjid_al-Quba.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Masjid_al-Quba.jpg/330px-Masjid_al-Quba.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Masjid_al-Quba.jpg/440px-Masjid_al-Quba.jpg 2x" data-file-width="810" data-file-height="589"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Masjid_al-Quba.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Quba_Mosque" title="Quba Mosque">Quba Mosque</a> in <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a>, the Hejaz. This is considered to be the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_oldest_mosques" title="List of the oldest mosques">first mosque</a> that dates to the lifetime of the <a href="/wiki/Prophets_and_messengers_in_Islam" title="Prophets and messengers in Islam">Islamic Prophet</a> <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445">[e]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Virtually all Saudi citizens are Muslim<sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">[441]</a></sup> (officially, all are), and almost all Saudi residents are Muslim.<sup id="cite_ref-PewForump.17_447-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PewForump.17-447">[442]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[443]</a></sup> Estimates of the <a href="/wiki/Sunni" class="mw-redirect" title="Sunni">Sunni</a> population of Saudi Arabia range between 75% and 90%, with the remaining 10–25% being <a href="/wiki/Shia" class="mw-redirect" title="Shia">Shia</a> Muslim.<sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449">[444]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PF2009_450-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PF2009-450">[445]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bbc-shia_451-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-shia-451">[446]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cfr-shiite_452-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cfr-shiite-452">[447]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Nasr2006_p._236_453-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nasr2006_p._236-453">[448]</a></sup> The official and dominant form of Sunni Islam in Saudi Arabia is commonly known as <a href="/wiki/Wahhabism" title="Wahhabism">Wahhabism</a><sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454">[449]</a></sup> (proponents prefer the name <a href="/wiki/Salafism" class="mw-redirect" title="Salafism">Salafism</a>, considering <i>Wahhabi</i> derogatory<sup id="cite_ref-The_Daily_Star_455-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Daily_Star-455">[450]</a></sup>), which was founded in the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> by <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_ibn_Abd_al-Wahhab" title="Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab">Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab</a> in the 18th century. Other denominations, such as the minority <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia Islam</a>, are systematically suppressed.<sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456">[451]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to estimates there are about 1,500,000 <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Christianity in Saudi Arabia">Christians</a> in Saudi Arabia, almost all foreign workers.<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[452]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia allows Christians to enter the country as foreign workers for <a href="/wiki/Temporary_work" title="Temporary work">temporary work</a>, but does not allow them to practice their faith openly. The percentage of Saudi Arabian citizens who are Christians is officially zero,<sup id="cite_ref-458" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-458">[453]</a></sup> as Saudi Arabia forbids <a href="/wiki/Religious_conversion" title="Religious conversion">religious conversion</a> from Islam (<a href="/wiki/Apostasy" title="Apostasy">apostasy</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Capital punishment in Saudi Arabia">punishes it by death</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459">[454]</a></sup> According to Pew Research Center there are 390,000 <a href="/wiki/Hindus" title="Hindus">Hindus</a> in Saudi Arabia, almost all foreign workers.<sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460">[455]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There may be a significant fraction of <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheists</a> and <a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">agnostics</a> in Saudi Arabia,<sup id="cite_ref-Gallup_461-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gallup-461">[456]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462">[457]</a></sup> although they are officially called "terrorists".<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[458]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In its 2017 religious freedom report, the US State Department named Saudi Arabia a Country of Particular Concern (CPC).<sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464">[459]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreigners">Foreigners</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_workers_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Foreign workers in Saudi Arabia">Foreign workers in Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Migrant_workers_in_the_Gulf_region" class="mw-redirect" title="Migrant workers in the Gulf region">Migrant workers in the Gulf region</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kafala_system" title="Kafala system">Kafala system</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Foreign_worker" title="Foreign worker">Foreign worker</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Saudi Arabia's Central Department of Statistics &amp; Information estimated the foreign population at the end of 2014 at 33% (10.1 million).<sup id="cite_ref-CDSI_465-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CDSI-465">[460]</a></sup> The CIA Factbook estimated that as of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> foreign nationals living in Saudi Arabia made up about 21% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_4-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook-4">[3]</a></sup> Other sources report differing estimates.<sup id="cite_ref-alriyadh.com_436-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alriyadh.com-436">[432]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Non-resident_Indian_and_person_of_Indian_origin" title="Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin">Indian</a>: 1.5 million, <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistani people">Pakistani</a>: 1.3 million,<sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466">[461]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Egyptians" title="Egyptians">Egyptian</a>: 900,000, <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemeni</a>: 800,000, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladeshi</a>: 400,000, <a href="/wiki/Filipinos_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Filipinos in Saudi Arabia">Filipino</a>: 500,000, <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordanian</a>/Palestinian: 260,000, <a href="/wiki/Indonesians_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Indonesians in Saudi Arabia">Indonesian</a>: 250,000, <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lankan</a>: 350,000, <a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudanese</a>: 250,000, <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Syria" title="Demographics of Syria">Syrian</a>: 100,000 and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turkish</a>: 80,000.<sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467">[462]</a></sup> There are around 100,000 <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">Westerners</a> in Saudi Arabia, most of whom live in <a href="/wiki/Compound_(enclosure)" title="Compound (enclosure)">compounds</a> or <a href="/wiki/Gated_community" title="Gated community">gated communities</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Foreign Muslims<sup id="cite_ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468">[463]</a></sup> who have resided in the kingdom for ten years may apply for Saudi citizenship. (Priority is given to holders of degrees in various scientific fields,<sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469">[464]</a></sup> and exception made for <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Palestinian people">Palestinians</a> who are excluded unless married to a Saudi national, because of <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a> instructions barring the Arab states from granting them citizenship.) Saudi Arabia is not a signatory to the <a href="/wiki/Convention_relating_to_the_Status_of_Refugees" class="mw-redirect" title="Convention relating to the Status of Refugees">1951 UN Refugee Convention</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470">[465]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As Saudi population grows and oil export revenues stagnate, pressure for "<a href="/wiki/Saudization" title="Saudization">Saudization</a>" (the replacement of foreign workers with Saudis) has grown, and the Saudi government hopes to decrease the number of foreign nationals in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471">[466]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia expelled 800,000 Yemenis in 1990 and 1991<sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472">[467]</a></sup> and has built a <a href="/wiki/Saudi%E2%80%93Yemen_barrier" title="Saudi–Yemen barrier">Saudi–Yemen barrier</a> against an influx of <a href="/wiki/Illegal_immigrant" class="mw-redirect" title="Illegal immigrant">illegal immigrants</a> and against the smuggling of drugs and weapons.<sup id="cite_ref-473" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-473">[468]</a></sup> In November 2013, Saudi Arabia expelled thousands of illegal Ethiopian residents from the Kingdom. Various Human Rights entities have criticised Saudi Arabia's handling of the issue.<sup id="cite_ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474">[469]</a></sup> Over 500,000 <a href="/wiki/Illegal_immigration_in_Saudi_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Illegal immigration in Saudi Arabia">undocumented migrant workers</a> — mostly from Somalia, Ethiopia, and Yemen — have been detained and deported since 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475">[470]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 13 August 2020, <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> reported dozens of <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">Euthopian</a> migrants who had been forcibly expelled by <a href="/wiki/Houthi_movement" title="Houthi movement">Houthi forces</a>, under the pretext of <a href="/wiki/Coronavirus_disease_2019" title="Coronavirus disease 2019">COVID-19</a> measures, were killed and detained by <a href="/wiki/General_Directorate_of_Border_Guard" title="General Directorate of Border Guard">Saudi border guards</a>. The migrants were captured by Saudi guards when they tried to escape from the border area.<sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476">[471]</a></sup> An investigation led by <a href="/wiki/The_Sunday_Telegraph" title="The Sunday Telegraph">The Sunday Telegraph</a>, exposed the condition of African migrants who were detained in Saudi Arabia allegedly for containing <a href="/wiki/Coronavirus_disease_2019" title="Coronavirus disease 2019">Covid-19</a> in the kingdom. They were beaten, tortured and electrocuted. Many of the migrants died due to heatstroke or by attempting suicide, after being severely beaten and tortured. The migrants lack proper living condition, provision of food and water.<sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477">[472]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Culture of Saudi Arabia">Culture of Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca,_Saudi_Arabia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca%2C_Saudi_Arabia.jpg/220px-Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca%2C_Saudi_Arabia.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca%2C_Saudi_Arabia.jpg/330px-Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca%2C_Saudi_Arabia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca%2C_Saudi_Arabia.jpg/440px-Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca%2C_Saudi_Arabia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Supplicating_Pilgrim_at_Masjid_Al_Haram._Mecca,_Saudi_Arabia.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Supplicating <a href="/wiki/Pilgrimage#Islam" title="Pilgrimage">pilgrim</a> at <i><a href="/wiki/Great_Mosque_of_Mecca" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Mosque of Mecca">Al-Masjid Al-Ḥarām</a></i> (The Sacred Mosque) in <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Kaaba" title="Kaaba">Kaaba</a> is the cubic building in front of the pilgrim.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Saudi Arabia has centuries-old attitudes and traditions, often derived from Arab civilization. The main factors that influence the culture of Saudi Arabia are Islamic heritage and Bedouin traditions as well as its historical role as an ancient trade center.<sup id="cite_ref-478" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-478">[473]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion_in_society">Religion in society</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Religion in Saudi Arabia">Religion in Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Islam in Saudi Arabia">Islam in Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Freedom of religion in Saudi Arabia">Freedom of religion in Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wahhabism" title="Wahhabism">Wahhabism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Salafism" class="mw-redirect" title="Salafism">Salafism</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The Hejazi region, where the <a href="/wiki/Holiest_sites_in_Islam" title="Holiest sites in Islam">Islamic holy cities</a> of Mecca and Medina are located, is the destination of the <a href="/wiki/Hajj" title="Hajj">Ḥajj</a> pilgrimage, and often deemed to be the cradle of Islam.<sup id="cite_ref-Arabia:_the_Cradle_of_Islam_479-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arabia:_the_Cradle_of_Islam-479">[474]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-490" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-490">[f]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Islam is the state religion of Saudi Arabia and its law <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Saudi_Arabia#Policy_of_exclusion" title="Religion in Saudi Arabia">requires</a> that all citizens be Muslims.<sup id="cite_ref-depstate_491-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-depstate-491">[485]</a></sup> Neither Saudi citizens nor guest workers have the right of <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-depstate_491-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-depstate-491">[485]</a></sup> The official and dominant form of Islam in the kingdom—<a href="/wiki/Wahhabism" title="Wahhabism">Wahhabism</a>—arose in the central region of Najd, in the 18th century. Proponents call the movement "<a href="/wiki/Salafism" class="mw-redirect" title="Salafism">Salafism</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-The_Daily_Star_455-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Daily_Star-455">[450]</a></sup> and believe that its teachings purify the practice of Islam of innovations or practices that deviate from the seventh-century teachings of Muhammad and <a href="/wiki/Sahaba" class="mw-redirect" title="Sahaba">his companions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-492" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-492">[486]</a></sup> The Saudi government has often been viewed as an active oppressor of <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia Muslims</a> because of the funding of the Wahhabi ideology which denounces the Shia faith.<sup id="cite_ref-493" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-493">[487]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-syedjaffar_494-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-syedjaffar-494">[488]</a></sup> Prince <a href="/wiki/Bandar_bin_Sultan" class="mw-redirect" title="Bandar bin Sultan">Bandar bin Sultan</a>, Saudi ambassador to the United States, stated: "The time is not far off in the Middle East when it will be literally 'God help the Shia'. More than a billion Sunnis have simply had enough of them."<sup id="cite_ref-495" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-495">[489]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Saudi Arabia is one of the few countries that have "<a href="/wiki/Committee_for_the_Promotion_of_Virtue_and_the_Prevention_of_Vice_(Saudi_Arabia)" title="Committee for the Promotion of Virtue and the Prevention of Vice (Saudi Arabia)">religious police</a>" (known as <i>Haia</i> or <i>Mutaween</i>), who patrol the streets "<a href="/wiki/Enjoining_good_and_forbidding_wrong" title="Enjoining good and forbidding wrong">enjoining good and forbidding wrong</a>" by enforcing <a href="/wiki/Clothing_laws_by_country" title="Clothing laws by country">dress codes</a>, strict <a href="/wiki/Sex_segregation" title="Sex segregation">separation of men and women</a>, attendance at prayer (<i><a href="/wiki/Salat" class="mw-redirect" title="Salat">salat</a></i>) five times each day, the ban on alcohol, and other aspects of <i><a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a></i> (Islamic law). In the privacy of the home behavior can be far looser, and reports from <a href="/wiki/WikiLeaks" title="WikiLeaks">WikiLeaks</a> indicate that the ruling Saudi Royal family applies a different moral code to itself, indulging in parties, drugs and sex.<sup id="cite_ref-496" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-496">[490]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Until 2016, the kingdom used the lunar <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Islamic calendar</a>, not the international <a href="/wiki/Gregorian_calendar" title="Gregorian calendar">Gregorian calendar</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-497" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-497">[491]</a></sup> but in 2016 the kingdom announced its switch to the Gregorian calendar for civil purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-498" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-498">[492]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-499" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-499">[493]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Daily life is dominated by Islamic observance. Businesses are closed three or four times a day<sup id="cite_ref-500" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-500">[494]</a></sup> for 30 to 45 minutes during business hours while employees and customers are sent off to <a href="/wiki/Salat" class="mw-redirect" title="Salat">pray</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-HT2009:_214_501-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HT2009:_214-501">[495]</a></sup> The weekend is Friday-Saturday, not Saturday-Sunday, because Friday is the holiest day for Muslims.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_146-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-146">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-502" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-502">[496]</a></sup> For many years only two religious holidays were publicly recognized – <i><a href="/wiki/%CA%BF%C4%AAd_al-Fi%E1%B9%ADr" class="mw-redirect" title="ʿĪd al-Fiṭr">ʿĪd al-Fiṭr</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/%CA%BF%C4%AAd_al-A%E1%B8%8D%E1%B8%A5%C4%81" class="mw-redirect" title="ʿĪd al-Aḍḥā">ʿĪd al-Aḍḥā</a></i>. (<i>ʿĪd al-Fiṭr</i> is "the biggest" holiday, a three-day period of "feasting, gift-giving and general letting go".<sup id="cite_ref-HT2009:35_503-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HT2009:35-503">[497]</a></sup>) </p>
      <p>As of 2004<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, approximately half of the broadcast airtime of Saudi <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Saudi_Arabia#State-run_channels" title="Television in Saudi Arabia">state television</a> was devoted to religious issues.<sup id="cite_ref-nyrob-relig-educ_504-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyrob-relig-educ-504">[498]</a></sup> 90 percent of books published in the kingdom were on religious subjects, and most of the doctorates awarded by its universities were in Islamic studies.<sup id="cite_ref-nyrob-relig-books_505-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyrob-relig-books-505">[499]</a></sup> In the state school system, about half of the material taught is religious. In contrast, assigned readings over 12 years of primary and secondary schooling devoted to covering the history, literature, and cultures of the non-Muslim world comes to a total of about 40 pages.<sup id="cite_ref-nyrob-relig-educ_504-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyrob-relig-educ-504">[498]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Not_for_us_(3975139168).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Not_for_us_%283975139168%29.jpg/220px-Not_for_us_%283975139168%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Not_for_us_%283975139168%29.jpg/330px-Not_for_us_%283975139168%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Not_for_us_%283975139168%29.jpg/440px-Not_for_us_%283975139168%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Not_for_us_(3975139168).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Non-Muslims are prohibited from entering the Islamic holy city of Mecca
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>"Fierce religious resistance" had to be overcome to permit such innovations as paper money (in 1951), female education (1964), and television (1965) and the abolition of slavery (1962).<sup id="cite_ref-506" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-506">[500]</a></sup> Public support for the traditional political/religious structure of the kingdom is so strong that one researcher interviewing Saudis found virtually no support for reforms to secularize the state.<sup id="cite_ref-507" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-507">[501]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Because of religious restrictions, Saudi culture lacks any diversity of religious expression, buildings, annual festivals and public events.<sup id="cite_ref-IRFR_508-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IRFR-508">[502]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-irf2013_509-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-irf2013-509">[503]</a></sup> Celebration of other (non-Wahhabi) Islamic holidays, such as the <a href="/wiki/Mawlid" title="Mawlid">Muhammad's birthday</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Day_of_Ashura" class="mw-redirect" title="Day of Ashura">Day of Ashura</a>, (an important holiday for the 10–25 percent of the population<sup id="cite_ref-PF2009_450-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PF2009-450">[445]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bbc-shia_451-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-shia-451">[446]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cfr-shiite_452-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cfr-shiite-452">[447]</a></sup> that is <a href="/wiki/Shia" class="mw-redirect" title="Shia">Shīʿa</a> Muslim), are tolerated only when celebrated locally and on a small scale.<sup id="cite_ref-statsKSA_510-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-statsKSA-510">[504]</a></sup> Shia also face systematic discrimination in employment, education, the justice system according to <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-511" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-511">[505]</a></sup> Non-Muslim festivals like Christmas and Easter are not tolerated at all,<sup id="cite_ref-Times_512-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Times-512">[506]</a></sup> although there are nearly a million Christians as well as <a href="/wiki/Hindu" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindu">Hindus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhist" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhist">Buddhists</a> among the foreign workers.<sup id="cite_ref-irf2010_513-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-irf2010-513">[507]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Times_512-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Times-512">[506]</a></sup> No churches, temples or other non-Muslim houses of worship are permitted in the country. <a href="/wiki/Proselytizing" class="mw-redirect" title="Proselytizing">Proselytizing</a> by non-Muslims and <a href="/wiki/Apostasy_in_Islam" title="Apostasy in Islam">conversion by Muslims to another religion</a> is illegal,<sup id="cite_ref-irf2010_513-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-irf2010-513">[507]</a></sup> and as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the distribution of "publications that have prejudice to any other religious belief other than Islam" (such as <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bibles</a>), was reportedly punishable by death.<sup id="cite_ref-514" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-514">[508]</a></sup> In legal <a href="/wiki/Diyya#Saudi_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Diyya">compensation</a> court cases (<i><a href="/wiki/Diyya" class="mw-redirect" title="Diyya">Diyya</a></i>) non-Muslim are awarded less than Muslims.<sup id="cite_ref-Times_512-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Times-512">[506]</a></sup> Atheists are legally designated as terrorists.<sup id="cite_ref-515" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-515">[509]</a></sup> And at least one religious minority, the <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya" title="Ahmadiyya">Ahmadiyya</a> Muslims, had its adherents deported,<sup id="cite_ref-516" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-516">[510]</a></sup> as they are legally banned from entering the country.<sup id="cite_ref-517" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-517">[511]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Islamic_heritage_sites">Islamic heritage sites</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Destruction_of_early_Islamic_heritage_sites_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Destruction of early Islamic heritage sites in Saudi Arabia">Destruction of early Islamic heritage sites in Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Tourism in Saudi Arabia">Tourism in Saudi Arabia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Heritage_Preservation_Society" title="Saudi Heritage Preservation Society">Saudi Heritage Preservation Society</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:MasjidNabawi.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/MasjidNabawi.jpg/220px-MasjidNabawi.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/MasjidNabawi.jpg/330px-MasjidNabawi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/MasjidNabawi.jpg/440px-MasjidNabawi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4320" data-file-height="3240"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:MasjidNabawi.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Mosque_of_the_Prophet" class="mw-redirect" title="Mosque of the Prophet">Mosque of the Prophet</a> in <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a> containing the tomb of <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Saudi <a href="/wiki/Wahhabism" title="Wahhabism">Wahhabism</a> is hostile to any reverence given to historical or religious places of significance for fear that it may give rise to <a href="/wiki/Shirk_(Islam)" title="Shirk (Islam)">'shirk'</a> (idolatry), and the most significant historic Muslim sites (in Mecca and Medina) are located in the western Saudi region of the Hejaz.<sup id="cite_ref-Arabia:_the_Cradle_of_Islam_479-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arabia:_the_Cradle_of_Islam-479">[474]</a></sup> As a consequence, under Saudi rule, an estimated 95% of Mecca's historic buildings, most over a thousand years old, <a href="/wiki/Destruction_of_early_Islamic_heritage_sites_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Destruction of early Islamic heritage sites in Saudi Arabia">have been demolished</a> for religious reasons.<sup id="cite_ref-518" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-518">[512]</a></sup> Critics claim that over the last 50 years, 300 historic sites linked to Muhammad, his family or companions have been lost,<sup id="cite_ref-519" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-519">[513]</a></sup> leaving fewer than 20 structures remaining in Mecca that date back to the time of Muhammad.<sup id="cite_ref-independent.co.uk_520-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-independent.co.uk-520">[514]</a></sup> Demolished structures include the mosque originally built by Muhammad's daughter <a href="/wiki/Fatima_bint_Muhammad" class="mw-redirect" title="Fatima bint Muhammad">Fatima</a>, and other mosques founded by <a href="/wiki/Abu_Bakr" title="Abu Bakr">Abu Bakr</a> (Muhammad's father-in-law and the first <a href="/wiki/Caliph" class="mw-redirect" title="Caliph">Caliph</a>), <a href="/wiki/Umar_ibn_al-Khattab" class="mw-redirect" title="Umar ibn al-Khattab">Umar</a> (the second Caliph), <a href="/wiki/Ali_ibn_Abi_Talib" class="mw-redirect" title="Ali ibn Abi Talib">Ali</a> (Muhammad's son-in-law and the fourth Caliph), and <a href="/wiki/Salman_al-Farsi" class="mw-redirect" title="Salman al-Farsi">Salman al-Farsi</a> (another of Muhammad's companions).<sup id="cite_ref-521" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-521">[515]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Five cultural sites in Saudi Arabia are designated as <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage Sites">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>: Al-Hijr Archaeological Site (<a href="/wiki/Mada%27in_Saleh" class="mw-redirect" title="Mada'in Saleh">Madâin Sâlih</a>);<sup id="cite_ref-522" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-522">[516]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Turaif_district" class="mw-redirect" title="Turaif district">Turaif district</a> in the city of Diriyah;<sup id="cite_ref-523" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-523">[517]</a></sup> Historic <a href="/wiki/Jeddah" title="Jeddah">Jeddah</a>, the Gate to <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-524" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-524">[518]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Al-Ahsa_Oasis" title="Al-Ahsa Oasis">Al-Ahsa Oasis</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-525" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-525">[519]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Rock_Art_in_the_Ha%27il_Region" title="Rock Art in the Ha'il Region">Rock Art in the Hail Region</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-526" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-526">[520]</a></sup> Ten other sites submitted requests for recognition to UNESCO in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-527" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-527">[521]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are six elements inscribed on <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">UNESCO's Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity list</a>:<sup id="cite_ref-528" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-528">[522]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Al-Qatt_Al-Asiri" title="Al-Qatt Al-Asiri">Al-Qatt Al-Asiri</a>, female traditional interior wall decoration in <a href="/wiki/%27Asir_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="'Asir Region">Asir</a>; <a href="/wiki/Almezmar_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Almezmar in Saudi Arabia">Almezmar</a>, drumming and dancing with sticks; Falconry, a living human heritage; <a href="/wiki/Arabic_coffee" title="Arabic coffee">Arabic coffee</a>, a symbol of generosity; <a href="/wiki/Majlis" title="Majlis">Majlis</a>, a cultural and social space; Alardah Alnajdiyah, dance, drumming and poetry in Saudi Arabia. </p>
      <p>In June 2014, the Council of Ministers approved a law that gives the <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Commission_for_Tourism_and_National_Heritage" class="mw-redirect" title="Saudi Commission for Tourism and National Heritage">Saudi Commission for Tourism and National Heritage</a> the means to protect Saudi Arabia's ancient relics and historic sites. Within the framework of the 2016 National Transformation Program, also known as <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Vision_2030" title="Saudi Vision 2030">Saudi Vision 2030</a>, the kingdom allocated 900 million euros to preserve its historical and cultural heritage.<sup id="cite_ref-529" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-529">[523]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia also participates in the International Alliance for the Protection of Heritage in Conflict Areas (ALIPH), created in March 2017, with a contribution of 18.5 million euros.<sup id="cite_ref-530" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-530">[524]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2017, Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman promised to return Saudi Arabia to the "moderate Islam" of the era before the 1979 Iranian revolution.<sup id="cite_ref-531" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-531">[525]</a></sup> A new center, the King Salman Complex for the Prophet's Hadith, was established that year to monitor interpretations of the Prophet Mohammed's hadiths to prevent them being used to justify terrorism.<sup id="cite_ref-532" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-532">[526]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In March 2018, the Crown Prince met the Archbishop of Canterbury during a visit to the UK, pledging to promote interfaith dialogue. In Riyadh the following month King Salman met the head of the Vatican's Pontifical Council for Interreligious Dialogue.<sup id="cite_ref-533" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-533">[527]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In July 2019, UNESCO signed a letter with the Saudi Minister of Culture of In which Saudi Arabia contribute US$25 million to UNESCO for the preservation of heritage.<sup id="cite_ref-534" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-534">[528]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dress">Dress</span></h3> 
      <p>Saudi Arabian dress strictly follows the principles of <a href="/wiki/Hijab" title="Hijab">hijab</a> (the Islamic principle of <a href="/wiki/Modesty" title="Modesty">modesty</a>, especially in dress). The predominantly loose and flowing, but covering, garments are suited to Saudi Arabia's <a href="/wiki/Desert" title="Desert">desert</a> climate. Traditionally, men usually wear a white ankle length garment woven from wool or cotton (known as a <a href="/wiki/Thawb" title="Thawb">thawb</a>), with a <a href="/wiki/Keffiyeh" title="Keffiyeh">keffiyeh</a> (a large checkered square of cotton held in place by an <a href="/wiki/Agal" class="mw-redirect" title="Agal">agal</a>) or a <a href="/wiki/Keffiyeh" title="Keffiyeh">ghutra</a> (a plain white square made of finer cotton, also held in place by an <a href="/wiki/Agal" class="mw-redirect" title="Agal">agal</a>) worn on the head. For rare chilly days, Saudi men wear a <a href="/wiki/Camel" title="Camel">camel</a>-hair cloak (<a href="/wiki/Bisht_(clothing)" title="Bisht (clothing)">bisht</a>) over the top. In public women are required to wear a black <a href="/wiki/Abaya" title="Abaya">abaya</a> or other black clothing that covers everything under the neck with the exception of their hands and feet, although most women cover their head in respect for their religion. This requirement applies to non-Muslim women too and failure to abide can result in police action, particularly in more conservative areas of the country. Women's clothes are often decorated with tribal motifs, coins, sequins, metallic thread, and appliques. </p> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Ghutrah" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghutrah">Ghutrah</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">غتره</span>‎) is a traditional <a href="/wiki/Headdress" class="mw-redirect" title="Headdress">headdress</a> typically worn by <a href="/wiki/Arab" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab">Arab</a> men. It is made of a square of cloth ("scarf"), usually cotton, folded and wrapped in various styles around the head. It is commonly worn in areas with an <a href="/wiki/Arid" title="Arid">arid</a> climate, to provide protection from direct <a href="/wiki/Sun_exposure" class="mw-redirect" title="Sun exposure">sun exposure</a>, and also protection of the mouth and eyes from blown dust and <a href="/wiki/Sand" title="Sand">sand</a>.</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Agal" class="mw-redirect" title="Agal">Agal</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">عقال</span>‎) is an item of <a href="/wiki/Arab" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab">Arab</a> headgear constructed of cord which is fastened around the <a href="/wiki/Ghutrah" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghutrah">Ghutrah</a> to hold it in place. The <i>agal</i> is usually black in colour.</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Thawb" title="Thawb">Thawb</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">ثوب</span>‎) is the standard Arabic word for garment. It is ankle-length, usually with long sleeves, similar to a <a href="/wiki/Robe" title="Robe">robe</a>.</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Bisht_(clothing)" title="Bisht (clothing)">Bisht</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">بشت</span>‎) is a traditional Arabic men's <a href="/wiki/Cloak" title="Cloak">cloak</a> usually only worn for prestige on special occasions such as weddings.</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Abaya" title="Abaya">Abaya</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">عبائة</span>‎) is a woman's garment. It is a black cloak which loosely covers the entire body except the head. Some women choose to cover their faces with a niqāb and some do not. Some abayas cover the top of the head as well.<sup id="cite_ref-535" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-535">[529]</a></sup></li>
      </ul> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts_and_entertainment">Arts and entertainment</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_art" title="Saudi Arabian art">Saudi Arabian art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Cinema of Saudi Arabia">Cinema of Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Music of Saudi Arabia">Music of Saudi Arabia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Theatre_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Theatre in Saudi Arabia">Theatre in Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg/180px-King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg/270px-King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg/360px-King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg 2x" data-file-width="481" data-file-height="606"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:King_Abdullah_in_his_youth.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>King Abdullah practising <a href="/wiki/Falconry" title="Falconry">falconry</a>, a traditional pursuit in the country
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
