      <p>During the 1970s, cinemas were numerous in the Kingdom although they were seen as contrary to Wahhabi norms.<sup id="cite_ref-Return_of_cinema_in_Saudi_Arabia_provokes_critics_536-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Return_of_cinema_in_Saudi_Arabia_provokes_critics-536">[530]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_revival" title="Islamic revival">Islamic revival</a> movement in the 1980s, and as a political response to an increase in <a href="/wiki/Islamist" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamist">Islamist</a> activism including the 1979 <a href="/wiki/Grand_Mosque_Seizure" class="mw-redirect" title="Grand Mosque Seizure">seizure of the Grand Mosque in Mecca</a>, the government closed all cinemas and theaters. However, with King Abdullah's reforms from 2005, some cinemas have re-opened,<sup id="cite_ref-537" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-537">[531]</a></sup> including one in <a href="/wiki/King_Abdullah_University_of_Science_and_Technology" title="King Abdullah University of Science and Technology">KAUST</a>. </p>
      <p>From the 18th century onward, <a href="/wiki/Wahhabi" class="mw-redirect" title="Wahhabi">Wahhabi</a> fundamentalism discouraged artistic development inconsistent with its teaching. In addition, Sunni Islamic prohibition of creating representations of people have limited the visual arts, which tend to be dominated by <a href="/wiki/Islamic_geometric_patterns" title="Islamic geometric patterns">geometric</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabesque_(Islamic_art)" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabesque (Islamic art)">floral</a>, and abstract designs and by <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calligraphy" title="Islamic calligraphy">calligraphy</a>. With the advent of oil-wealth in the 20th century came exposure to outside influences, such as Western housing styles, furnishings, and clothes. Music and dance have always been part of Saudi life. Traditional music is generally associated with poetry and is sung collectively. Instruments include the rabābah, an instrument not unlike a three-string fiddle, and various types of percussion instruments, such as the ṭabl (drum) and the ṭār (tambourine). Of the native dances, the most popular is a martial line dance known as the ʿarḍah, which includes lines of men, frequently armed with swords or rifles, dancing to the beat of drums and tambourines. Bedouin poetry, known as nabaṭī, is still very popular.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_146-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-146">[142]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Censorship has limited the development of Saudi literature, although several <a href="/wiki/List_of_Saudi_Arabian_writers" title="List of Saudi Arabian writers">Saudi novelists and poets</a> have achieved critical and popular acclaim in the Arab world—albeit generating official hostility in their home country. These include <a href="/wiki/Ghazi_Algosaibi" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghazi Algosaibi">Ghazi Algosaibi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abdelrahman_Munif" class="mw-redirect" title="Abdelrahman Munif">Abdelrahman Munif</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turki_al-Hamad" title="Turki al-Hamad">Turki al-Hamad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rajaa_al-Sanea" title="Rajaa al-Sanea">Rajaa al-Sanea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Guardian2410_538-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian2410-538">[532]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-539" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-539">[533]</a></sup> In 2016, the General Entertainment Authority was formed to oversee the expansion of the Saudi entertainment sector.<sup id="cite_ref-540" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-540">[534]</a></sup> The first concerts in Riyadh for 25 years took place the following year.<sup id="cite_ref-541" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-541">[535]</a></sup> Other events since the GEA's creation have included comedy shows, professional wrestling events and monster truck rallies.<sup id="cite_ref-542" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-542">[536]</a></sup> In 2018 the first public cinema opened after a ban of 35 years, with plans to have more than 2,000 screens running by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-543" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-543">[537]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Developments in the arts in 2018 included Saudi Arabia's debut appearances at the <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Venice_Biennale" title="Venice Biennale">Venice Biennale</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-544" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-544">[538]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-545" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-545">[539]</a></sup> At the same time, <a href="/wiki/David_Guetta" title="David Guetta">David Guetta</a> declared that "There is obviously a very big effort in Saudi to open to music and to artists". This was after he performed a concert attended by more than 10,000 people in the heritage site north-west of Riyadh. The concert also included shows by <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Iglesias" title="Enrique Iglesias">Enrique Iglesias</a> and The <a href="/wiki/Black_Eyed_Peas" title="Black Eyed Peas">Black Eyed Peas</a>. Guetta's comments come as Saudi Arabia increasingly attracts big name western music acts to perform in the kingdom. Since his concert last November, <a href="/wiki/Mariah_Carey" title="Mariah Carey">Mariah Carey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sean_Paul" title="Sean Paul">Sean Paul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Akon" title="Akon">Akon</a> all performed in various Saudi cities.<sup id="cite_ref-546" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-546">[540]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Sport in Saudi Arabia">Sport in Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_sport_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Women's sport in Saudi Arabia">Women's sport in Saudi Arabia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_at_the_Olympics" title="Saudi Arabia at the Olympics">Saudi Arabia at the Olympics</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:King_Fahd_International_Stadium,_Riyadh,_Saudi_Arabia,_April_2014.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/King_Fahd_International_Stadium%2C_Riyadh%2C_Saudi_Arabia%2C_April_2014.jpg/220px-King_Fahd_International_Stadium%2C_Riyadh%2C_Saudi_Arabia%2C_April_2014.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/King_Fahd_International_Stadium%2C_Riyadh%2C_Saudi_Arabia%2C_April_2014.jpg/330px-King_Fahd_International_Stadium%2C_Riyadh%2C_Saudi_Arabia%2C_April_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/King_Fahd_International_Stadium%2C_Riyadh%2C_Saudi_Arabia%2C_April_2014.jpg/440px-King_Fahd_International_Stadium%2C_Riyadh%2C_Saudi_Arabia%2C_April_2014.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1920"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:King_Fahd_International_Stadium,_Riyadh,_Saudi_Arabia,_April_2014.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/King_Fahd_International_Stadium" title="King Fahd International Stadium">King Fahd International Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Riyadh" title="Riyadh">Riyadh</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Football_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Football in Saudi Arabia">Football</a> is the national sport in Saudi Arabia. The <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_national_football_team" title="Saudi Arabia national football team">Saudi Arabia national football team</a> is considered as one of Asia's most successful national teams, having reached a joint record 6 <a href="/wiki/AFC_Asian_Cup" title="AFC Asian Cup">AFC Asian Cup</a> finals, winning three of those finals (1984, 1988, and 1996) and having qualified for the World Cup four consecutive times ever since debuting at the 1994 tournament. In the <a href="/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1994 FIFA World Cup">1994 FIFA World Cup</a> under the leadership of Jorge Solari, Saudi Arabia beat both Belgium and Morocco in the group stage before falling to defeat Sweden in the round of 16. During the <a href="/wiki/1992_King_Fahd_Cup" title="1992 King Fahd Cup">1992 FIFA Confederations Cup</a>, which was played in Saudi Arabia, the country reached the <a href="/wiki/1992_King_Fahd_Cup_Final" title="1992 King Fahd Cup Final">final</a>, losing 1–3 to <a href="/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team" title="Argentina national football team">Argentina</a>. <a href="/wiki/Scuba_diving" title="Scuba diving">Scuba diving</a>, <a href="/wiki/Windsurfing" title="Windsurfing">windsurfing</a>, sailing and basketball (which is played by both men and women) are also popular with the <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Saudi Arabia national basketball team">Saudi Arabian national basketball team</a> winning bronze at the <a href="/wiki/1999_ABC_Championship" title="1999 ABC Championship">1999 Asian Championship</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-547" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-547">[541]</a></sup> More traditional sports such as <a href="/wiki/Horse_racing" title="Horse racing">horse racing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Camel_racing" title="Camel racing">camel racing</a> are also popular. A stadium in Riyadh holds races in the winter. The annual King's Camel Race, begun in 1974, is one of the sport's most important contests and attracts animals and riders from throughout the region. <a href="/wiki/Falconry" title="Falconry">Falconry</a>, another traditional pursuit, is still practiced.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_146-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-146">[142]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Women's sport is controversial due to the suppression of female participation in sport by conservative Islamic religious authorities,<sup id="cite_ref-548" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-548">[542]</a></sup> however this restriction has eased slightly in recent years.<sup id="cite_ref-549" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-549">[543]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-550" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-550">[544]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-551" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-551">[545]</a></sup> Until 2018 women were not permitted in sport stadiums. Segregated seating, allowing women to enter, has been developed in three stadiums across major cities.<sup id="cite_ref-552" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-552">[546]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Saudi Arabia, in its vision for modernization introduced the nation to a number of international sporting events, bringing sports stars to the Kingdom. However, in August 2019, the kingdom's strategy received criticism for appearing as a method of <a href="/wiki/Sportswashing" title="Sportswashing">sportswashing</a> soon after Saudi's US based 2018 lobbying campaign foreign registration documentations got published online. The documents showed Saudi Arabia as allegedly implementing a ‘sportswashing’ strategy, inclusive of meetings and official calls with supreme authorities of associations like the Major League Soccer (MLS), World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE), National Basketball Association (NBA). The strategy is being viewed as a method of sportswashing following the chaos spread across Yemen since 4 years.<sup id="cite_ref-553" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-553">[547]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 31 October 2019, Saudi Arabia hosted the first ever women's <a href="/wiki/Wrestling" title="Wrestling">wrestling</a> match held by the <a href="/wiki/WWE" title="WWE">World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE)</a>. However, the superstar players <a href="/wiki/Lacey_Evans" title="Lacey Evans">Lacey Evans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natalya_Neidhart" title="Natalya Neidhart">Natalya</a> were required to cover their arms and legs by wearing bodysuits during the fight, instead of the more revealing gear that they would normally wear.<sup id="cite_ref-554" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-554">[548]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Saudi Arabia, in December 2019, came under fire for using Western sports to rehabilitate global image tarnished following the continued crackdown on dissidents. Critics accused the kingdom of "sportswashing", as it turned a blind eye to the unending violation of human rights in the country against women, minorities, rights advocates and critics.<sup id="cite_ref-555" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-555">[549]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Only two years after Saudi Arabia signed a contract of 10 years with WWE, an increasing number of <a href="/wiki/Professional_wrestlers" class="mw-redirect" title="Professional wrestlers">wrestlers</a> denied to visit Riyadh. In 2018, superstars like <a href="/wiki/John_Cena" title="John Cena">John Cena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Owens" title="Kevin Owens">Kevin Owens</a> and <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Bryan" title="Daniel Bryan">Daniel Bryan</a> refused to fly to Saudi, over the Kingdom's declining human rights records citing <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Jamal_Khashoggi" title="Assassination of Jamal Khashoggi">Jamal Khashoggi's assassination</a>. In January 2020, several other WWE superstars cast doubt over visiting Saudi, following the <a href="/wiki/2020_Baghdad_International_Airport_airstrike" class="mw-redirect" title="2020 Baghdad International Airport airstrike">heightened tensions</a> in <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a> due to assassination of <a href="/wiki/Qassem_Soleimani" class="mw-redirect" title="Qassem Soleimani">Qassem Soleimani</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-556" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-556">[550]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> announced to hold its 2021 race in Saudi Arabia for the next season. It would be the first time the Gulf nation would be hosting an F1 race as one of 23 grand prix in the busiest calendar ever. The night race is said to be held on a street circuit in <a href="/wiki/Jeddah" title="Jeddah">Jeddah</a>. However, F1’s decision of letting Saudi Arabia host the next season of race is expected to receive criticism considering the nation's human rights abuse record and the alleged use of F1 with the intent of sportswashing.<sup id="cite_ref-557" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-557">[551]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_cuisine" title="Saudi Arabian cuisine">Saudi Arabian cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:ArabicCoffee.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/ArabicCoffee.jpg/170px-ArabicCoffee.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="222" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/ArabicCoffee.jpg/255px-ArabicCoffee.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/ArabicCoffee.jpg/340px-ArabicCoffee.jpg 2x" data-file-width="576" data-file-height="753"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:ArabicCoffee.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Arabic_coffee" title="Arabic coffee">Arabic coffee</a> is a traditional beverage in Arabian cuisine
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_cuisine" title="Saudi Arabian cuisine">Saudi Arabian cuisine</a> is similar to that of the surrounding countries in the Arabian Peninsula and the wider Arab world, and has influenced and been influenced by Turkish, Indian, Persian, and African food. <a href="/wiki/Islamic_dietary_laws" title="Islamic dietary laws">Islamic dietary laws</a> are enforced: pork is not allowed and other animals are slaughtered in accordance with <a href="/wiki/Halal" title="Halal">halal</a>. <a href="/wiki/Kebabs" class="mw-redirect" title="Kebabs">Kebabs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Falafel" title="Falafel">falafel</a> are popular, as is <i>shāwarmā</i> (<a href="/wiki/Shawarma" title="Shawarma">shawarma</a>), a marinated grilled meat dish of <a href="/wiki/Lamb_and_mutton" title="Lamb and mutton">lamb</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mutton" class="mw-redirect" title="Mutton">mutton</a>, or chicken. As in other Arab countries of the Arabian Peninsula, <i>machbūs</i> (<a href="/wiki/Kabsa" title="Kabsa">kabsa</a>), a rice dish with lamb, chicken, fish or <a href="/wiki/Shrimp" title="Shrimp">shrimp</a>, is among the national dishes as well as the dish <a href="/wiki/Mandi_(food)" title="Mandi (food)">mandi (food)</a>. Flat, unleavened <a href="/wiki/Taboon_bread" title="Taboon bread">taboon bread</a> is a staple of virtually every meal, as are <a href="/wiki/Date_(fruit)" class="mw-redirect" title="Date (fruit)">dates</a>, fresh fruit, yoghurt and <a href="/wiki/Hummus" title="Hummus">hummus</a>. Coffee, served in the <a href="/wiki/Arabic_coffee" title="Arabic coffee">Arabic style</a>, is the traditional beverage but tea and various fruit juices are popular as well.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_146-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-146">[142]</a></sup> Arabic coffee is a traditional beverage in Arabian cuisine. The earliest substantiated evidence of either <a href="/wiki/History_of_coffee" title="History of coffee">coffee drinking</a> or knowledge of the coffee tree is from the 15th century, in the <a href="/wiki/Sufi" class="mw-redirect" title="Sufi">Sufi</a> monasteries of <a href="/wiki/Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabia">Arabia</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Women">Women</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_rights_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Women's rights in Saudi Arabia">Women's rights in Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_education_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Women's education in Saudi Arabia">Women's education in Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Women do not have equal rights to men in the kingdom; the <a href="/wiki/U.S._State_Department" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. State Department">U.S. State Department</a> considers Saudi Arabian government's discrimination against women a "significant problem" in Saudi Arabia and notes that women have few political rights due to the government's discriminatory policies.<sup id="cite_ref-State2010_558-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-State2010-558">[552]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum</a> 2010 <a href="/wiki/Global_Gender_Gap_Report" title="Global Gender Gap Report">Global Gender Gap Report</a> ranked Saudi Arabia 129th out of 134 countries for gender parity.<sup id="cite_ref-559" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-559">[553]</a></sup> Other sources had complained of an absence of laws criminalizing violence against women.<sup id="cite_ref-State2010_558-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-State2010-558">[552]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Under Saudi law, every adult female must have a male relative as her "guardian" (<i><a href="/wiki/Wali_(Islamic_legal_guardian)" title="Wali (Islamic legal guardian)">wali</a></i>),<sup id="cite_ref-State2010_558-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-State2010-558">[552]</a></sup> As of 2008, a woman was required to have permission from her male guardian in order to travel, study, or work.<sup id="cite_ref-State2010_558-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-State2010-558">[552]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-HRWPM2_560-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HRWPM2-560">[554]</a></sup> A royal decree passed in May 2017 allowed them to avail government services such as education and healthcare without the need of a consent of a male guardian. The order however also stated that it should only be allowed if it does not contradict the Sharia system.<sup id="cite_ref-561" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-561">[555]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-562" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-562">[556]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Saudi_in_niqap.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Saudi_in_niqap.jpg/170px-Saudi_in_niqap.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="248" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Saudi_in_niqap.jpg/255px-Saudi_in_niqap.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Saudi_in_niqap.jpg/340px-Saudi_in_niqap.jpg 2x" data-file-width="583" data-file-height="850"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Saudi_in_niqap.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Saudi woman wearing a <a href="/wiki/Niq%C4%81b" title="Niqāb">niqāb</a> in Riyadh. Under Saudi law, women are required to wear an <a href="/wiki/Abaya" title="Abaya">abaya</a> but niqab and <a href="/wiki/Hijab" title="Hijab">hijab</a> is optional.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to a leading Saudi feminist and journalist, <a href="/wiki/Wajeha_al-Huwaider" title="Wajeha al-Huwaider">Wajeha al-Huwaider</a>, "Saudi women are weak, no matter how high their status, even the 'pampered' ones among them, because they have no law to protect them from attack by anyone."<sup id="cite_ref-563" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-563">[557]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Women face discrimination in the courts, where the testimony of one man equals that of two women <a href="/wiki/Legal_system_of_Saudi_Arabia#Family_law" title="Legal system of Saudi Arabia">in family and inheritance law</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-State2010_558-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-State2010-558">[552]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Polygamy" title="Polygamy">Polygamy</a> is permitted for men,<sup id="cite_ref-564" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-564">[558]</a></sup> and men have a unilateral right to divorce their wives (<a href="/wiki/Divorce_(Islamic)" class="mw-redirect" title="Divorce (Islamic)">talaq</a>) without needing any legal justification.<sup id="cite_ref-Otto164_565-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Otto164-565">[559]</a></sup> A woman can only obtain a divorce with the consent of her husband or judicially if her husband has harmed her.<sup id="cite_ref-Otto163_566-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Otto163-566">[560]</a></sup> In practice, it is very difficult for a Saudi woman to obtain a judicial divorce.<sup id="cite_ref-Otto163_566-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Otto163-566">[560]</a></sup> With regard to the law of inheritance, the Quran specifies that fixed portions of the deceased's estate must be left to the <i>Qur'anic heirs</i><sup id="cite_ref-Otto165_567-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Otto165-567">[561]</a></sup> and generally, female heirs receive half the portion of male heirs.<sup id="cite_ref-Otto165_567-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Otto165-567">[561]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The average <a href="/wiki/Age_at_first_marriage" class="mw-redirect" title="Age at first marriage">age at first marriage</a> among Saudi females is 25 years in Saudi Arabia,<sup id="cite_ref-568" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-568">[562]</a></sup> with child marriage no longer common.<sup id="cite_ref-569" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-569">[563]</a></sup> As of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Saudi women constitute 13% of the country's native workforce despite being 51% of all university graduates.<sup id="cite_ref-570" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-570">[564]</a></sup> Female literacy is estimated to be 81%, lower than male literacy.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_4-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook-4">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-unicef-literacy_571-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unicef-literacy-571">[565]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Obesity is a problem among middle and upper class Saudis who have domestic servants to do traditional work but, until 2018, were forbidden to drive and so are limited in their ability to leave their home.<sup id="cite_ref-beliefs_572-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beliefs-572">[566]</a></sup> As of April 2014, Saudi authorities in the education ministry have been asked by the Shoura Council to consider lifting a state school ban on sports for girls with the proviso that any sports conform to Sharia rules on dress and gender segregation, according to the official SPA news agency.<sup id="cite_ref-McDowall_391-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McDowall-391">[387]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Islamic_religious_police" title="Islamic religious police">religious police</a>, known as the <i>mutawa</i>, impose many restrictions on women in public in Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-State2010_558-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-State2010-558">[552]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Dammer_573-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dammer-573">[567]</a></sup> The restrictions include forcing women to sit in separate specially designated family sections in restaurants, to wear an <a href="/wiki/Abaya" title="Abaya">abaya</a> and to cover their hair.<sup id="cite_ref-State2010_558-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-State2010-558">[552]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Although Saudi Arabia imposes a strict dress code on women throughout the country by using <a href="/wiki/Islamic_religious_police" title="Islamic religious police">religious police</a>, female anchors working for <a href="/wiki/Al_Arabiya" title="Al Arabiya">Al-Arabia news network</a> which is partly owned by <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Aziz_bin_Fahd" class="mw-redirect" title="Abdul Aziz bin Fahd">Prince Abdulaziz</a>, the son of the late <a href="/wiki/Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Fahd of Saudi Arabia">King Fahad</a>, are prohibited from wearing a veil and are encouraged to adopt a <a href="/wiki/Western_dress_codes" title="Western dress codes">Western dress code</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-574" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-574">[568]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A few Saudi women have risen to the top of the medical profession; for example, Dr. Ghada Al-Mutairi heads a medical research center in California<sup id="cite_ref-alarabiya.net_575-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alarabiya.net-575">[569]</a></sup> and Dr. <a href="/wiki/Salwa_Al-Hazzaa" class="mw-redirect" title="Salwa Al-Hazzaa">Salwa Al-Hazzaa</a> is head of the ophthalmology department at <a href="/wiki/King_Faisal_Specialist_Hospital" class="mw-redirect" title="King Faisal Specialist Hospital">King Faisal Specialist Hospital</a> in Riyadh and was the late King Fahad's personal <a href="/wiki/Ophthalmologist" class="mw-redirect" title="Ophthalmologist">ophthalmologist</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-576" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-576">[570]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In February 2017, Saudi Arabia appointed its first woman to head the Saudi Stock Exchange.<sup id="cite_ref-577" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-577">[571]</a></sup> As of 2018, two women hold cabinet positions in the Saudi government: Dr Tamadur bint Youssef Al Ramah, who was appointed Deputy Labour Minister that year; and Norah bint Abdallah Al Faiz, who became deputy minister of education in charge of women's affairs in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-578" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-578">[572]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span id="Political.2C_economic.2C_and_social_changes_of_the_2010s"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Political,_economic,_and_social_changes_of_the_2010s">Political, economic, and social changes of the 2010s</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Vision_2030" title="Saudi Vision 2030">Saudi Vision 2030</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="box-Example_farm plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40">
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This article <b>may contain <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:What_Wikipedia_is_not#Wikipedia_is_not_an_indiscriminate_collection_of_information" title="Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not">indiscriminate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Embedded_lists#List_size" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Embedded lists">excessive</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Neutral_point_of_view#Due_and_undue_weight" title="Wikipedia:Neutral point of view">irrelevant</a> examples</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Saudi_Arabia&amp;action=edit">improve the article</a> by adding more descriptive text and removing <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Example_cruft" title="Wikipedia:Example cruft">less pertinent examples</a>. See Wikipedia's <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Writing_better_articles" title="Wikipedia:Writing better articles">guide to writing better articles</a> for further suggestions.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">September 2020</span>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>On 25 September 2011, King Abdullah announced that Saudi women would gain the right to vote (and to be candidates) in municipal elections, provided that a male guardian grants permission.<sup id="cite_ref-579" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-579">[573]</a></sup> Women were allowed to vote and be candidates in the <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabian_municipal_elections,_2015" class="mw-redirect" title="Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2015">12 December 2015 municipal elections</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-580" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-580">[574]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In August 2013, a law was passed that criminalized domestic violence against women. The ban includes penalties of a 12-month jail sentence and fines of up to 50,000 riyals ($13,000).<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Usher_581-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Usher-581">[575]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AlJazeeraAmerica_582-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AlJazeeraAmerica-582">[576]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-583" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-583">[577]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In February 2017, Saudi Arabia appointed its first woman to head the <a href="/wiki/Tadawul" title="Tadawul">Saudi Stock Exchange</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-584" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-584">[578]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-585" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-585">[579]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In April 2017, bin Salman announced a project to build one of the world's largest cultural, sports and entertainment cities in Al Qidiya, southwest of Riyadh. The 334-square kilometre city will include a safari and a <a href="/wiki/Six_Flags" title="Six Flags">Six Flags</a> theme park.<sup id="cite_ref-586" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-586">[580]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-587" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-587">[581]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In September 2017, King Salman issued a decree allowing <a href="/wiki/Women_to_drive_movement" title="Women to drive movement">women to drive</a>, lifting the world's only ban on women drivers.<sup id="cite_ref-588" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-588">[582]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As of February 2018, Saudi women can now open their own business, without a male's permission.<sup id="cite_ref-589" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-589">[583]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In March 2018, a law was passed allowing Saudi mothers to retain custody of their children after divorce without having to file any lawsuits.<sup id="cite_ref-590" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-590">[584]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In April 2018, the first public cinema opened in Saudi Arabia after a ban of 35 years, with plans to have more than 2,000 screens running by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-591" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-591">[585]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-592" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-592">[586]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Other domestic reforms include significant regulations restricting the powers of the <a href="/wiki/Committee_for_the_Promotion_of_Virtue_and_the_Prevention_of_Vice_(Saudi_Arabia)" title="Committee for the Promotion of Virtue and the Prevention of Vice (Saudi Arabia)">religious police</a> and establishing a national entertainment authority that has hosted comedy shows, pro wrestling events, and monster truck rallies. Further cultural developments include the first Saudi public concerts by a female singer, the first Saudi sports stadiums to admit women, and an increased presence of women in the workforce.<sup id="cite_ref-593" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-593">[587]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 1 August 2019, Saudi Arabia allowed women to travel abroad, register a divorce or a marriage, and apply for official documents without the consent of a male guardian. The laws also grant the women the eligibility for the guardianship of minor children.<sup id="cite_ref-594" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-594">[588]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-595" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-595">[589]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-596" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-596">[590]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 27 September 2019, Saudi Arabia announced new changes to <a href="/wiki/Tourist_visas" class="mw-redirect" title="Tourist visas">tourist visas</a> for non-religious visits, allowing citizens of 49 countries to apply for <a href="/wiki/E-Visa" class="mw-redirect" title="E-Visa">E-Visa</a> for 90 days.<sup id="cite_ref-597" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-597">[591]</a></sup> On 2 January 2020, Saudi Arabia announced three days Events-Only visa for expats living in <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">Bahrain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kuwait" title="Kuwait">Kuwait</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-598" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-598">[592]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Crown Prince <a href="/wiki/Mohammed_bin_Salman" class="mw-redirect" title="Mohammed bin Salman">Mohammed bin Salman</a> had envisaged the year 2020 in line with his modernization plans, where a record number of <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">Muslims</a> were to visit the <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a>, new industries were to set up, entertainment sector was meant to flourish, while the crown prince was to host the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a> summit. However, the unexpected impact of <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a> on the economy, along with Saudi Arabia's poor <a href="/wiki/Human_rights" title="Human rights">human rights</a> records, laid unforeseen challenges before the development plans of the Kingdom, where some of the programs under ‘<a href="/wiki/Saudi_Vision_2030" title="Saudi Vision 2030">Vision 2030</a>’ were also expected to be affected.<sup id="cite_ref-599" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-599">[593]</a></sup> On 2 May, the Finance Minister of Saudi Arabia admitted that the country's economy was facing a severe economical crisis for the first time in decades, due to the pandemic as well as declining global oil markets. <a href="/wiki/Mohammed_Al-Jadaan" title="Mohammed Al-Jadaan">Mohammed Al-Jadaan</a> said that the country will take “painful” measures and keep all options open to deal with the impact. However, despite the gloomy economy and the need to “cut deeply” the government spending, the country had laid plans to acquire <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_United" class="mw-redirect" title="Newcastle United">Newcastle United</a> worth £300 million.<sup id="cite_ref-600" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-600">[594]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-601" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-601">[595]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Education in Saudi Arabia">Education in Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg/220px-KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg/330px-KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg/440px-KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1384" data-file-height="867"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:KAUST_laboratory_buildings_and_town_mosque.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Laboratory buildings at <a href="/wiki/KAUST" class="mw-redirect" title="KAUST">KAUST</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG/220px-Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG/330px-Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG/440px-Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="599"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Al_Yamamah_University_Main_Campus.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Al-Yamamah_Private_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-Yamamah Private University">Al-Yamamah Private University</a> in Riyadh
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Education is free at all levels.<sup id="cite_ref-602" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-602">[596]</a></sup> The school system is composed of elementary, intermediate, and secondary schools. A large part of the curriculum at all levels is devoted to Islam, and, at the secondary level, students are able to follow either a religious or a technical track. The rate of literacy is 97.1% among males and is about 92.71% among females (2017).<sup id="cite_ref-603" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-603">[597]</a></sup> Classes are segregated by sex. </p>
      <p>According to the educational plan for secondary (high school) education 1435–1438 <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Hijri</a>, students enrolling in the "natural sciences" path are required to take five religion subjects which are: <a href="/wiki/Tawhid" title="Tawhid">Tawhid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fiqh" title="Fiqh">Fiqh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tafsir" title="Tafsir">Tafseer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hadith" title="Hadith">Hadith</a> and Islamic Education and Quran. In addition, students are required to take six science subjects which are Maths, Physics, Chemistry, Biology, Geology and Computer.<sup id="cite_ref-604" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-604">[598]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Higher education has expanded rapidly, with large numbers of <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_and_colleges_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="List of universities and colleges in Saudi Arabia">Universities and colleges being founded particularly since 2000</a>. Institutions of higher education include the country's first university, <a href="/wiki/King_Saud_University" title="King Saud University">King Saud University</a> founded in 1957, the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_University_of_Madinah" title="Islamic University of Madinah">Islamic University</a> at <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a> founded in 1961, and the <a href="/wiki/King_Abdulaziz_University" title="King Abdulaziz University">King Abdulaziz University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jeddah" title="Jeddah">Jeddah</a> founded in 1967. <a href="/wiki/King_Abdullah_University_of_Science_and_Technology" title="King Abdullah University of Science and Technology">King Abdullah University of Science and Technology</a>, known as KAUST, founded recently in 2009. Other colleges and universities emphasize curricula in sciences and technology, military studies, religion, and medicine. Institutes devoted to Islamic studies, in particular, abound. Women typically receive college instruction in segregated institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_146-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-146">[142]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png/220px-UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="174" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png/330px-UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/85/UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png 2x" data-file-width="403" data-file-height="318"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:UIS_literacy_rate_Saudi_Arabia_population_plus15_1990-2015.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Institute_for_Statistics" title="UNESCO Institute for Statistics">UIS</a> literacy rate Saudi Arabia population, 15 plus, 1990–2015
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities" title="Academic Ranking of World Universities">Academic Ranking of World Universities</a></i>, known as Shanghai Ranking, ranked 4 of Saudi Arabian institutions among its 2016–2017 list of the 980 top universities in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-605" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-605">[599]</a></sup> Also, the <a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">QS World University Rankings</a> has ranked 19 Saudi universities among the top 100 Arab institutions, on its 13th edition.<sup id="cite_ref-606" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-606">[600]</a></sup> The latest list of Academic Ranking of World Universities 2018, ranked two Saudi universities, King Abdulaziz University and King Saud University, among the top 150 universities in the World.<sup id="cite_ref-607" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-607">[601]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-608" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-608">[602]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2018, Saudi Arabia ranked 28th worldwide in terms of high-quality research output according to the <a href="/wiki/Scientific_journal" title="Scientific journal">scientific journal</a> <a href="/wiki/Nature_(journal)" title="Nature (journal)">Nature</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-609" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-609">[603]</a></sup> This makes Saudi Arabia the best performing <a href="/wiki/Middle_Eastern" class="mw-redirect" title="Middle Eastern">Middle Eastern</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab">Arab</a> and <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> country.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Saudi Arabia spends 8.8% of its gross domestic product on education, compared with the global average of 4.6%.<sup id="cite_ref-610" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-610">[604]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Memorization by rote of large parts of the Qur'an, its interpretation and understanding (<a href="/wiki/Tafsir" title="Tafsir">Tafsir</a>) and the application of Islamic tradition to everyday life is at the core of the curriculum. Religion taught in this manner is also a compulsory subject for all University students.<sup id="cite_ref-611" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-611">[605]</a></sup> As a consequence, Saudi youth "generally lacks the education and technical skills the private sector needs" according to the CIA.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_4-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook-4">[3]</a></sup> Similarly, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Chronicle_of_Higher_Education" title="The Chronicle of Higher Education">The Chronicle of Higher Education</a></i> wrote in 2010 that "the country needs educated young Saudis with marketable skills and a capacity for innovation and entrepreneurship. That's not generally what Saudi Arabia's educational system delivers, steeped as it is in rote learning and religious instruction."<sup id="cite_ref-chronicle.com_612-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chronicle.com-612">[606]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The religious sector of the Saudi national curriculum was examined in a 2006 report by <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> which concluded that "the Saudi public school religious curriculum continues to propagate an ideology of hate toward the 'unbeliever', that is, Christians, Jews, Shiites, Sufis, Sunni Muslims who do not follow <a href="/wiki/Wahhabi" class="mw-redirect" title="Wahhabi">Wahhabi</a> doctrine, <a href="/wiki/Hindu" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindu">Hindus</a>, atheists and others".<sup id="cite_ref-FH-education_613-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FH-education-613">[607]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-614" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-614">[608]</a></sup> The Saudi religious studies curriculum is taught outside the Kingdom via Saudi-linked <a href="/wiki/Madrasah" class="mw-redirect" title="Madrasah">madrasah</a>, schools, and clubs throughout the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Panorama_2010_615-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Panorama_2010-615">[609]</a></sup> Critics have described the education system as "medieval" and that its primary goal "is to maintain the rule of absolute monarchy by casting it as the ordained protector of the faith, and that Islam is at war with other faiths and cultures".<sup id="cite_ref-616" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-616">[610]</a></sup> This radical teaching takes place in Saudi funded mosques and <a href="/wiki/Madrasas" class="mw-redirect" title="Madrasas">madrasas</a> across the Islamic world from <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a> to <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> to <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-617" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-617">[611]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The approach taken in the Saudi education system has been accused of encouraging <a href="/wiki/Islamic_terrorism" title="Islamic terrorism">Islamic terrorism</a>, leading to reform efforts.<sup id="cite_ref-Reforming_Saudi_Education_618-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reforming_Saudi_Education-618">[612]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-619" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-619">[613]</a></sup> Following the 9/11 attacks, the government aimed to tackle the twin problems of encouraging extremism and the inadequacy of the country's university education for a modern economy, by slowly modernising the education system through the "Tatweer" reform program.<sup id="cite_ref-Reforming_Saudi_Education_618-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reforming_Saudi_Education-618">[612]</a></sup> The Tatweer program is reported to have a budget of approximately US$2 billion and focuses on moving teaching away from the traditional Saudi methods of memorization and rote learning towards encouraging students to analyze and problem-solve. It also aims to create an education system which will provide a more secular and vocationally based training.<sup id="cite_ref-chronicle.com_612-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chronicle.com-612">[606]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-620" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-620">[614]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2021, the <a href="/wiki/Washington_Post" class="mw-redirect" title="Washington Post">Washington Post</a> newspaper published a report on the measures taken by Saudi Arabia to clean textbooks from paragraphs considered anti-Semitic and anti-women. The paragraphs dealing with the punishment of homosexuality or same-sex relations have been deleted, and expressions of admiration for the extremist martyrdom. Anti-Semitic expressions and calls to fight the Jews became fewer. David Weinberg, director of international affairs for the Anti-Defamation League in Washington, said that references to demonizing Jews, Christians and Shiites have been removed from some places or have toned down, noting the deletion of paragraphs that talk about killing gays, infidels and witches. The US State Department expressed in an email that it welcomed the changes to the materials affecting Saudi educational curricula. The Foreign Ministry supports a training program for Saudi teachers.<sup id="cite_ref-621" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-621">[615]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_care">Health care</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Health in Saudi Arabia">Health in Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Health care in Saudi Arabia">Health care in Saudi Arabia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Saudi Arabia has a <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> of 74.99 years (73.79 for males and 76.61 for females) according to the latest data for the year 2018 from the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_622-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-622">[616]</a></sup> Infant mortality in 2018 was 6 per 1,000.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_622-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-622">[616]</a></sup> In 2016, 69.7% of the adult population was <a href="/wiki/Overweight" title="Overweight">overweight</a> and 35.5% was <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">obese</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-623" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-623">[617]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <i><a href="/wiki/Shahada" title="Shahada">Shahādah</a></i> (Statement of faith) is sometimes translated into English as 'There is no god but Allah', using the <a href="/wiki/Romanization" title="Romanization">romanization</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a> word <i><a href="/wiki/Allah" title="Allah">Allāh</a></i> instead of its translation. The word <i>Allāh</i> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">ٱلله</span>‎) literally translates as <i>the God</i>, as the prefix 'Al-' is the definite article.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-10">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Legislation is by <a href="/wiki/Rule_by_decree" title="Rule by decree">king's decree</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Consultative_Assembly_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia">Consultative Assembly</a> exists to advise the king.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-15">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">ˌ</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="/ɔː/: 'au' in 'fraud'">ɔː</span><span title="'d' in 'dye'">d</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span></span><span class="wrap"> </span><span 'face'">eɪ</span><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span></span>/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Saudi_Arabia-2.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" Arabia-2.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>, <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">ˌ</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="/aʊ/: 'ou' in 'mouth'">aʊ</span></span>-/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Saudi_Arabia-3.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b3/En-us-Saudi_Arabia-3.ogg" class="internal" title="En-us-Saudi Arabia-3.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>; <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">ٱلسَّعُوْدِيَّة</span>‎ <i><i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language romanization">As-Saʿūdīyah</i></i></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">KSA; <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">ٱلْمَمْلَكَة ٱلْعَرَبِيَّة ٱلسَّعُوْدِيَّة</span>‎ <i><i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language romanization">al-Mamlakah al-ʿArabīyah as-Saʿūdīyah</i></i>, <span style="font-size:90%;"><span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ar-Kingdom_Saudi_Arabia.oga" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/48/Ar-Kingdom_Saudi_Arabia.oga" class="internal" title="Ar-Kingdom Saudi Arabia.oga">pronunciation</a></span>&nbsp;<small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">(<a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:Media help"><span style="cursor:help;">help</span></a>·<a href="/wiki/File:Ar-Kingdom_Saudi_Arabia.oga" title="File:Ar-Kingdom Saudi Arabia.oga"><span style="cursor:help;">info</span></a>)</small></span></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-445"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-445">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Mosque_of_the_Companions,_Massawa" title="Mosque of the Companions, Massawa">Mosque of the Companions</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Eritrea" title="Eritrea">Eritrean</a> city of <a href="/wiki/Massawa" title="Massawa">Massawa</a> dates to approximately the same period, the 7th century CE.<sup id="cite_ref-Reid2012Massawa_444-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reid2012Massawa-444">[440]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-490"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-490">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A number of Muslims, using justifications from the Quran,<sup id="cite_ref-Cite_quran|2|7|e=286|s=ns_480-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cite_quran|2|7|e=286|s=ns-480">[475]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Cite_quran|3|96|t=y|s=ns_481-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cite_quran|3|96|t=y|s=ns-481">[476]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Cite_quran|22|25|e=37|s=ns_482-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cite_quran|22|25|e=37|s=ns-482">[477]</a></sup> insist that Islam did not begin with <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_in_Islam" title="Muhammad in Islam">Muhammad</a>, but that it represents even previous <a href="/wiki/Prophet" title="Prophet">Prophets</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Abraham_in_Islam" title="Abraham in Islam">Abraham</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Esposito1998_483-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Esposito1998-483">[478]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Esposito2002b_484-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Esposito2002b-484">[479]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Peters2003_485-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Peters2003-485">[480]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Alli2013_486-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alli2013-486">[481]</a></sup> who is credited with having established the sanctuary of Mecca.<sup id="cite_ref-Michigan_C_1986_487-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Michigan_C_1986-487">[482]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Abu_Sway_2011_488-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abu_Sway_2011-488">[483]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Dyrness2013_489-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dyrness2013-489">[484]</a></sup></span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>

         <li id="cite_note-landscape-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-landscape_19-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.pewforum.org/2012/12/18/global-religious-landscape-exec/">"The Global Religious Landscape"</a>.          <li id="cite_note-Safran1988-55"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Safran1988_55-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSafran1988" class="citation book cs1">Safran, Nadav (1988). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=zSkIi_1T1FsC&amp;pg=PA55"><i>Saudi Arabia: The Ceaseless Quest for Security</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-Cordesman_2009-127"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Cordesman_2009_127-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Cordesman_2009_127-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation book cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/worlditspeoplesm0000unse/page/78"><i>World and Its Peoples: the Arabian Peninsula</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-Gerhard-142"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Gerhard_142-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-170"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-170">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRobertson2007" class="citation news cs1">Robertson, David (7 June 2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article1899614.ece">"Saudi bribe claims delay £20bn fighter deal"</a>. <i>The Times</i>.          <li id="cite_note-PBS-171"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-PBS_171-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/terrorism/interviews/bandar.html">"Interview: Bandar Bin Sultan"</a>.          <li id="cite_note-Long11-190"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Long11_190-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#Long">Long</a>, p. 11</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-IBP-191"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-IBP_191-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IBP_191-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-199"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-199">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFOxford_Business_Group2009" class="citation book cs1">Oxford Business Group (2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=gMPjxHzG1xQC&amp;pg=PA202"><i>The Report: Saudi Arabia</i></a>. p.&nbsp;202. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-902339-00-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-902339-00-9"><bdi>978-1-902339-00-9</bdi></a>. <q>it is not always possible to reach a conclusion on how a Saudi court or judicial committee would view a particular case [because] decisions of a court or a judicial committee have no binding authority with respect to another case, [and] in general there is also no system of court reporting in the Kingdom.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Report%3A+Saudi+Arabia&amp;rft.pages=202&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-902339-00-9&amp;rft.au=Oxford+Business+Group&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DgMPjxHzG1xQC%26pg%3DPA202&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-345"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-345">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/uk-and-saudi-arabia-made-secret-deal-to-exchange-votes-for-human-rights-council-seats-leaked-a6673491.html">UK helped Saudi Arabia get UN human rights role through 'secret deal' to exchange votes, leaked documents suggest</a>". <i><a href="/wiki/The_Independent" title="The Independent">The Independent</a></i>. 30 September 2015.</span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-398"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-398">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20101122123445/http://www.eia.doe.gov/pub/international/iealf/crudeoilreserves.xls">"Crude Oil Reserves"</a>.          <li id="cite_note-399"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-399">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSimmons2005" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Matthew_Simmons" title="Matthew Simmons">Simmons, Matthew</a> (2005) [10 June 2005]. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/twilightindesert00simm_0"><i>Twilight in the Desert: The Coming Saudi Oil Shock and the World Economy</i></a>. Wiley. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-471-73876-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-471-73876-3"><bdi>978-0-471-73876-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Twilight+in+the+Desert%3A+The+Coming+Saudi+Oil+Shock+and+the+World+Economy&amp;rft.pub=Wiley&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-471-73876-3&amp;rft.aulast=Simmons&amp;rft.aufirst=Matthew&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Ftwilightindesert00simm_0&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Aluwaisheg-400"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Aluwaisheg_400-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAbdel_Aziz_Aluwaisheg2014" class="citation journal cs1">Abdel Aziz Aluwaisheg (29 September 2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.arabnews.com/news/464657">"When privatization goes wrong"</a>. <i>Arab News</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Arab+News&amp;rft.atitle=When+privatization+goes+wrong&amp;rft.date=2014-09-29&amp;rft.au=Abdel+Aziz+Aluwaisheg&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.arabnews.com%2Fnews%2F464657&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-MV2013-401"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-MV2013_401-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mondovisione.com/media-and-resources/news/saudi-stock-exchange-tadawul-annual-statistical-report-2013/">"Saudi Stock Exchange, Annual Statistical Report 2013"</a>. <i>mondovisione.com</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=mondovisione.com&amp;rft.atitle=Saudi+Stock+Exchange%2C+Annual+Statistical+Report+2013&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mondovisione.com%2Fmedia-and-resources%2Fnews%2Fsaudi-stock-exchange-tadawul-annual-statistical-report-2013%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-house-161-402"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-house-161_402-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#House">House</a>, p. 161: "Over the past decade, the government has announced one plan after another to 'Saudize' the economy, but to no avail. The foreign workforce grows, and so does unemployment among Saudis. .... The previous plan called for slashing unemployment to 2.8% only to see it rise to 10.5% in 2009, the end of that plan period. Government plans in Saudi are like those in the old Soviet Union, grandiose but unmet. (Also, as in the old Soviet Union, nearly all Saudi official statistics are unreliable, so economists believe the real Saudi unemployment rate is closer to 40%)"</span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-429"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-429">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/saudi-arabia/">"Saudi Arabia"</a>. <i>The World Factbook</i>.          <li id="cite_note-430"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-430">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131115051640/http://www.relooney.info/SI_Milken-Arabia/0-Important_14.pdf">"Saudi Arabia Population Statistics 2011 (Arabic)"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. p.&nbsp;11.          <li id="cite_note-431"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-431">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.opendemocracy.net/faith-europe_islam/mecca_3882.jsp">"Mecca: Islam's cosmopolitan heart"</a>. <q>The Hijaz is the largest, most populated, and most culturally and religiously diverse region of Saudi Arabia, in large part because it was the traditional host area of all the pilgrims to Mecca, many of whom settled and intermarried there.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Mecca%3A+Islam%27s+cosmopolitan+heart&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.opendemocracy.net%2Ffaith-europe_islam%2Fmecca_3882.jsp&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-432"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-432">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#House">House</a>, p. 69: "Most Saudis only two generations ago eked out a subsistence living in rural provinces, but ... urbanization over the past 40 years [so now] .... fully 80% of Saudis now live in one of the country's three major urban centers – Riyadh, Jeddah, and Dammam."</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-433"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-433">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#HT2003">Tripp, <i>Culture Shock</i>, 2003</a>: p. 31</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-434"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-434">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">One journalist states that 51% of the Saudi population is under the age of 25: 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCaryle_Murphy2012" class="citation web cs1">Caryle Murphy (7 February 2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.newsecuritybeat.org/2012/02/saudi-arabias-youth-and-the-kingdoms-future/">"Saudi Arabia's Youth and the Kingdom's Future"</a>. Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars' Environmental Change and Security Program.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Saudi+Arabia%27s+Youth+and+the+Kingdom%27s+Future&amp;rft.pub=Woodrow+Wilson+International+Center+for+Scholars%27+Environmental+Change+and+Security+Program&amp;rft.date=2012-02-07&amp;rft.au=Caryle+Murphy&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.newsecuritybeat.org%2F2012%2F02%2Fsaudi-arabias-youth-and-the-kingdoms-future%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span> Two other sources state that 60% is under the age of 21: 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation journal cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.economist.com/node/21548973">"Out of the comfort zone"</a>. <i>The Economist</i>. 3 March 2012.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Economist&amp;rft.atitle=Out+of+the+comfort+zone&amp;rft.date=2012-03-03&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.economist.com%2Fnode%2F21548973&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span>, <a href="#House">House</a>, p. 221</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-435"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-435">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Economist magazine lists an estimated nine million: 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation journal cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21589871-saudi-edict-limit-reliance-foreign-workers-fraught">"Go home, but who will replace you?"</a>. <i>The Economist</i>. 16 November 2013.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Economist&amp;rft.atitle=Go+home%2C+but+who+will+replace+you%3F&amp;rft.date=2013-11-16&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.economist.com%2Fnews%2Fmiddle-east-and-africa%2F21589871-saudi-edict-limit-reliance-foreign-workers-fraught&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span> out of a population of 30 million: 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation journal cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21595480-despite-their-immense-wealth-saudis-are-not-happy-no-satisfaction">"Saudi Arabia No satisfaction"</a>. <i>The Economist</i>. 1 February 2014.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Economist&amp;rft.atitle=Saudi+Arabia+No+satisfaction&amp;rft.date=2014-02-01&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.economist.com%2Fnews%2Fmiddle-east-and-africa%2F21595480-despite-their-immense-wealth-saudis-are-not-happy-no-satisfaction&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-alriyadh.com-436"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-alriyadh.com_436-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-alriyadh.com_436-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFجريدة_الرياض" class="citation web cs1">جريدة الرياض. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.alriyadh.com/2010/08/05/article549461.html">"جريدة الرياض&nbsp;: سكان المملكة 27 مليوناً بينهم 8 ملايين مقيم"</a>. Alriyadh.com.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%D8%AC%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%AF%D8%A9+%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B6+%3A+%D8%B3%D9%83%D8%A7%D9%86+%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%85%D9%84%D9%83%D8%A9+27+%D9%85%D9%84%D9%8A%D9%88%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%8B+%D8%A8%D9%8A%D9%86%D9%87%D9%85+8+%D9%85%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%8A%D9%8A%D9%86+%D9%85%D9%82%D9%8A%D9%85&amp;rft.pub=Alriyadh.com&amp;rft.au=%D8%AC%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%AF%D8%A9+%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B6&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.alriyadh.com%2F2010%2F08%2F05%2Farticle549461.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-460"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-460">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.pewforum.org/2012/12/18/table-religious-composition-by-country-in-numbers/">Table: Religious Composition by Country, in Numbers</a> Pew Research Center, Washington D.C. (December 2012)</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Gallup-461"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Gallup_461-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">WIN-Gallup 2012 <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://redcresearch.ie/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/RED-C-press-release-Religion-and-Atheism-25-7-12.pdf">Global Index of Religion and atheism</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120812210929/http://redcresearch.ie/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/RED-C-press-release-Religion-and-Atheism-25-7-12.pdf">Archived</a> 12 August 2012 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-462"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-462">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Fisher, M. &amp; Dewey, C.          <li id="cite_note-Peters2003-485"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Peters2003_485-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFPeters2003" class="citation book cs1">Peters, F.E.
