         <li id="cite_note-497"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-497">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">the start of each lunar month determined not ahead of time by astronomical calculation, but only after the crescent moon is sighted by the proper religious authorities. (source: <a href="#HT2009">Tripp, <i>Culture Shock</i>, 2009</a>: pp. 154–155)</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-498"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-498">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRasooldeen,_MohammedHassan,_Rashid2016" class="citation web cs1">Rasooldeen, Mohammed; Hassan, Rashid (3 October 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.arabnews.com/node/993061/saudi-arabia">"KSA switches to Gregorian calendar"</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=KSA+switches+to+Gregorian+calendar&amp;rft.date=2016-10-03&amp;rft.au=Rasooldeen%2C+Mohammed&amp;rft.au=Hassan%2C+Rashid&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.arabnews.com%2Fnode%2F993061%2Fsaudi-arabia&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-500"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-500">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">the time varying according to sunrise and sunset times</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-HT2009:_214-501"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-HT2009:_214_501-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#HT2009">Tripp, <i>Culture Shock</i>, 2009</a>: p. 214</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-502"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-502">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">* Sulaiman, Tosin. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/economics/article697051.ece">Bahrain changes the weekend in efficiency drive</a>, <i>The Times</i>, 2 August 2006. Retrieved 25 June 2008. Turkey has a weekend on Saturday and Sunday 
           <ul>
            <li>Prior to 29 June 2013, the weekend was Thursday-Friday, but was shifted to better serve the Saudi economy and its international commitments. (source: 
             <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20141029175552/http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&amp;contentid=20130624171030">"Weekend shift: A welcome change"</a>. <i>SaudiGazette.com.sa</i>. 24 June 2013. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method%3Dhome.regcon%26contentid%3D20130624171030">the original</a> on 29 October 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">28 October</span> 2014</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=SaudiGazette.com.sa&amp;rft.atitle=Weekend+shift%3A+A+welcome+change&amp;rft.date=2013-06-24&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.saudigazette.com.sa%2Findex.cfm%3Fmethod%253Dhome.regcon%2526contentid%253D20130624171030&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span>)</li>
           </ul> </span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-HT2009:35-503"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-HT2009:35_503-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#HT2009">Tripp, <i>Culture Shock</i>, 2009</a>: p. 35</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-nyrob-relig-educ-504"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-nyrob-relig-educ_504-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-nyrob-relig-educ_504-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRodenbeck2004" class="citation journal cs1">Rodenbeck, Max (21 October 2004). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nybooks.com/articles/17477">"Unloved in Arabia (Book Review)"</a>. <i>The New York Review of Books</i>. <b>51</b> (16). <q>Almost half of Saudi state television's airtime is devoted to religious issues, as is about half the material taught in state schools" (source: By the estimate of an elementary schoolteacher in Riyadh, Islamic studies make up 30 percent of the actual curriculum. But another 20 percent creeps into textbooks on history, science, Arabic, and so forth. In contrast, by one unofficial count the entire syllabus for 12 years of Saudi schooling contains a total of just 38 pages covering the history, literature, and cultures of the non-Muslim world.)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Review+of+Books&amp;rft.atitle=Unloved+in+Arabia+%28Book+Review%29&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=16&amp;rft.date=2004-10-21&amp;rft.aulast=Rodenbeck&amp;rft.aufirst=Max&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nybooks.com%2Farticles%2F17477&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-nyrob-relig-books-505"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-nyrob-relig-books_505-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRodenbeck2004" class="citation journal cs1">Rodenbeck, Max (21 October 2004). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nybooks.com/articles/17477">"Unloved in Arabia (Book Review)"</a>. <i>The New York Review of Books</i>. <b>51</b> (16). <q>Nine out of ten titles published in the kingdom are on religious subjects, and most of the doctorates its universities awards are in Islamic studies.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Review+of+Books&amp;rft.atitle=Unloved+in+Arabia+%28Book+Review%29&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=16&amp;rft.date=2004-10-21&amp;rft.aulast=Rodenbeck&amp;rft.aufirst=Max&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nybooks.com%2Farticles%2F17477&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-506"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-506">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nybooks.com/articles/17477">Review. "Unloved in Arabia"</a> By Max Rodenbeck. <i>The New York Review of Books</i>, Volume 51, Number 16 · 21 October 2004.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-507"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-507">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">from p. 195 of a <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/4284264?seq=4">review</a> by Joshua Teitelbum, <i>Middle East Studies</i>, Vol. 38, No. 4, Oct. 2002, of <i>Changed Identities: The Challenge of the New Generation in Saudi Arabia</i> by anthropologist Mai Yamani, quoting p. 116 |quote=Saudis of all stripes interviewed expressed a desire for the kingdom to remain a Muslim society ruled by an overtly Muslim state. Secularist are simply not to be found. [Both traditional and somewhat westernized Saudis she talked to mediate their concerns] though the certainties of religion.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-IRFR-508"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-IRFR_508-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://2001-2009.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2008/108492.htm">"Saudi Arabia"</a>. <i>U.S. Department of State</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=U.S.+Department+of+State&amp;rft.atitle=Saudi+Arabia&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2F2001-2009.state.gov%2Fg%2Fdrl%2Frls%2Firf%2F2008%2F108492.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-irf2013-509"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-irf2013_509-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/religiousfreedom/index.htm">"Saudi Arabia: International Religious Freedom Report 2013"</a>.          <li id="cite_note-independent.co.uk-520"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-independent.co.uk_520-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/shame-of-the-house-of-saud-shadows-over-mecca-474736.html">'Shame of the House of Saud: Shadows over Mecca'</a>, The Independent, 19 April 2006</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-521"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-521">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://theamericanmuslim.org/tam.php/features/articles/saudi_destruction_of_muslim_historical_sites/">Destruction of Islamic Architectural Heritage in Saudi Arabia: A Wake-up Call</a>, The American Muslim. Retrieved 17 January 2011 Other historic buildings that have been destroyed include the house of <a href="/wiki/Khadijah" class="mw-redirect" title="Khadijah">Khadijah</a>, the wife of Muhammad, the house of <a href="/wiki/Abu_Bakr" title="Abu Bakr">Abu Bakr</a>, now the site of the local <a href="/wiki/Hilton_hotel" class="mw-redirect" title="Hilton hotel">Hilton hotel</a>; the house of Ali-Oraid, the grandson of Muhammad, and the Mosque of abu-Qubais, now the location of the King's palace in Mecca. (source: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/shame-of-the-house-of-saud-shadows-over-mecca-474736.html">'Shame of the House of Saud: Shadows over Mecca'</a>, <i>The Independent</i>, 19 April 2006)</span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-548"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-548">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.arabianbusiness.com/saudi-women-push-for-right-play-sports-447831.html">"Saudi women push for right to play sports – Sport"</a>.              <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.women-without-borders.org/files/downloads/111104_Gulf_Analysis_Saudi_Youth.pdf">"Saudi Youth: Unveiling the Force for Change"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Saudi+Youth%3A+Unveiling+the+Force+for+Change&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.women-without-borders.org%2Ffiles%2Fdownloads%2F111104_Gulf_Analysis_Saudi_Youth.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span></li>

         <li id="cite_note-569"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-569">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">* <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/01/17/saudi.child.marriage/">'Top Saudi cleric: OK for young girls to wed'</a> CNN, 17 January 2009; Retrieved 18 January 2011

         <li id="cite_note-621"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-621">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation journal cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/gdpr-consent/?next_url=https%3a%2f%2fwww.washingtonpost.com%2fworld%2fmiddle_east%2fsaudi-arabia-textbooks-education-curriculum%2f2021%2f01%2f30%2f28ebe632-5a54-11eb-a849-6f9423a75ffd_story.html">"Saudi Arabia scrubs school textbooks of some offensive text"</a>. <i>The Washington Post</i>. 30 January 2021.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Washington+Post&amp;rft.atitle=Saudi+Arabia+scrubs+school+textbooks+of+some+offensive+text&amp;rft.date=2021-01-30&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.washingtonpost.com%2Fgdpr-consent%2F%3Fnext_url%3Dhttps%253a%252f%252fwww.washingtonpost.com%252fworld%252fmiddle_east%252fsaudi-arabia-textbooks-education-curriculum%252f2021%252f01%252f30%252f28ebe632-5a54-11eb-a849-6f9423a75ffd_story.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASaudi+Arabia" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-:1-622"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:1_622-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:1_622-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.DYN.LE00.IN?locations=SA&amp;most_recent_value_desc=true">"Life expectancy at birth, total (years) – Saudi Arabia | Data"</a>. <i>data.worldbank.org</i><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-623"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-623">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

                   <li><a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a></li> 
                   <li><i><a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Ocean_Territory" title="British Indian Ocean Territory">British Indian Ocean Territory</a> <span style="font-size:85%;">United Kingdom</span></i></li> 
                   <li><i><a href="/wiki/Christmas_Island" title="Christmas Island">Christmas Island</a></i> <span style="font-size:85%;">(Australia)</span></li> 
                   <li><i><a href="/wiki/Cocos_(Keeling)_Islands" title="Cocos (Keeling) Islands">Cocos (Keeling) Islands</a></i> <span style="font-size:85%;">(Australia)</span></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Kuwait" title="Kuwait">Kuwait</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Maldives" title="Maldives">Maldives</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a></li> 
                   <li><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Saudi Arabia</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/East_Timor" title="East Timor">Timor-Leste</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a></li>
                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
               </tr>
               <tr>
                <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Other</th>
                <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">

                    <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;text-align:left;padding-right:0.75em;font-weight:normal;">
                     <div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">
                      Muslim
                      <br>communities
                     </div></th>
                    <td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
                     <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
                      <ul>
                       <li><a href="/wiki/Moro_National_Liberation_Front" title="Moro National Liberation Front">Moro National Liberation Front</a></li>
                      </ul> 
                     </div></td>
                   </tr>
                   <tr>
                    <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;text-align:left;padding-right:0.75em;font-weight:normal;">
                     <div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">
                      International
                      <br>organizations
                     </div></th>
                    <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
                     <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
                      <ul>
                       <li><a href="/wiki/Economic_Cooperation_Organization" title="Economic Cooperation Organization">Economic Cooperation Organization</a></li> 
                       <li><a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">African Union</a></li> 
                       <li><a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a></li> 
                       <li><a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a></li> 
                       <li><a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a></li>
                      </ul> 
                     </div></td>
                   </tr>
                  </tbody>
                 </table>
                 <div></div></td>
               </tr>
               <tr>
                <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2">
                 <div> 
                  <ul>
                   <li><sup><small>1</small></sup> As the "Turkish Cypriot State".</li>
                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>

             </table>

       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-zea"><a href="https://zea.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saoedi-Araobi%C3%AB" title="Saoedi-Araobië – Zeelandic" lang="zea" hreflang="zea" class="interlanguage-link-target">Zeêuws</a></li>
       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-bat-smg"><a href="https://bat-smg.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sauda_Arab%C4%97j%C4%97" title="Sauda Arabėjė – Samogitian" lang="sgs" hreflang="sgs" class="interlanguage-link-target">Žemaitėška</a></li>
       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-zh"><a href="https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%B2%99%E7%89%B9%E9%98%BF%E6%8B%89%E4%BC%AF" title="沙特阿拉伯 – Chinese" lang="zh" hreflang="zh" class="interlanguage-link-target">中文</a></li>

      </ul>
